and the PAH's -- the aromatic hydrocarbons --

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
went from 10,000 parts per million to less than 200 in eight weeks.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
The last image we don't have.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
The entire pile was a green berm of life.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
These are gateway species,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:34.958
vanguard species that open the door for other biological communities.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
So I invented burlap sacks, bunker spawn --

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and putting the mycelium -- using storm blown debris,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
you can take these burlap sacks and put them downstream

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
from a farm that's producing E. coli, or other wastes,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
or a factory with chemical toxins,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
and it leads to habitat restoration.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
So, we set up a site in Mason County, Washington,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
and we've seen a dramatic decrease in the amount of coliforms.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
And I'll show you a graph here.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
This is a logarithmic scale, 10 to the eighth power.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
There's more than a 100 million colonies per gram,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
and 10 to the third power is around 1,000.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
In 48 hours to 72 hours, these three mushroom species

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
reduced the amount of coliform bacteria 10,000 times.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
Think of the implications.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
This is a space-conservative method that uses storm debris --

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and we can guarantee that we will have storms every year.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:29.958
So, this one mushroom, in particular, has drawn our interest over time.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
This is my wife Dusty,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
with a mushroom called Fomitopsis officinalis -- Agarikon.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
It's a mushroom exclusive to the old-growth forest

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
that Dioscorides first described in 65 A.D.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
as a treatment against consumption.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
This mushroom grows in Washington State, Oregon,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
northern California, British Columbia, now thought to be extinct in Europe.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
May not seem that large --

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
let's get closer.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
This is extremely rare fungus.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Our team -- and we have a team of experts that go out --

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
we went out 20 times in the old-growth forest last year.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
We found one sample to be able to get into culture.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:05.958
Preserving the genome of these fungi in the old-growth forest

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
I think is absolutely critical for human health.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
I've been involved with the U.S. Defense Department BioShield program.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
We submitted over 300 samples of mushrooms that were boiled in hot water,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and mycelium harvesting these extracellular metabolites.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And a few years ago,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
we received these results.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
We have three different strains of Agarikon mushrooms

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
that were highly active against poxviruses.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
Dr. Earl Kern, who's a smallpox expert

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
of the U.S. Defense Department, states that any compounds

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
that have a selectivity index of two or more are active.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
10 or greater are considered to be very active.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Our mushroom strains were in the highly active range.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
There's a vetted press release that you can read --

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
it's vetted by DOD --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
if you Google "Stamets" and "smallpox."

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Or you can go to NPR.org and listen to a live interview.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
So, encouraged by this, naturally we went to flu viruses.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
And so, for the first time, I am showing this.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
We have three different strains of Agarikon mushrooms

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
highly active against flu viruses.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
Here's the selectivity index numbers --

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
against pox, you saw 10s and 20s -- now against flu viruses,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
compared to the ribavirin controls,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
we have an extraordinarily high activity.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And we're using a natural extract

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
within the same dosage window as a pure pharmaceutical.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.958
We tried it against flu A viruses -- H1N1, H3N2 --

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
as well as flu B viruses.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
So then we tried a blend,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and in a blend combination we tried it against H5N1,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
and we got greater than 1,000 selectivity index.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:39.958
(Applause)

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:44.958
I then think that we can make the argument

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
that we should save the old-growth forest

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
as a matter of national defense.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
(Applause)

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
I became interested in entomopathogenic fungi --

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
fungi that kill insects.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
Our house was being destroyed by carpenter ants.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So, I went to the EPA homepage, and they were recommending studies

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
with metarhizium species of a group of fungi

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
that kill carpenter ants, as well as termites.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
I did something that nobody else had done.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
I actually chased the mycelium, when it stopped producing spores.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
These are spores -- this is in their spores.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
I was able to morph the culture

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
into a non-sporulating form.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And so the industry has spent over 100 million dollars

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
specifically on bait stations to prevent termites from eating your house.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
But the insects aren't stupid,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
and they would avoid the spores when they came close,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
and so I morphed the cultures into a non-sporulating form.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
And I got my daughter's Barbie doll dish,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
I put it right where a bunch of carpenter ants

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
were making debris fields, every day,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
in my house, and the ants were attracted to the mycelium,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
because there's no spores.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:48.958
They gave it to the queen.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
One week later, I had no sawdust piles whatsoever.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And then -- a delicate dance between dinner and death --

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
the mycelium is consumed by the ants,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
they become mummified, and, boing, a mushroom pops out of their head.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:05.958
(Laughter)

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Now after sporulation, the spores repel.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
So, the house is no longer suitable for invasion.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
So, you have a near-permanent solution for reinvasion of termites.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And so my house came down, I received my first patent

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
against carpenter ants, termites and fire ants.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Then we tried extracts, and lo and behold,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
we can steer insects to different directions.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
This has huge implications.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
I then received my second patent -- and this is a big one.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
It's been called an Alexander Graham Bell patent.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
It covers over 200,000 species.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
This is the most disruptive technology --

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
I've been told by executives of the pesticide industry --

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
that they have ever witnessed.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
This could totally revamp the pesticide industries throughout the world.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:49.958
You could fly 100 Ph.D. students under the umbrella of this concept,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
because my supposition is that entomopathogenic fungi,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
prior to sporulation, attract the very insects

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
that are otherwise repelled by those spores.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And so I came up with a Life Box, because I needed a delivery system.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
The Life Box -- you're gonna be getting a DVD of the TED conference --

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
you add soil, you add water,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:12.958
you have mycorrhizal and endophytic fungi as well as spores,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
like of the Agarikon mushroom.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
The seeds then are mothered by this mycelium.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And then you put tree seeds in here,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and then you end up growing -- potentially --

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
an old-growth forest from a cardboard box.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
I want to reinvent the delivery system,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
and the use of cardboard around the world,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
so they become ecological footprints.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
If there's a YouTube-like site that you could put up,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
you could make it interactive, zip code specific --

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
where people could join together,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
and through satellite imaging systems,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
through Virtual Earth or Google Earth,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
you could confirm carbon credits are being sequestered

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
by the trees that are coming through Life Boxes.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
You could take a cardboard box delivering shoes,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
you could add water -- I developed this for the refugee community --

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
corns, beans and squash and onions.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:01.958
I took several containers -- my wife said, if I could do this, anybody could --

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
and I ended up growing a seed garden.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
Then you harvest the seeds --

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
and thank you, Eric Rasmussen, for your help on this --

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
and then you're harvesting the seed garden.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.958
Then you can harvest the kernels, and then you just need a few kernels.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:19.958
I add mycelium to it, and then I inoculate the corncobs.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
Now, three corncobs, no other grain --

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
lots of mushrooms begin to form.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Too many withdrawals from the carbon bank,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and so this population will be shut down.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
But watch what happens here.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
The mushrooms then are harvested,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
but very importantly,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
the mycelium has converted the cellulose into fungal sugars.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:47.958
And so I thought, how could we address the energy crisis in this country?

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
And we came up with Econol.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:57.958
Generating ethanol from cellulose using mycelium as an intermediary --

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
and you gain all the benefits that I've described to you already.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:05.958
But to go from cellulose to ethanol is ecologically unintelligent,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
and I think that we need to be econologically intelligent

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
about the generation of fuels.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
So, we build the carbon banks on the planet, renew the soils.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
These are a species that we need to join with.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:22.958
I think engaging mycelium can help save the world.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
(Applause)

title: Can we domesticate germs?
transcript: What I'd like to do is just drag us all down into the gutter, and actually all the way down into the sewer because I want to talk about diarrhea. And in particular, I want to talk about the design of diarrhea. And when evolutionary biologists talk about design, they really mean design by natural selection. And that brings me to the title of the talk, "Using Evolution to Design Disease Organisms Intelligently." And I also have a little bit of a sort of smartass subtitle to this. But I'm not just doing this to be cute. I really think that this subtitle explains what somebody like me, who's sort of a Darwin wannabe, how they actually look at one's role in sort of coming into this field of health sciences and medicine. It's really not a very friendly field for evolutionary biologists. You actually see a great potential, but you see a lot of people who are sort of defending their turf, and may actually be very resistant, when one tries to introduce ideas.So, all of the talk today is going to deal with two general questions. One is that, why are some disease organisms more harmful? And a very closely related question, which is, how can we take control of this situation once we understand the answer to the first question? How can we make the harmful organisms more mild? And I'm going to be talking, to begin with, as I said, about diarrheal disease organisms. And the focus when I'm talking about the diarrheal organisms, as well as the focus when I'm talking about any organisms that cause acute infectious disease, is to think about the problem from a germ's point of view, germ's-eye view. And in particular, to think about a fundamental idea which I think makes sense out of a tremendous amount of variation in the harmfulness of disease organisms. And that idea is that from the germ's-eye point of view, disease organisms have to get from one host to another, and often they have to rely on the well-being of the host to move them to another host.But not always. Sometimes, you get disease organisms that don't rely on host mobility at all for transmission. And when you have that, then evolutionary theory tells us that natural selection will favor the more exploitative, more predator-like organisms. So, natural selection will favor organisms that are more likely to cause damage. If instead transmission to another host requires host mobility, then we expect that the winners of the competition will be the milder organisms. So, if the pathogen doesn't need the host to be healthy and active, and actual selection favors pathogens that take advantage of those hosts, the winners in the competition are those that exploit the hosts for their own reproductive success. But if the host needs to be mobile in order to transmit the pathogen, then it's the benign ones that tend to be the winners.So, I'm going to begin by applying this idea to diarrheal diseases. Diarrheal disease organisms get transmitted in basically three ways. They can be transmitted from person-to-person contact, person-to-food-then-to-person contact, when somebody eats contaminated food, or they can be transmitted through the water. And when they're transmitted through the water, unlike the first two modes of transmission, these pathogens don't rely on a healthy host for transmission. A person can be sick in bed and still infect tens, even hundreds of other individuals. To sort of illustrate that, this diagram emphasizes that if you've got a sick person in bed, somebody's going to be taking out the contaminated materials. They're going to wash those contaminated materials, and then the water may move into sources of drinking water. People will come in to those places where you've got contaminated drinking water, bring things back to the family, may drink right at that point. The whole point is that a person who can't move can still infect many other individuals.And so, the theory tells us that when diarrheal disease organisms are transported by water, we expect them to be more predator-like, more harmful. And you can test these ideas. So, one way you can test is just look at all diarrheal bacteria, and see whether or not the ones that tend to be more transmitted by water, tend to be more harmful. And the answer is — yep, they are. Now I put those names in there just for the bacteria buffs, but the main point here is that — (Laughter) there's a lot of them here, I can tell — the main point here is that those data points all show a very strong, positive association between the degree to which a disease organism is transmitted by water, and how harmful they are, how much death they cause per untreated infection. So this suggests we're on the right track. But this, to me, suggests that we really need to ask some additional questions.Remember the second question that I raised at the outset was, how can we use this knowledge to make disease organisms evolve to be mild? Now, this suggests that if you could just block waterborne transmission, you could cause disease organisms to shift from the right-hand side of that graph to the left-hand side of the graph. But it doesn't tell you how long. I mean, if this would require thousands of years, then it's worthless in terms of controlling of these pathogens. But if it could occur in just a few years, then it might be a very important way to control some of the nasty problems that we haven't been able to control. In other words, this suggests that we could domesticate these organisms. We could make them evolve to be not so harmful to us.And so, as I was thinking about this, I focused on this organism, which is the El Tor biotype of the organism called Vibrio cholerae. And that is the species of organism that is responsible for causing cholera. And the reason I thought this is a really great organism to look at is that we understand why it's so harmful. It's harmful because it produces a toxin, and that toxin is released when the organism gets into our intestinal tract. It causes fluid to flow from the cells that line our intestine into the lumen, the internal chamber of our intestine, and then that fluid goes the only way it can, which is out the other end. And it flushes out thousands of different other competitors that would otherwise make life difficult for the Vibrios.So what happens, if you've got an organism, it produces a lot of toxin. After a few days of infection you end up having — the fecal material really isn't so disgusting as we might imagine. It's sort of cloudy water. And if you took a drop of that water, you might find a million diarrheal organisms. If the organism produced a lot of toxin, you might find 10 million, or 100 million. If it didn't produce a lot of this toxin, then you might find a smaller number. So the task is to try to figure out how to determine whether or not you could get an organism like this to evolve towards mildness by blocking waterborne transmission, thereby allowing the organism only to be transmitted by person-to-person contact, or person-food-person contact — both of which would really require that people be mobile and fairly healthy for transmission.Now, I can think of some possible experiments. One would be to take a lot of different strains of this organism — some that produce a lot of toxins, some that produce a little — and take those strains and spew them out in different countries. Some countries that might have clean water supplies, so that you can't get waterborne transmission: you expect the organism to evolve to mildness there. Other countries, in which you've got a lot of waterborne transmission, there you expect these organisms to evolve towards a high level of harmfulness, right? There's a little ethical problem in this experiment. I was hoping to hear a few gasps at least. That makes me worry a little bit.(Laughter)But anyhow, the laughter makes me feel a little bit better. And this ethical problem's a big problem. Just to emphasize this, this is what we're really talking about. Here's a girl who's almost dead. She got rehydration therapy, she perked up, within a few days she was looking like a completely different person. So, we don't want to run an experiment like that. But interestingly, just that thing happened in 1991. In 1991, this cholera organism got into Lima, Peru, and within two months it had spread to the neighboring areas. Now, I don't know how that happened, and I didn't have anything to do with it, I promise you. I don't think anybody knows, but I'm not averse to, once that's happened, to see whether or not the prediction that we would make, that I did make before, actually holds up. Did the organism evolve to mildness in a place like Chile, which has some of the most well protected water supplies in Latin America? And did it evolve to be more harmful in a place like Ecuador, which has some of the least well protected? And Peru's got something sort of in between.And so, with funding from the Bosack-Kruger Foundation, I got a lot of strains from these different countries and we measured their toxin production in the lab. And we found that in Chile — within two months of the invasion of Peru you had strains entering Chile — and when you look at those strains, in the very far left-hand side of this graph, you see a lot of variation in the toxin production. Each dot corresponds to an islet from a different person — a lot of variation on which natural selection can act. But the interesting point is, if you look over the 1990s, within a few years the organisms evolved to be more mild. They evolved to produce less toxin. And to just give you a sense of how important this might be, if we look in 1995, we find that there's only one case of cholera, on average, reported from Chile every two years.So, it's controlled. That's how much we have in America, cholera that's acquired endemically, and we don't think we've got a problem here. They didn't — they solved the problem in Chile. But, before we get too confident, we'd better look at some of those other countries, and make sure that this organism doesn't just always evolve toward mildness. Well, in Peru it didn't. And in Ecuador — remember, this is the place where it has the highest potential waterborne transmission — it looked like it got more harmful. In every case there's a lot of variation, but something about the environment the people are living in, and I think the only realistic explanation is that it's the degree of waterborne transmission, favored the harmful strains in one place, and mild strains in another.So, this is very encouraging, it suggests that something that we might want to do anyhow, if we had enough money, could actually give us a much bigger bang for the buck. It would make these organisms evolve to mildness, so that even though people might be getting infected, they'd be infected with mild strains. It wouldn't be causing severe disease. But there's another really interesting aspect of this, and this is that if you could control the evolution of virulence, evolution of harmfulness, then you should be able to control antibiotic resistance. And the idea is very simple. If you've got a harmful organism, a high proportion of the people are going to be symptomatic, a high proportion of the people are going to be going to get antibiotics. You've got a lot of pressure favoring antibiotic resistance, so you get increased virulence leading to the evolution of increased antibiotic resistance. And once you get increased antibiotic resistance, the antibiotics aren't knocking out the harmful strains anymore. So, you've got a higher level of virulence.So, you get this vicious cycle. The goal is to turn this around. If you could cause an evolutionary decrease in virulence by cleaning up the water supply, you should be able to get an evolutionary decrease in antibiotic resistance. So, we can go to the same countries and look and see. Did Chile avoid the problem of antibiotic resistance, whereas did Ecuador actually have the beginnings of the problem? If we look in the beginning of the 1990s, we see, again, a lot of variation. In this case, on the Y-axis, we've just got a measure of antibiotic sensitivity — and I won't go into that. But we've got a lot of variation in antibiotic sensitivity in Chile, Peru and Ecuador, and no trend across the years. But if we look at the end of the 1990s, just half a decade later, we see that in Ecuador they started having a resistance problem. Antibiotic sensitivity was going down. And in Chile, you still had antibiotic sensitivity.So, it looks like Chile dodged two bullets. They got the organism to evolve to mildness, and they got no development of antibiotic resistance. Now, these ideas should apply across the board, as long as you can figure out why some organisms evolved to virulence. And I want to give you just one more example, because we've talked a little bit about malaria. And the example I want to deal with is, or the idea I want to deal with, the question is, what can we do to try to get the malarial organism to evolve to mildness? Now, malaria's transmitted by a mosquito, and normally if you're infected with malaria, and you're feeling sick, it makes it even easier for the mosquito to bite you.And you can show, just by looking at data from literature, that vector-borne diseases are more harmful than non-vector-borne diseases. But I think there's a really fascinating example of what one can do experimentally to try to actually demonstrate this. In the case of waterborne transmission, we'd like to clean up the water supplies, see whether or not we can get those organisms to evolve towards mildness. In the case of malaria, what we'd like to do is mosquito-proof houses. And the logic's a little more subtle here. If you mosquito-proof houses, when people get sick, they're sitting in bed — or in mosquito-proof hospitals, they're sitting in a hospital bed — and the mosquitoes can't get to them.So, if you're a harmful variant in a place where you've got mosquito-proof housing, then you're a loser. The only pathogens that get transmitted are the ones that are infecting people that feel healthy enough to walk outside and get mosquito bites. So, if you were to mosquito proof houses, you should be able to get these organisms to evolve to mildness. And there's a really wonderful experiment that was done that suggests that we really should go ahead and do this. And that experiment was done in Northern Alabama. Just to give you a little perspective on this, I've given you a star at the intellectual center of the United States, which is right there in Louisville, Kentucky. And this really cool experiment was done about 200 miles south of there, in Northern Alabama, by the Tennessee Valley Authority. They had dammed up the Tennessee River. They'd caused the water to back up, they needed electric, hydroelectric power. And when you get stagnant water, you get mosquitoes. They found in the late '30s — 10 years after they'd made these dams — that the people in Northern Alabama were infected with malaria, about a third to half of them were infected with malaria.This shows you the positions of some of these dams. OK, so the Tennessee Valley Authority was in a little bit of a bind. There wasn't DDT, there wasn't chloroquines: what do they do? Well, they decided to mosquito proof every house in Northern Alabama. So they did. They divided Northern Alabama into 11 zones, and within three years, about 100 dollars per house, they mosquito proofed every house. And these are the data. Every row across here represents one of those 11 zones. And the asterisks represent the time at which the mosquito proofing was complete. And so what you can see is that just the mosquito-proofed housing, and nothing else, caused the eradication of malaria. And this was, incidentally, published in 1949, in the leading textbook of malaria, called "Boyd's Malariology." But almost no malaria experts even know it exists. This is important, because it tells us that if you have moderate biting densities, you can eradicate malaria by mosquito proofing houses.Now, I would suggest that you could do this in a lot of places. Like, you know, just as you get into the malaria zone, sub-Saharan Africa. But as you move to really intense biting rate areas, like Nigeria, you're certainly not going to eradicate. But that's when you should be favoring evolution towards mildness. So to me, it's an experiment that's waiting to happen, and if it confirms the prediction, then we should have a very powerful tool. In a way, much more powerful than the kind of tools we're looking at, because most of what's being done today is to rely on things like anti-malarial drugs. And we know that, although it's great to make those anti-malarial drugs available at really low cost and high frequency, we know that when you make them highly available you're going to get resistance to those drugs. And so it's a short-term solution. This is a long-term solution.What I'm suggesting here is that we could get evolution working in the direction we want it to go, rather than always having to battle evolution as a problem that stymies our efforts to control the pathogen, for example with anti-malarial drugs. So, this table I've given just to emphasize that I've only talked about two examples. But as I said earlier, this kind of logic applies across the board for infectious diseases, and it ought to. Because when we're dealing with infectious diseases, we're dealing with living systems. We're dealing with living systems; we're dealing with systems that evolve. And so if you do something with those systems, they're going to evolve one way or another. And all I'm saying is that we need to figure out how they'll evolve, so that — we need to adjust our interventions to get the most bang for the intervention buck, so that we can get these organisms to evolve in the direction we want them to go.So, I don't really have time to talk about those things, but I did want to put them up there, just to give you a sense that there really are solutions to controlling the evolution of harmfulness of some of the nasty pathogens that we're confronted with. And this links up with a lot of the other ideas that have been talked about. So, for example, earlier today there was discussion of, how do you really lower sexual transmission of HIV? What this emphasizes is that we need to figure out how it will work. Will it maybe get lowered if we alter the economy of the area? It may get lowered if we intervene in ways that encourage people to stay more faithful to partners, and so on.But the key thing is to figure out how to lower it, because if we lower it, we'll get an evolutionary change in the virus. And the data really do support this: that you actually do get the virus evolving towards mildness. And that will just add to the effectiveness of our control efforts. So the other thing I really like about this, besides the fact that it brings a whole new dimension into the study of control of disease, is that often the kinds of interventions that you want, that it indicates should be done, are the kinds of interventions that people want anyhow. But people just haven't been able to justify the cost.So, this is the kind of thing I'm talking about. If we know that we're going to get extra bang for the buck from providing clean water, then I think that we can say, let's push the effort into that aspect of the control, so that we can actually solve the problem, even though, if you just look at the frequency of infection, you would suggest that you can't solve the problem well enough just by cleaning up water supply. Anyhow, I'll end that there, and thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
What I'd like to do is just drag us all down into the gutter,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
and actually all the way down into the sewer

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
because I want to talk about diarrhea.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:22.958
And in particular, I want to talk about

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
the design of diarrhea.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
And when evolutionary biologists talk about design,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:30.958
they really mean design by natural selection.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
And that brings me to the title of the talk,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:36.958
"Using Evolution to Design Disease Organisms Intelligently."

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
And I also have a little bit of a sort of smartass subtitle to this.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
But I'm not just doing this to be cute.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
I really think that this subtitle explains

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
what somebody like me, who's sort of a Darwin wannabe,

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
how they actually look at one's role in

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:55.958
sort of coming into this field of health sciences and medicine.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
It's really not a very friendly field for evolutionary biologists.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
You actually see a great potential,

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
but you see a lot of people who are sort of defending their turf,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:07.958
and may actually be very resistant, when one tries

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
to introduce ideas.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:14.958
So, all of the talk today is going to deal with two general questions.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
One is that, why are some disease organisms more harmful?

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
And a very closely related question, which is,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:23.958
how can we take control of this situation once we understand

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:24.958
the answer to the first question?

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
How can we make the harmful organisms more mild?

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
And I'm going to be talking, to begin with, as I said,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
about diarrheal disease organisms.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
And the focus when I'm talking about the diarrheal organisms,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
as well as the focus when I'm talking about any organisms

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
that cause acute infectious disease,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
is to think about the problem from a germ's point of view,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
germ's-eye view.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:48.958
And in particular, to think about a fundamental idea

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
which I think makes sense out of a tremendous amount of variation

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
in the harmfulness of disease organisms.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:58.958
And that idea is that from the germ's-eye point of view,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
disease organisms have to get from one host to another,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and often they have to rely on the well-being of the host

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
to move them to another host.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
But not always.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
Sometimes, you get disease organisms

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
that don't rely on host mobility at all for transmission.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
And when you have that, then evolutionary theory tells us

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.958
that natural selection will favor the more exploitative,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
more predator-like organisms.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
So, natural selection will favor organisms

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
that are more likely to cause damage.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:30.958
If instead transmission to another host requires host mobility,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
then we expect that the winners of the competition

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
will be the milder organisms.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
So, if the pathogen doesn't need the host to be healthy and active,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
and actual selection favors pathogens

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
that take advantage of those hosts,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
the winners in the competition are those that exploit the hosts

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
for their own reproductive success.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:52.958
But if the host needs to be mobile in order to transmit the pathogen,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
then it's the benign ones that tend to be the winners.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:58.958
So, I'm going to begin by applying this idea to diarrheal diseases.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
Diarrheal disease organisms get transmitted in basically three ways.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
They can be transmitted from person-to-person contact,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
person-to-food-then-to-person contact,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
when somebody eats contaminated food,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
or they can be transmitted through the water.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
And when they're transmitted through the water,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
unlike the first two modes of transmission,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:18.958
these pathogens don't rely on a healthy host for transmission.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
A person can be sick in bed and still infect tens, even hundreds

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:21.958
of other individuals.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
To sort of illustrate that, this diagram emphasizes that

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
if you've got a sick person in bed,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
somebody's going to be taking out the contaminated materials.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:31.958
They're going to wash those contaminated materials,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
and then the water may move into sources of drinking water.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
People will come in to those places where you've got

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:39.958
contaminated drinking water,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:40.958
bring things back to the family,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:41.958
may drink right at that point.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
The whole point is that a person who can't move

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
can still infect many other individuals.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And so, the theory tells us that

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:54.958
when diarrheal disease organisms are transported by water,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
we expect them to be more predator-like, more harmful.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
And you can test these ideas.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
So, one way you can test is just look at all diarrheal bacteria,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
and see whether or not the ones that tend to be

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
more transmitted by water, tend to be more harmful.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
And the answer is -- yep, they are.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
Now I put those names in there just for the bacteria buffs,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
but the main point here is that --

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:13.958
(Laughter)

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:14.958
there's a lot of them here, I can tell --

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
the main point here is that those data points

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
all show a very strong, positive association between

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
the degree to which a disease organism is transmitted by water,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:25.958
and how harmful they are,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
how much death they cause per untreated infection.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
So this suggests we're on the right track.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:35.958
But this, to me, suggests that we really need

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:36.958
to ask some additional questions.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
Remember the second question that I raised at the outset was,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
how can we use this knowledge

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
to make disease organisms evolve to be mild?

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Now, this suggests that if you could just block waterborne transmission,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
you could cause disease organisms to shift from

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
the right-hand side of that graph to the left-hand side of the graph.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
But it doesn't tell you how long.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
I mean, if this would require thousands of years,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
then it's worthless in terms of controlling of these pathogens.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
But if it could occur in just a few years,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
then it might be a very important way to control

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
some of the nasty problems that we haven't been able to control.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
In other words, this suggests that we could

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
domesticate these organisms.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
We could make them evolve to be not so harmful to us.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And so, as I was thinking about this, I focused on this organism,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:21.958
which is the El Tor biotype of the organism called Vibrio cholerae.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.958
And that is the species of organism that is responsible

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
for causing cholera.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
And the reason I thought this is a really great organism to look at

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
is that we understand why it's so harmful.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
It's harmful because it produces a toxin,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and that toxin is released when the organism

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:38.958
gets into our intestinal tract.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
It causes fluid to flow from the cells that line our intestine

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
into the lumen, the internal chamber of our intestine,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
and then that fluid goes the only way it can, which is out the other end.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
And it flushes out thousands of different other competitors

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
that would otherwise make life difficult for the Vibrios.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
So what happens, if you've got an organism,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:57.958
it produces a lot of toxin.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
After a few days of infection you end up having --

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
the fecal material really isn't so disgusting as we might imagine.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
It's sort of cloudy water.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
And if you took a drop of that water,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
you might find a million diarrheal organisms.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
If the organism produced a lot of toxin,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
you might find 10 million, or 100 million.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
If it didn't produce a lot of this toxin,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
then you might find a smaller number.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
So the task is to try to figure out

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
how to determine whether or not you could get an organism like this

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
to evolve towards mildness by blocking waterborne transmission,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
thereby allowing the organism only to be transmitted

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
by person-to-person contact,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:34.958
or person-food-person contact --

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
both of which would really require that people be

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
mobile and fairly healthy for transmission.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Now, I can think of some possible experiments.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
One would be to take a lot of different strains of this organism --

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
some that produce a lot of toxins, some that produce a little --

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:51.958
and take those strains and spew them out in different countries.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
Some countries that might have clean water supplies,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:55.958
so that you can't get waterborne transmission:

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
you expect the organism to evolve to mildness there.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
Other countries, in which you've got a lot of waterborne transmission,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
there you expect these organisms to evolve

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
towards a high level of harmfulness, right?

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
There's a little ethical problem in this experiment.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
I was hoping to hear a few gasps at least.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
That makes me worry a little bit.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:15.958
(Laughter)

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
But anyhow, the laughter makes me feel a little bit better.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
And this ethical problem's a big problem.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Just to emphasize this, this is what we're really talking about.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
Here's a girl who's almost dead.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
She got rehydration therapy, she perked up,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
within a few days she was looking like a completely different person.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
So, we don't want to run an experiment like that.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But interestingly, just that thing happened in 1991.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
In 1991, this cholera organism got into Lima, Peru,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
and within two months it had spread to the neighboring areas.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Now, I don't know how that happened,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
and I didn't have anything to do with it, I promise you.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
I don't think anybody knows,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
but I'm not averse to, once that's happened,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
to see whether or not the prediction that we would make,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
that I did make before, actually holds up.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Did the organism evolve to mildness in a place like Chile,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
which has some of the most well protected water supplies

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:08.958
in Latin America?

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
And did it evolve to be more harmful in a place like Ecuador,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
which has some of the least well protected?

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And Peru's got something sort of in between.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And so, with funding from the Bosack-Kruger Foundation,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
I got a lot of strains from these different countries

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
and we measured their toxin production in the lab.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
And we found that in Chile -- within two months of the invasion of Peru

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
you had strains entering Chile --

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
and when you look at those strains,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
in the very far left-hand side of this graph,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
you see a lot of variation in the toxin production.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
Each dot corresponds to an islet from a different person --

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
a lot of variation on which natural selection can act.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
But the interesting point is, if you look over the 1990s,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
within a few years the organisms evolved to be more mild.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:52.958
They evolved to produce less toxin.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
And to just give you a sense of how important this might be,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:09:00.958
if we look in 1995, we find that there's only one case of cholera,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
on average, reported from Chile every two years.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
So, it's controlled.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
That's how much we have in America,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
cholera that's acquired endemically,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and we don't think we've got a problem here.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
They didn't -- they solved the problem in Chile.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
But, before we get too confident, we'd better look at some of those other countries,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and make sure that this organism doesn't just always evolve toward mildness.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Well, in Peru it didn't.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
And in Ecuador -- remember, this is the place where it has

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
the highest potential waterborne transmission --

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:26.958
it looked like it got more harmful.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
In every case there's a lot of variation,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
but something about the environment the people are living in,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
and I think the only realistic explanation is that it's

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
the degree of waterborne transmission,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
favored the harmful strains in one place, and mild strains in another.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
So, this is very encouraging,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
it suggests that something that we might want to do anyhow,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
if we had enough money, could actually give us a much bigger bang for the buck.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
It would make these organisms evolve to mildness,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
so that even though people might be getting infected,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
they'd be infected with mild strains.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
It wouldn't be causing severe disease.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
But there's another really interesting aspect of this,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and this is that if you could control the evolution of virulence,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
evolution of harmfulness,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
then you should be able to control antibiotic resistance.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And the idea is very simple.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
If you've got a harmful organism,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
a high proportion of the people are going to be symptomatic,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
a high proportion of the people are going to be going to get antibiotics.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
You've got a lot of pressure favoring antibiotic resistance,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
so you get increased virulence leading to

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
the evolution of increased antibiotic resistance.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
And once you get increased antibiotic resistance,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
the antibiotics aren't knocking out the harmful strains anymore.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
So, you've got a higher level of virulence.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
So, you get this vicious cycle.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
The goal is to turn this around.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
If you could cause an evolutionary decrease in virulence

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
by cleaning up the water supply,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
you should be able to get an evolutionary decrease

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
in antibiotic resistance.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
So, we can go to the same countries and look and see.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Did Chile avoid the problem of antibiotic resistance,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
whereas did Ecuador actually have the beginnings of the problem?

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
If we look in the beginning of the 1990s,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
we see, again, a lot of variation.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
In this case, on the Y-axis, we've just got a measure of antibiotic sensitivity --

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and I won't go into that.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
But we've got a lot of variation in antibiotic sensitivity in Chile,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Peru and Ecuador, and no trend across the years.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.958
But if we look at the end of the 1990s, just half a decade later,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
we see that in Ecuador they started having a resistance problem.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
Antibiotic sensitivity was going down.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
And in Chile, you still had antibiotic sensitivity.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
So, it looks like Chile dodged two bullets.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
They got the organism to evolve to mildness,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and they got no development of antibiotic resistance.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Now, these ideas should apply across the board,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
as long as you can figure out why some organisms evolved to virulence.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
And I want to give you just one more example,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
because we've talked a little bit about malaria.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And the example I want to deal with is,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
or the idea I want to deal with, the question is,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
what can we do to try to get the malarial organism to evolve to mildness?

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
Now, malaria's transmitted by a mosquito,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
and normally if you're infected with malaria, and you're feeling sick,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
it makes it even easier for the mosquito to bite you.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And you can show, just by looking at data from literature,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
that vector-borne diseases are more harmful

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
than non-vector-borne diseases.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
But I think there's a really fascinating example

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
of what one can do experimentally to try to actually demonstrate this.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
In the case of waterborne transmission,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
we'd like to clean up the water supplies,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
see whether or not we can get those organisms to evolve towards mildness.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:13.958
In the case of malaria, what we'd like to do is mosquito-proof houses.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And the logic's a little more subtle here.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
If you mosquito-proof houses,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
when people get sick, they're sitting in bed --

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
or in mosquito-proof hospitals, they're sitting in a hospital bed --

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and the mosquitoes can't get to them.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
So, if you're a harmful variant

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
in a place where you've got mosquito-proof housing, then you're a loser.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
The only pathogens that get transmitted

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
are the ones that are infecting people that feel healthy enough

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
to walk outside and get mosquito bites.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
So, if you were to mosquito proof houses,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
you should be able to get these organisms to evolve to mildness.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
And there's a really wonderful experiment that was done

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
that suggests that we really should go ahead and do this.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
And that experiment was done in Northern Alabama.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Just to give you a little perspective on this,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
I've given you a star at the intellectual center of the United States,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
which is right there in Louisville, Kentucky.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
And this really cool experiment was done

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
about 200 miles south of there, in Northern Alabama,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:06.958
by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
They had dammed up the Tennessee River.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
They'd caused the water to back up,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
they needed electric, hydroelectric power.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And when you get stagnant water, you get mosquitoes.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
They found in the late '30s -- 10 years after they'd made these dams --

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:26.958
that the people in Northern Alabama were infected with malaria,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
about a third to half of them were infected with malaria.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
This shows you the positions of some of these dams.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
OK, so the Tennessee Valley Authority was in a little bit of a bind.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
There wasn't DDT, there wasn't chloroquines: what do they do?

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
Well, they decided to mosquito proof every house in Northern Alabama.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
So they did. They divided Northern Alabama into 11 zones,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and within three years, about 100 dollars per house,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
they mosquito proofed every house.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
And these are the data.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:56.958
Every row across here represents one of those 11 zones.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
And the asterisks represent the time at which

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
the mosquito proofing was complete.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
And so what you can see is that

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
just the mosquito-proofed housing, and nothing else,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
caused the eradication of malaria.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
And this was, incidentally, published in 1949,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
in the leading textbook of malaria, called "Boyd's Malariology."

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
But almost no malaria experts even know it exists.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
This is important,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
because it tells us that if you have moderate biting densities,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
you can eradicate malaria by mosquito proofing houses.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
Now, I would suggest that you could do this in a lot of places.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:28.958
Like, you know, just as you get into the malaria zone,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
sub-Saharan Africa.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
But as you move to really intense biting rate areas, like Nigeria,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
you're certainly not going to eradicate.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:39.958
But that's when you should be favoring evolution towards mildness.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
So to me, it's an experiment that's waiting to happen,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and if it confirms the prediction, then

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
we should have a very powerful tool.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
In a way, much more powerful than the kind of tools we're looking at,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
because most of what's being done today is

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
to rely on things like anti-malarial drugs.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
And we know that, although it's great to make those

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:01.958
anti-malarial drugs available at really low cost and high frequency,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
we know that when you make them highly available

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
you're going to get resistance to those drugs.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
And so it's a short-term solution.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
This is a long-term solution.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
What I'm suggesting here is that we could get evolution

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
working in the direction we want it to go,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
rather than always having to battle evolution as a problem

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
that stymies our efforts to control the pathogen,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
for example with anti-malarial drugs.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
So, this table I've given just to emphasize

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
that I've only talked about two examples.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
But as I said earlier, this kind of logic applies across the board

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
for infectious diseases, and it ought to.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
Because when we're dealing with infectious diseases, we're dealing with living systems.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
We're dealing with living systems;

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
we're dealing with systems that evolve.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And so if you do something with those systems,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
they're going to evolve one way or another.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
And all I'm saying is that we need to figure out how they'll evolve,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
so that -- we need to adjust our interventions

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
to get the most bang for the intervention buck,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
so that we can get these organisms to evolve in the direction we want them to go.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
So, I don't really have time to talk about those things,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
but I did want to put them up there,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
just to give you a sense that there really are solutions

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
to controlling the evolution of harmfulness

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
of some of the nasty pathogens that we're confronted with.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
And this links up with a lot of the other ideas that have been talked about.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:21.958
So, for example, earlier today there was discussion of,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:27.958
how do you really lower sexual transmission of HIV?

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
What this emphasizes is that we need to figure out how it will work.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
Will it maybe get lowered if we alter the economy of the area?

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
It may get lowered if we intervene in ways that

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
encourage people to stay more faithful to partners, and so on.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
But the key thing is to figure out how to lower it,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
because if we lower it, we'll get an evolutionary change in the virus.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
And the data really do support this:

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
that you actually do get the virus evolving towards mildness.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:54.958
And that will just add to the effectiveness of our control efforts.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
So the other thing I really like about this,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
besides the fact that it brings a whole new dimension

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
into the study of control of disease,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
is that often the kinds of interventions that you want,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
that it indicates should be done,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
are the kinds of interventions that people want anyhow.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
But people just haven't been able to justify the cost.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:15.958
So, this is the kind of thing I'm talking about.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
If we know that we're going to get extra bang for the buck from providing clean water,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
then I think that we can say,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
let's push the effort into that aspect of the control,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
so that we can actually solve the problem,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
even though, if you just look at the frequency of infection,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
you would suggest that you can't solve the problem well enough

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
just by cleaning up water supply.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
Anyhow, I'll end that there, and thank you very much.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
(Applause)

title: Juggling as art ... and science
transcript: I started juggling a long time ago, but long before that, I was a golfer, and that's what I was, a golfer. And as a golfer and as a kid, one of the things that really sort of seeped into my pores, that I sort of lived my whole life, is process. And it's the process of learning things. One of the great things was that my father was an avid golfer, but he was lefty. And he had a real passion for golf, and he also created this whole mythology about Ben Hogan and various things. Well, I learned a lot about interesting things that I knew nothing about at the time, but grew to know stuff about. And that was the mythology of skill.So, one of the things that I love to do is to explore skill. And since Richard put me on this whole thing with music — I'm supposed to actually be doing a project with Tod Machover with the MIT Media Lab — it relates a lot to music. But Tod couldn't come and the project is sort of somewhere, I'm not sure whether it's happening the way we thought, or not. But I'm going to explore skill, and juggling, and basically visual music, I guess. OK, you can start the music, thanks.(Music)(Applause)Thanks. Thank you. Now, juggling can be a lot of fun; play with skill and play with space, play with rhythm. And you can turn the mike on now. I'm going to do a couple of pieces. I do a big piece in a triangle and these are three sections from it. Part of the challenge was to try to understand rhythm and space using not just my hands — because a lot of juggling is hand-oriented — but using the rhythm of my body and feet, and controlling the balls with my feet.(Applause)Thanks. Now, this next section was an attempt to explore space. You see, I think Richard said something about people that are against something. Well, a lot of people think jugglers defy gravity or do stuff. Well, I kind of, from my childhood and golf and all that, it's a process of joining with forces. And so what I'd like to do is try to figure out how to join with the space through the technique. So juggling gravity — up, down. If you figure out what up and down really are, it's a complex physical set of skills to be able to throw a ball down and up and everything, but then you add in sideways.(Applause)Now, I look at it somewhat as a way — when you learn juggling what you learn is how to feel with your eyes, and see with your hands because you're not looking at your hands, you're looking at where the balls are or you're looking at the audience. So this next part is really a way of understanding space and rhythm, with the obvious reference to the feet, but it's also time — where the feet were, where the balls were.(Applause)Thanks. So, visual music: rhythm and complexity. I'm going to build towards complexity now. Juggling three balls is simple and normal.(Laughter)Excuse me.(Laughter)We're jugglers, OK. And remember, you're transposing, you're getting into a subculture here.(Laughter)And juggling — the balls cross and all that. OK, if you keep them in their assigned paths you get parallel lines of different heights, but then hopefully even rhythm. And you can change the rhythm — good, Michael. You can change the rhythm, if you get out of the lights. OK? Change the rhythm, so it's even. Or you can go back and change the height. Now, skill. But you're boxed in, if you can only do it up and down that way. So, you've got to go after the space down there. OK, then you've got to combine them, because then you have the whole spatial palette in front of you. And then you get crazy.(Applause)Now, I'm actually going to ask you to try something, so you've got to pay attention. Complexity: if you spend enough time doing something, time slows down or your skill increases, so your perceptions change. It's learning skills — like being in a high-speed car crash. Things slow down as you learn, as you learn, as you learn. You may not be able to affect it, it almost drifts on you. It goes. But that's the closest approximation I can have to it.So, complexity. Now, how many here are jugglers? OK, so most of you are going to have a similar reaction to this. OK? And whoever laughed there — you understood it completely, right?(Laughter)No, it looks like a mess. It looks like a mess with a guy there, who's got his hands around that mess, OK. Well, that's what juggling is about, right? It's being able to do something that other people can't do or can't understand. All right. So, that's one way of doing it, which is five balls down. OK? Another way is the outside. And you could play with the rhythm. Same pattern. Make it faster and smaller. Make it wider. Make it narrower. Bring it back up. OK. It's done. Thanks.(Applause)Now, what I wanted to get to is that you're all very bright, very tactile. I have no idea how computer-oriented or three-dimensionally-oriented you are, but let's try something. OK, so since you all don't understand what the five-ball pattern is, I'm going to give you a little clue. Enough of a clue? So, you get the pattern, right? OK.(Laughter)You're not getting off that easy. All right? Now, do me a favor: follow the ball that I ask you to follow. Green. Yellow. Pink. White. OK, you can do that? Yeah? OK.Now, let's actually learn something. Actually, let me put you in that area of learning, which is very insecure. You want to do it? Yeah? OK. Hands out in front of you. Palms up, together. What you're going to learn is this.(Laughter)OK? So what I want you to do is just listen to me and do it. Index finger, middle finger, ring, little. Little, ring, middle, index. And then open. Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. A little bit faster. Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger.(Laughter)All right. A lot of different learning processes going on in here.(Laughter)One learning process that I see is this —(Laughter)OK. Another learning process that I see is this —(Laughter)OK. So, everybody take a deep breath in, breath out. OK. Now, one more time, and — finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Open. Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. OK. Shake your hands out.Now, I assume a lot of you spend a lot of time at a computer. OK? So, what you're doing is, you're going la, la, la, and you're getting this. OK? So that's exactly what I'm going to ask you to do, but in a slightly different way. You're going to combine it. So what I want you to do is — fingers. I'll tell you what to do with your fingers, same thing. But I want you to do is also, with your eyes, is follow the colored ball that I ask you to follow.(Laughter)OK? Here we go. So, we're going to start off looking at the white ball — and I'm going to tell you which color, and I'm also going to tell you to go with your fingers. OK? So white ball and — finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Pink. Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Green. Finger, finger, finger, finger. Yellow. Finger, finger, finger, pink or finger. Pink, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. All right.(Applause)How did you do? Well? OK. The reason I wanted you to do this is because that's actually what most people face throughout their lives, a moment of learning, a moment of challenge. It's a moment that you can't make sense of. Why the hell should I learn this? OK? Does it really have anything to do with anything in my life? You know, I can't decipher — is it fun? Is it challenging? Am I supposed to cheat?(Laughter)You know, what are you supposed to do? You've got somebody up here who is the operative principle of doing that for his whole life. OK? Trying to figure that stuff out. But is it going to get you anywhere? It's just a moment. That's all it is, a moment. OK? I'm going to change the script for one second. Just let me do this. I don't need music for it. Talking about time in a moment. There's a piece that I recently developed which was all about that, a moment. And what I do as a creative artist is I develop vocabularies or languages of moving objects.What I've done for you here, I developed a lot of those tricks and I put the choreography together, but they're not original techniques. Now, I'm going to start showing you some original techniques that come from the work that I've developed. OK? So, a moment, how would you define a moment? Well, as a juggler, what I wanted to do was create something that was representational of a moment.Ahhh. All right, I'm going to get on my knees and do it. So, a moment.(Rattling)OK? And then, what I did as a juggler was say, OK, what can I do to make that something that is dependent on something else, another dynamic.(Rattling)So, a moment.(Rattling)Another moment.(Rattling)Excuse me, still getting there. A moment that travels.(Rattling)A moment — no, we'll try that again. It separates, and comes back together. Time. How can you look at time? And what do you dedicate it to, in exploring a particular thing? Well, obviously, there's something in here, and you can all have a guess as to what it is. There's a mystery. There's a mystery in the moment. And it has to settle. And then it's dependent on something else. And then it comes to rest. Just a little thing about time.Now, this has expanded into a much bigger piece, because I use ramps of different parabolas that I roll the balls on while I'm keeping time with this. But I just thought I'd talk about a moment.(Applause)All right. OK. Can we show the video of the triangle? Are we ready to do that? Yes? This is the piece that I told you about. It's a much bigger piece that I do exploring the space of a geometric triangle.(Applause)Thanks. The only thing I'll say about the last session is, you ever try juggling and driving the car with your knees at 120 miles an hour?(Laughter)The only other thing is, it was a real shock. I always drove motorcycles. And when I bought my first car, it shocked me that it cost three times more than my parents' house. Interesting.Anyway, balance: constant movement to find an approach to stillness. Cheating.(Laughter)Balance: making up the rules so you can't cheat, so you learn to approach stillness with different parts of your body. To have a conversation with it. To speak. To listen.(Laughter)Hup. Now, it's dependent on rhythm, and keeping a center of balance. When it falls, going underneath. So, there's a rhythm to it. The rhythm can get much smaller. As your skill increases, you learn to find those tinier spaces, those tinier movements. Thanks.(Applause)Now, I'm going to show you the beginnings of a piece that is about balance in some ways, and also — oh, actually, if you're bored, not here, here's one use for it.(Laughter)You can go with the "Sticks One" music.(Music)(Applause)Thanks. That has a certain kind of balance to it, which is all about plumb. I apprenticed with a carpenter and learned about plumb, square and level. And they influenced that, and this next piece, which I'll do a little segment of. "Two Sticks," you can go with it. Thanks. Which is again exploring space, or the lines in space.(Music)(Applause)Working with space and the lines in space in a different way. Oh, let's see here.(Applause)So, I'll come back to that in a second. But working with one ball, now, what if you attach something to it, or change it. This is a little thing that I made because I really like the idea of curves and balls together. And then creating space and the rhythm of space, using the surface of the balls, the surface of the arms. Just a little toy. Which leads me to the next thing, which is — what have I got here? OK. All right.I'm actually leading up to something, the newest thing that I'm working on. This is not it. This is exploring geometry and the rhythm of shape.(Applause)Now, what I just did was I worked with the mathematics — the diameter and the circumference. Sometimes these pieces are mathematical, in that way that I look at a shape and say, what about if I use this and this and this. Sometimes what happens in life affects my choice of objects that I try to work with.The next piece that I'm going to do — which is the cylinders piece, if you want to get that up — it has to do with cylinder seals from about 5,000 years ago, which were stones with designs that were used to roll over wet clay with all sorts of great designs. I love ceramics and all of that. It's a combination of that, the beauty of that, the shape, and the stories that were involved in it, as well as the fact that they protected the contents.The second influence on this piece came from recycling and looking into a tin can recycling bin and seeing all that beautiful emptiness. So, if you want to go with the music for cylinders.(Music)(Applause)Talking about geometry and everything, if you take the circle and you split it in half — can you run "S-Curve music?" I'm going to do just a short version of it. Circles split in half and rotated, and mythology.(Music)(Applause)Anyway, that piece also has a kinetic sculpture in the middle of it, and I dance around a small stage so — two minutes, just to end? The latest piece that I'm working on — what I love is that I never know what I'm working on, why I'm working on it. They're not ideas, they're instincts. And the latest thing that I'm working on —(Clattering) —is something really — I don't know what it is yet. And that's good. I like not to know for as long as possible. Well, because then it tells me the truth, instead of me imposing the truth. And what it is, is working with both positive and negative space but also with these curves. And what it involves, and I don't know if my hands are too beaten up to do it or not, but I'll do a little bit of it.It initially started off with me stacking these things, bunches of them, and then playing with the sense of space, of filling in the space. And then it started changing, and become folding on themselves. And then changing levels. Because my attempt is to make visual instruments, not to just make — I'll try one other thing. For work in three dimensions, with your perceptions of space and time. Now, I don't know exactly where it's going, but I've got a bit of effort involved in this thing. And it's going to change as I go through it. But I really like it, it feels right. This may not be the right shape, and — look at this shape, and then I'll show you the first design I ever put to it, just to see, just to play, because I love all different kinds of things to play with. Let's see here. To work with the positive and negative in a different way. And to change, and to change.So, I'm off in my new direction with this to explore rhythm and space. We'll see what I come up with. Thanks for having me.(Applause)
