00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
The first question is this.

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
Our country has two exploration programs.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:21.958
One is NASA, with a mission to explore the great beyond,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
to explore the heavens, which we all want to go to if we're lucky.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
And you can see we have Sputnik, and we have Saturn,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:31.958
and we have other manifestations of space exploration.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
Well, there's also another program,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
in another agency within our government, in ocean exploration.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
It's in NOAA, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:46.958
And my question is this: "why are we ignoring the oceans?"

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
Here's the reason, or not the reason, but here's why I ask that question.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:55.958
If you compare NASA's annual budget to explore the heavens,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
that one-year budget would fund NOAA's budget

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:04.958
to explore the oceans for 1,600 years.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:09.958
Why? Why are we looking up? Is it because it's heaven?

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And hell is down here? Is it a cultural issue?

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
Why are people afraid of the ocean?

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:20.958
Or do they just assume the ocean is just a dark, gloomy place

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
that has nothing to offer?

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:28.958
I'm going to take you on a 16-minute trip on 72 percent of the planet, so buckle up.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
OK. And what we're going to do

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
is we're going to immerse ourselves in my world.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
And what I'm going to try -- I hope I make the following points.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
I'm going to make it right now in case I forget.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
Everything I'm going to present to you

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
was not in my textbooks when I went to school.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
And most of all, it was not even in my college textbooks.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:52.958
I'm a geophysicist, and all my Earth science books when I was a student --

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
I had to give the wrong answer to get an A.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
We used to ridicule continental drift. It was something we laughed at.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
We learned of Marshall Kay's geosynclinal cycle, which is a bunch of crap.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
In today's context, it was a bunch of crap,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
but it was the law of geology, vertical tectonics.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
All the things we're going to walk through

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
in our explorations and discoveries of the oceans

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
were mostly discoveries made by accident.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Mostly discoveries made by accident.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
We were looking for something and found something else.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
And everything we're going to talk about

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:30.958
represents a one tenth of one percent glimpse, because that's all we've seen.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
I have a characterization.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
This is a characterization of what it would look like if you could remove the water.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
It gives you the false impression it's a map.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
It is not a map.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
In fact, I have another version at my office

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:48.958
and I ask people, "Why are there mountains here, on this area here,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
but there are none over here?" And they go, "Well, gee,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
I don't know," saying,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
"Is it a fracture zone? Is it a hot spot?"

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
No, no, that's the only place a ship's been.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
Most of the southern hemisphere is unexplored.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
We had more exploration ships down there

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
during Captain Cook's time than now. It's amazing.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
All right. So we're going to immerse ourselves

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
in the 72 percent of the planet because, you know,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
it's really naive to think that the Easter Bunny

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
put all the resources on the continents.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
(Laughter)

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
You know, it's just ludicrous.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:31.958
We are always, constantly playing the zero sum game.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
You know, we're going to do this, we're going to take it away from something else.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
I believe in just enriching the economy.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:40.958
And we're leaving so much on the table, 72 percent of the planet.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And as I will point out later in the presentation,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:48.958
50 percent of the United States of America lies beneath the sea.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
50 percent of our country that we own, have all legal jurisdiction,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
have all rights to do whatever we want, lies beneath the sea

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
and we have better maps of Mars than that 50 percent.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:06.958
Why? OK. Now, I began my explorations the hard way.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
Back then -- actually my first expedition

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
was when I was 17 years old. It was 49 years ago.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:15.958
Do the math, I'm 66. And I went out to sea on a Scripps ship

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
and we almost got sunk by a giant rogue wave,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
and I was too young to be -- you know, I thought it was great!

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
I was a body surfer and I thought, "Wow, that was an incredible wave!"

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:28.958
And we almost sank the ship, but I became enraptured

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
with mounting expeditions. And over the last 49 years,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.958
I've done about 120, 121 -- I keep doing them -- expeditions.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
But in the early days, the only way I could get to the bottom

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
was to crawl into a submarine, a very small submarine,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
and go down to the bottom.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
I dove in a whole series of different deep diving submersibles.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Alvin and Sea Cliff and Cyana,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and all the major deep submersibles we have, which are about eight.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:57.958
In fact, on a good day, we might have four or five human beings

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
at the average depth of the Earth --

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
maybe four or five human beings out of whatever billions we've got going.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
And so it's very difficult to get there, if you do it physically.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:11.958
But I was enraptured, and in my graduate years

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
was the dawn of plate tectonics. And we realized

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
that the greatest mountain range on Earth lies beneath the sea.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
The mid-ocean ridge runs around like the seam on a baseball.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
This is on a Mercator projection.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
But if you were to put it on an equal area projection,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
you'd see that the mid-ocean ridge covers 23 percent

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
of the Earth's total surface area.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
Almost a quarter of our planet is a single mountain range

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
and we didn't enter it until after Neil Armstrong

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and Buzz Aldrin went to the moon.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
So we went to the moon, played golf up there,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
before we went to the largest feature on our own planet.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
And our interest in this mountain range, as Earth scientists in those days,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
was not only because of its tremendous size, dominating the planet,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
but the role it plays in the genesis of the Earth's outer skin.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
Because it's along the axis of the mid-ocean ridge

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
where the great crustal plates are separating.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And like a living organism, you tear it open,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
it bleeds its molten blood, rises up to heal that wound

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:07.958
from the asthenosphere, hardens, forms new tissue and moves laterally.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
But no one had actually gone down

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
into the actual site of the boundary of creation as we call it --

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
into the Rift Valley -- until a group of seven of us

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:19.958
crawled in our little submarines in the summer of 1973, 1974

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
and were the first human beings to enter the Great Rift Valley.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
We went down into the Rift Valley.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
This is all accurate except for one thing -- it's pitch black.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
It's absolutely pitch black, because

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
photons cannot reach the average depth of the ocean,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
which is 12,000 feet. In the Rift Valley, it's 9,000 feet.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:39.958
Most of our planet does not feel the warmth of the sun.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Most of our planet is in eternal darkness.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And for that reason, you do not have photosynthesis in the deep sea.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And with the absence of photosynthesis

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
you have no plant life, and as a result,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
you have very little animal life living in this underworld.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Or so we thought. And so in our initial explorations,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
we were totally focused on exploring the boundary of creation,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:05.958
looking at the volcanic features running along that entire 42,000 miles.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
Running along this entire 42,000 miles

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
are tens of thousands of active volcanoes.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Tens of thousands of active volcanoes.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
There are more active volcanoes beneath the sea

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
than on land by two orders of magnitude.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So, it's a phenomenally active region,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:24.958
it's not just a dark, boring place. It's a very alive place.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
And it's then being ripped open.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
But we were dealing with a particular scientific issue back then.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
We couldn't understand why you had a mountain under tension.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
In plate tectonic theory, we knew that if you had plates collide,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
it made sense: they would crush into one another,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
you would thicken the crust, you'd uplift it.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
That's why you get, you know, you get seashells up on Mount Everest.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
It's not a flood, it was pushed up there.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
We understood mountains under compression,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
but we could not understand why we had a mountain under tension.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
It should not be. Until one of my colleagues said,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
"It looks to me like a thermal blister, and the mid-ocean ridge

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
must be a cooling curve." We said, "Let's go find out."

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
We punched a bunch of heat probes. Everything made sense,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
except, at the axis, there was missing heat. It was missing heat.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
It was hot. It wasn't hot enough.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
So, we came up with multiple hypotheses:

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
there's little green people down there taking it;

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
there's all sorts of things going on.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
But the only logical [explanation] was that there were hot springs.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So, there must be underwater hot springs.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
We mounted an expedition to look for the missing heat.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And so we went along this mountain range, in an area along Galapagos Rift,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
and did we find the missing heat.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
It was amazing. These giant chimneys, huge giant chimneys.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
We went up to them with our submersible.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
We wanted to get a temperature probe, we stuck it in there,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
looked at it -- it pegged off scale.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
The pilot made this great observation: "That's hot."

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
(Laughter)

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
And then we realized our probe was made out of the same stuff --

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
it could have melted. But it turns out the exiting temperature

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
was 650 degrees F, hot enough to melt lead.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
This is what a real one looks like, on the Juan de Fuca Ridge.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
What you're looking at is an incredible pipe organ

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
of chemicals coming out of the ocean.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Everything you see in this picture is commercial grade:

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
copper, lead, silver, zinc and gold.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
So the Easter Bunny has put things in the ocean floor,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
and you have massive heavy metal deposits

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
that we're making in this mountain range.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
We're making huge discoveries of large commercial-grade ore

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
along this mountain range, but it was dwarfed by what we discovered.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
We discovered a profusion of life,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:20.958
in a world that it should not exist [in]. Giant tube worms, 10 feet tall.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
I remember having to use vodka -- my own vodka -- to pickle it

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
because we don't carry formaldehyde.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
We went and found these incredible clam beds

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
sitting on the barren rock. Large clams,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
and when we opened them, they didn't look like a clam.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And when we cut them open, they didn't have the anatomy of a clam.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
No mouth, no gut, no digestive system.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
Their bodies had been totally taken over

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
by another organism, a bacterium, that had figured out

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
how to replicate photosynthesis in the dark,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
through a process we now call chemosynthesis.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
None of it in our textbooks. None of this in our textbooks.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
We did not know about this life system.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
We were not predicting it.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
We stumbled on it, looking for some missing heat.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
So, we wanted to accelerate this process.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
We wanted to get away from this silly trip, up and down on a submarine:

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
average depth of the ocean, 12,000 feet;

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
two and half hours to get to work in the morning;

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
two and half hours to get to home. Five hour commute to work.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Three hours of bottom time, average distance traveled -- one mile.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
(Laughter)

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:21.958
On a 42,000 mile mountain range. Great job security, but not the way to go.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
So, I began designing a new technology of telepresence,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
using robotic systems to replicate myself,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
so I wouldn't have to cycle my vehicle system.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
We began to introduce that in our explorations,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
and we continued to make phenomenal discoveries

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
with our new robotic technologies. Again, looking for something else,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
moving from one part of the mid-ocean ridge to another.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:45.958
The scientists were off watch and they came across incredible life forms.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
They came across new creatures they had not seen before.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
But more importantly, they discovered

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
edifices down there that they did not understand.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
That did not make sense. They were not above a magma chamber.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
They shouldn't be there. And we called it Lost City.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And Lost City was characterized by these incredible limestone formations

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and upside down pools. Look at that.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
How do you do that? That's water upside down.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:14.958
We went in underneath and tapped it, and we found that it had the pH of Drano.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
The pH of 11, and yet it had chemosynthetic bacteria living in it

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
and at this extreme environment.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
And the hydrothermal vents were in an acidic environment.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
All the way at the other end, in an alkaline environment,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
at a pH of 11, life existed.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
So life was much more creative than we had ever thought.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
Again, discovered by accident. Just two years ago

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:38.958
working off Santorini, where people are sunning themselves on the beach,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
unbeknownst to them in the caldera nearby,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
we found phenomenal hydrothermal vent systems

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and more life systems.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
This was two miles from where people go to sunbathe,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and they were oblivious to the existence of this system.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
Again, you know, we stop at the water's edge.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Recently, diving off -- in the Gulf of Mexico, finding pools of water,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
this time not upside down, right side up.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:09.958
Bingo. You'd think you're in air, until a fish swims by.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
You're looking at brine pools formed by salt diapirs.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:18.958
Near that was methane. I've never seen volcanoes of methane.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Instead of belching out lava, they were belching out

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
big, big bubbles of methane. And they were creating these volcanoes,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
and there were flows, not of lava,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
but of the mud coming out of the Earth but driven by --

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
I've never seen this before.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Moving on, there's more than just natural history beneath the sea --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
human history. Our discoveries of the Titanic.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
The realization that the deep sea is the largest museum on Earth.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
It contains more history than all of the museums on land combined.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
And yet we're only now penetrating it.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Finding the state of preservation.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
We found the Bismarck in 16,000 feet. We then found the Yorktown.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
People always ask, "Did you find the right ship?"

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
It said Yorktown on the stern.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
(Laughter)

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
More recently, finding ancient history.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
How many ancient mariners have had a bad day? The number's a million.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
We've been discovering these along ancient trade routes,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
where they're not supposed to be.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
This shipwreck sank 100 years before the birth of Christ.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:21.958
This one sank carrying a prefabricated, Home Depot Roman temple.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And then here's one that sank at the time of Homer, at 750 B.C.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
More recently, into the Black Sea, where we're exploring.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
Because there's no oxygen there, it's the largest reservoir

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
of hydrogen sulfide on Earth. Shipwrecks are perfectly preserved.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
All their organics are perfectly preserved. We begin to excavate them.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
We expect to start hauling out the bodies in perfect condition with their DNA.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Look at the state of preservation --

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:50.958
still the ad mark of a carpenter. Look at the state of those artifacts.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
You still see the beeswax dripping. When they dropped, they sealed it.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
This ship sank 1,500 years ago.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Fortunately, we've been able to convince Congress.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
We begin to go on the Hill and lobby.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
And we stole recently a ship from the United States Navy.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
The Okeanos Explorer on its mission.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Its mission is as good as you could get.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Its mission is to go where no one has gone before on planet Earth.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:19.958
And I was looking at it yesterday, it's up in Seattle. OK.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:20.958
(Applause)

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It comes online this summer,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
and it begins its journey of exploration.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.958
But we have no idea what we're going find when we go out there with our technology.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
But certainly, it's going to be going to the unknown America.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
This is that part of the United States that lies beneath the sea.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
We own all of that blue and yet,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
like I say, particularly the western territorial trust,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
we don't have maps of them. We don't have maps of them.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
We have maps of Venus, but not of the western territorial trust.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
The way we're going to run this -- we have no idea what we're going to discover.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
We have no idea what we're going to discover.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
We're going to discover an ancient shipwreck, a Phoenician off Brazil,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
or a new rock formation, a new life.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
So, we're going to run it like an emergency hospital.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
We're going to connect our command center,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
via a high-bandwidth satellite link to a building we're building

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
at the University of Rhode Island, called the Interspace Center.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
And within that, we're going to run it just like you run a nuclear submarine,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
blue-gold team, switching them off and on, running 24 hours a day.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
A discovery is made, that discovery is instantly seen

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
in the command center a second later.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
But then it's connected through Internet too --

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
the new Internet highway that makes Internet one

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
look like a dirt road on the information highway --

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
with 10 gigabits of bandwidth.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
We'll go into areas we have no knowledge of.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
It's a big blank sheet on our planet. We'll map it within hours,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
have the maps disseminated out to the major universities.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
It turns out that 90 percent of all the oceanographic intellect

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
in this country are at 12 universities. They're all on I-2.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
We can then build a command center.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
This is a remote center at the University of Washington.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:57.958
She's talking to the pilot. She's 5,000 miles away, but she's assumed command.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
But the beauty of this, too, is we can then disseminate it to children.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
We can disseminate.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
They can follow this expedition. I've started a program --

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
where are you Jim? Jim Young who helped me start a program

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
called the Jason Project. More recently, we've started a program

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
with the Boys and Girls Clubs of America,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
so that we can use exploration,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
and the excitement of live exploration, to motivate them and excite them

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and then give them what they're already ready for.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
I would not let an adult drive my robot.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
You don't have enough gaming experience.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:31.958
But I will let a kid with no license take over control of my vehicle system.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
(Applause)

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
Because we want to create --

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
we want to create the classroom of tomorrow.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:42.958
We have stiff competition and we need to motivate and it's all being done.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:47.958
You win or lose an engineer or a scientist by eighth grade.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
The game is not over -- it's over by the eighth grade, it's not beginning.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
We need to be not only proud of our universities.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
We need to be proud of our middle schools.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
And when we have the best middle schools in the world,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
we'll have the best kids pumped out of that system, let me tell you.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:05.958
Because this is what we want. This is what we want.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
This is a young lady, not watching a football game,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
not watching a basketball game.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
Watching exploration live from thousands of miles away,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
and it's just dawning on her what she's seeing.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
And when you get a jaw drop, you can inform.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:23.958
You can put so much information into that mind, it's in full [receiving] mode.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
(Applause)

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:30.958
This, I hope, will be a future engineer

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
or a future scientist in the battle for truth.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
And my final question, my final question --

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:40.958
why are we not looking at moving out onto the sea?

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
Why do we have programs to build habitation on Mars,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
and we have programs to look at colonizing the moon,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:52.958
but we do not have a program looking at how we colonize our own planet?

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
And the technology is at hand.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:18:01.958
(Applause)

title: Designing objects that tell stories
transcript: Being a child, and sort of crawling around the house, I remember these Turkish carpets, and there were these scenes, these battle scenes, these love scenes. I mean, look, this animal is trying to fight back this spear from this soldier. And my mom took these pictures actually, last week, of our carpets, and I remember this to this day. There was another object, this sort of towering piece of furniture with creatures and gargoyles and nudity — pretty scary stuff, when you're a little kid.What I remember today from this is that objects tell stories, so storytelling has been a really strong influence in my work. And then there was another influence. I was a teenager, and at 15 or 16, I guess like all teenagers, we want to just do what we love and what we believe in. And so, I fused together the two things I loved the most, which was skiing and windsurfing. Those are pretty good escapes from the drab weather in Switzerland.So, I created this compilation of the two: I took my skis and I took a board and I put a mast foot in there, and some foot straps, and some metal fins, and here I was, going really fast on frozen lakes. It was really a death trap. I mean, it was incredible, it worked incredibly well, but it was really dangerous. And I realized then I had to go to design school. (Laughter) I mean, look at those graphics there. (Laughter)So, I went to design school, and it was the early '90s when I finished. And I saw something extraordinary happening in Silicon Valley, so I wanted to be there, and I saw that the computer was coming into our homes, that it had to change in order to be with us in our homes. And so I got myself a job and I was working for a consultancy, and we would get in to these meetings, and these managers would come in, and they would say, "Well, what we're going to do here is really important, you know." And they would give the projects code names, you know, mostly from "Star Wars," actually: things like C3PO, Yoda, Luke. So, in anticipation, I would be this young designer in the back of the room, and I would raise my hand, and I would ask questions. I mean, in retrospect, probably stupid questions, but things like, "What's this Caps Lock key for?" or "What's this Num Lock key for?" You know, that thing? "You know, do people really use it? Do they need it? Do they want it in their homes?" (Laughter)What I realized then is, they didn't really want to change the legacy stuff; they didn't want to change the insides. They were really looking for us, the designers, to create the skins, to put some pretty stuff outside of the box. And I didn't want to be a colorist. It wasn't what I wanted to do. I didn't want to be a stylist in this way. And then I saw this quote: "advertising is the price companies pay for being unoriginal." (Laughter)So, I had to start on my own. So I moved to San Francisco, and I started a little company, fuseproject. And what I wanted to work on is important stuff. And I wanted to really not just work on the skins, but I wanted to work on the entire human experience. And so the first projects were sort of humble, but they took technology and maybe made it into things that people would use in a new way, and maybe finding some new functionality.This is a watch we made for Mini Cooper, the car company, right when it launched, and it's the first watch that has a display that switches from horizontal to vertical. And that allows me to check my timer discretely, here, without bending my elbow. And other projects, which were really about transformation, about matching the human need. This is a little piece of furniture for an Italian manufacturer, and it ships completely flat, and then it folds into a coffee table and a stool and whatnot. And something a little bit more experimental: this is a light fixture for Swarovski, and what it does is, it changes shape. So, it goes from a circle, to a round, to a square, to a figure eight. And just by drawing on a little computer tablet, the entire light fixture adjusts to what shape you want.And then finally, the leaf lamp for Herman Miller. This is a pretty involved process; it took us about four and a half years. But I really was looking for creating a unique experience of light, a new experience of light. So, we had to design both the light and the light bulb. And that's a unique opportunity, I would say, in design. And the new experience I was looking for is giving the choice for the user to go from a warm, sort of glowing kind of mood light, all the way to a bright work light. So, the light bulb actually does that. It allows the person to switch, and to mix these two colorations. And it's done in a very simple way: one just touches the base of the light, and on one side, you can mix the brightness, and on the other, the coloration of the light.So, all of these projects have a humanistic sense to them, and I think as designers we need to really think about how we can create a different relationship between our work and the world, whether it's for business, or, as I'm going to show, on some civic-type projects. Because I think everybody agrees that as designers we bring value to business, value to the users also, but I think it's the values that we put into these projects that ultimately create the greater value. And the values we bring can be about environmental issues, about sustainability, about lower power consumption. You know, they can be about function and beauty; they can be about business strategy. But designers are really the glue that brings these things together.So Jawbone is a project that you're familiar with, and it has a humanistic technology. It feels your skin. It rests on your skin, and it knows when it is you're talking. And by knowing when it is you're talking, it gets rid of the other noises that it knows about, which is the environmental noises.But the other thing that is humanistic about Jawbone is that we really decided to take out all the techie stuff, and all the nerdy stuff out of it, and try to make it as beautiful as we can. I mean, think about it: the care we take in selecting sunglasses, or jewelry, or accessories is really important, so if it isn't beautiful, it really doesn't belong on your face. And this is what we're pursuing here.But how we work on Jawbone is really unique. I want to point at something here, on the left. This is the board, this is one of the things that goes inside that makes this technology work. But this is the design process: there's somebody changing the board, putting tracers on the board, changing the location of the ICs, as the designers on the other side are doing the work. So, it's not about slapping skins, anymore, on a technology. It's really about designing from the inside out. And then, on the other side of the room, the designers are making small adjustments, sketching, drawing by hand, putting it in the computer. And it's what I call being design driven. You know, there is some push and pull, but design is really helping define the whole experience from the inside out.And then, of course, design is never done. And this is — the other new way that is unique in how we work is, because it's never done, you have to do all this other stuff. The packaging, and the website, and you need to continue to really touch the user, in many ways. But how do you retain somebody, when it's never done? And Hosain Rahman, the CEO of Aliph Jawbone, you know, really understands that you need a different structure. So, in a way, the different structure is that we're partners, it's a partnership. We can continue to work and dedicate ourselves to this project, and then we also share in the rewards.And here's another project, another partnership-type approach. This is called Y Water, and it's this guy from Los Angeles, Thomas Arndt, Austrian originally, who came to us, and all he wanted to do was to create a healthy drink, or an organic drink for his kids, to replace the high-sugar-content sodas that he's trying to get them away from. So, we worked on this bottle, and it's completely symmetrical in every dimension. And this allows the bottle to turn into a game. The bottles connect together, and you can create different shapes, different forms. (Laughter) (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)And then while we were doing this, the shape of the bottle upside down reminded us of a Y, and then we thought, well these words, "why" and "why not," are probably the most important words that kids ask. So we called it Y Water. And so this is another place where it all comes together in the same room: the three-dimensional design, the ideas, the branding, it all becomes deeply connected. And then the other thing about this project is, we bring intellectual property, we bring a marketing approach, we bring all this stuff, but I think, at the end of the day, what we bring is these values, and these values create a soul for the companies we work with. And it's especially rewarding when your design work becomes a creative endeavor, when others can be creative and do more with it.Here's another project, which I think really emulates that. This is the One Laptop per Child, the $100 laptop. This picture is incredible. In Nigeria, people carry their most precious belongings on their heads. This girl is going to school with a laptop on her head. I mean, to me, it just means so much. But when Nicholas Negroponte — and he has spoken about this project a lot, he's the founder of OLPC — came to us about two and a half years ago, there were some clear ideas. He wanted to bring education and he wanted to bring technology, and those are pillars of his life, but also pillars of the mission of One Laptop per Child. But the third pillar that he talked about was design. And at the time, I wasn't really working on computers. I didn't really want to, from the previous adventure. But what he said was really significant, is that design was going to be why the kids were going to love this product, how we were going to make it low cost, robust. And plus, he said he was going to get rid of the Caps Lock key — (Laughter) — and the Num Lock key, too.So, I was convinced. We designed it to be iconic, to look different. To look like it's for a kid, but not like a toy. And then the integration of all these great technologies, which you've heard about, the Wi-Fi antennas that allow the kids to connect; the screen, which you can read in sunlight; the keyboard, which is made out of rubber, and it's protected from the environment.You know, all these great technologies really happened because of the passion and the OLPC people and the engineers. They fought the suppliers, they fought the manufacturers. I mean, they fought like animals for this to remain they way it is. And in a way, it is that will that makes projects like this one — allows the process from not destroying the original idea. And I think this is something really important.So, now you get these pictures — you get up in the morning, and you see the kids in Nigeria and you see them in Uruguay with their computers, and in Mongolia. And we went away from obviously the beige. I mean it's colorful, it's fun. In fact, you can see each logo is a little bit different. It's because we were able to run, during the manufacturing process, 20 colors for the X and the O, which is the name of the computer, and by mixing them on the manufacturing floor, you get 20 times 20: you get 400 different options there. So, the lessons from seeing the kids using them in the developing world are incredible.But this is my nephew, Anthony, in Switzerland, and he had the laptop for an afternoon, and I had to take it back. It was hard. (Laughter) And it was a prototype. And a month and a half later, I come back to Switzerland, and there he is playing with his own version. (Laughter) Like paper, paper and cardboard.So, I'm going to finish with one last project, and this is a little bit more of adult play. (Laughter) Some of you might have heard about the New York City condom. It's actually just launched, actually launched on Valentine's Day, February 14, about 10 days ago. So, the Department of Health in New York came to us, and they needed a way to distribute 36 million condoms for free to the citizens of New York. So a pretty big endeavor, and we worked on the dispensers. These are the dispensers. There's this friendly shape. It's a little bit like designing a fire hydrant, and it has to be easily serviceable: you have to know where it is and what it does. And we also designed the condoms themselves.And I was just in New York at the launch, and I went to see all these places where they're installed: this is at a Puerto Rican little mom-and-pop store; at a bar in Christopher Street; at a pool hall. I mean, they're being installed in homeless clinics — everywhere. Of course, clubs and discos, too. And here's the public service announcement for this project. (Music) (Laughter) Get some. (Applause)So, this is really where design is able to create a conversation. I was in these venues, and people were, you know, really into getting them. They were excited. It was breaking the ice, it was getting over a stigma, and I think that's also what design can do. So, I was going to throw some condoms in the room and whatnot, but I'm not sure it's the etiquette here. (Laughter) Yeah? All right, all right. I have only a few. (Laughter) (Applause) So, I have more, you can always ask me for some more later. (Laughter) And if anybody asks why you're carrying a condom, you can just say you like the design. (Laughter)So, I'll finish with just one thought: if we all work together on creating value, but if we really keep in mind the values of the work that we do, I think we can change the work that we do. We can change these values, can change the companies we work with, and eventually, together, maybe we can change the world. So, thank you. (Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
Being a child, and sort of crawling around the house,

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:15.958
I remember these Turkish carpets,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:20.958
and there were these scenes, these battle scenes, these love scenes.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:25.958
I mean, look, this animal is trying to fight back this spear

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:26.958
from this soldier.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
And my mom took these pictures actually, last week,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
of our carpets, and I remember this to this day.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:36.958
There was another object, this sort of towering piece of furniture

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
with creatures and gargoyles and nudity --

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
pretty scary stuff, when you're a little kid.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
What I remember today from this is that objects tell stories,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:53.958
so storytelling has been a really strong influence in my work.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:54.958
And then there was another influence.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
I was a teenager, and at 15 or 16, I guess like all teenagers,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:00.958
we want to just do what we love and what we believe in.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
And so,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
I fused together the two things I loved the most,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
which was skiing and windsurfing.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:13.958
Those are pretty good escapes from the drab weather in Switzerland.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
So, I created this compilation of the two:

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
I took my skis and I took a board and I put a mast foot in there,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
and some foot straps, and some metal fins,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
and here I was, going really fast on frozen lakes.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
It was really a death trap. I mean, it was incredible,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
it worked incredibly well, but it was really dangerous.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:37.958
And I realized then I had to go to design school.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:38.958
(Laughter)

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
I mean, look at those graphics there.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
(Laughter)

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
So, I went to design school,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:52.958
and it was the early '90s when I finished.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:56.958
And I saw something extraordinary happening in Silicon Valley,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:57.958
so I wanted to be there,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:01.958
and I saw that the computer was coming into our homes,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
that it had to change in order to be with us in our homes.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
And so I got myself a job and I was working for a consultancy,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:10.958
and we would get in to these meetings,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
and these managers would come in,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and they would say,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
"Well, what we're going to do here is really important, you know."

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
And they would give the projects code names, you know,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:28.958
mostly from "Star Wars," actually: things like C3PO, Yoda, Luke.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So, in anticipation, I would be this young designer

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
in the back of the room, and I would raise my hand,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
and I would ask questions.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
I mean, in retrospect, probably stupid questions,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
but things like, "What's this Caps Lock key for?"

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
or "What's this Num Lock key for?" You know, that thing?

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:49.958
"You know, do people really use it?

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
Do they need it? Do they want it in their homes?"

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
(Laughter)

00:02:55.958 --> 00:03:00.958
What I realized then is, they didn't really want to change

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
the legacy stuff; they didn't want to change the insides.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:08.958
They were really looking for us, the designers, to create the skins,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
to put some pretty stuff outside of the box.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And I didn't want to be a colorist.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
It wasn't what I wanted to do.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
I didn't want to be a stylist in this way.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And then I saw this quote:

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:30.958
"advertising is the price companies pay for being unoriginal."

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
(Laughter)

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
So, I had to start on my own. So I moved to San Francisco,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
and I started a little company, fuseproject.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And what I wanted to work on is important stuff.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
And I wanted to really not just work on the skins,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
but I wanted to work on the entire human experience.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And so the first projects were sort of humble,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:59.958
but they took technology and maybe made it into things

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
that people would use in a new way,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:03.958
and maybe finding some new functionality.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
This is a watch we made for Mini Cooper, the car company,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:08.958
right when it launched,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
and it's the first watch that has a display

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
that switches from horizontal to vertical.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And that allows me to check my timer discretely, here,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:19.958
without bending my elbow.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
And other projects, which were really about transformation,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
about matching the human need.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
This is a little piece of furniture for an Italian manufacturer,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
and it ships completely flat,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and then it folds into a coffee table and a stool and whatnot.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:37.958
And something a little bit more experimental:

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
this is a light fixture for Swarovski,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
and what it does is, it changes shape.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:47.958
So, it goes from a circle, to a round, to a square, to a figure eight.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
And just by drawing on a little computer tablet,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:54.958
the entire light fixture adjusts to what shape you want.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
And then finally, the leaf lamp for Herman Miller.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
This is a pretty involved process;

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
it took us about four and a half years.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:05.958
But I really was looking for creating a unique experience of light,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:07.958
a new experience of light.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:12.958
So, we had to design both the light and the light bulb.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
And that's a unique opportunity, I would say, in design.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
And the new experience I was looking for

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
is giving the choice for the user to go from

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
a warm, sort of glowing kind of mood light,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
all the way to a bright work light.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
So, the light bulb actually does that.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
It allows the person to switch,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
and to mix these two colorations.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And it's done in a very simple way:

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
one just touches the base of the light,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and on one side, you can mix the brightness,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
and on the other, the coloration of the light.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:50.958
So, all of these projects have a humanistic sense to them,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and I think as designers we need to really think

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
about how we can create a different relationship

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
between our work and the world,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:00.958
whether it's for business,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:05.958
or, as I'm going to show, on some civic-type projects.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:10.958
Because I think everybody agrees that as designers we bring

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:15.958
value to business, value to the users also,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
but I think it's the values that we put into these projects

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
that ultimately create the greater value.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:24.958
And the values we bring

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
can be about environmental issues,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
about sustainability, about lower power consumption.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
You know, they can be about function and beauty;

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
they can be about business strategy.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
But designers are really the glue

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
that brings these things together.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:46.958
So Jawbone is a project that you're familiar with,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and it has a humanistic technology.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
It feels your skin. It rests on your skin,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:54.958
and it knows when it is you're talking.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
And by knowing when it is you're talking,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
it gets rid of the other noises that it knows about,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
which is the environmental noises.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
But the other thing that is humanistic about Jawbone

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:09.958
is that we really decided to take out all the techie stuff,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and all the nerdy stuff out of it,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and try to make it as beautiful as we can.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:15.958
I mean, think about it:

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:20.958
the care we take in selecting sunglasses, or jewelry,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:26.958
or accessories is really important,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
so if it isn't beautiful, it really doesn't belong on your face.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And this is what we're pursuing here.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
But how we work on Jawbone is really unique.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
I want to point at something here, on the left.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.958
This is the board, this is one of the things that goes inside

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
that makes this technology work.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
But this is the design process:

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:48.958
there's somebody changing the board,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:52.958
putting tracers on the board, changing the location of the ICs,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
as the designers on the other side are doing the work.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.958
So, it's not about slapping skins, anymore, on a technology.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
It's really about designing from the inside out.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
And then, on the other side of the room,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:05.958
the designers are making small adjustments,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.958
sketching, drawing by hand, putting it in the computer.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:14.958
And it's what I call being design driven.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:15.958
You know, there is some push and pull,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
but design is really helping define

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
the whole experience from the inside out.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And then, of course, design is never done.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And this is -- the other new way that is unique

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
in how we work is, because it's never done,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
you have to do all this other stuff.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
The packaging, and the website, and you need to continue

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
to really touch the user, in many ways.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
But how do you retain somebody, when it's never done?

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:49.958
And Hosain Rahman, the CEO of Aliph Jawbone,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
you know, really understands that you need a different structure.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So, in a way, the different structure is that we're partners,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:02.958
it's a partnership. We can continue to work

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
and dedicate ourselves to this project,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
and then we also share in the rewards.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And here's another project, another partnership-type approach.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
This is called Y Water,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and it's this guy from Los Angeles, Thomas Arndt,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Austrian originally, who came to us,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
and all he wanted to do was to create a healthy drink,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
or an organic drink for his kids,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
to replace the high-sugar-content sodas

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
that he's trying to get them away from.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
So, we worked on this bottle,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and it's completely symmetrical in every dimension.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And this allows the bottle to turn into a game.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:46.958
The bottles connect together,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and you can create different shapes, different forms.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:51.958
(Laughter)

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
(Applause)

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:54.958
Thank you.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:55.958
(Applause)

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And then while we were doing this,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:01.958
the shape of the bottle upside down reminded us of a Y,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and then we thought, well these words, "why" and "why not,"

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
are probably the most important words that kids ask.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
So we called it Y Water. And so this is

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
another place where it all comes together in the same room:

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:21.958
the three-dimensional design, the ideas, the branding,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
it all becomes deeply connected.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
And then the other thing about this project is,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
we bring intellectual property,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
we bring a marketing approach,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
we bring all this stuff, but I think, at the end of the day,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
what we bring is these values,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
and these values create a soul for the companies we work with.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And it's especially rewarding when your design work

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
becomes a creative endeavor,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
when others can be creative and do more with it.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Here's another project,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
which I think really emulates that.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:55.958
This is the One Laptop per Child, the $100 laptop.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:58.958
This picture is incredible.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:03.958
In Nigeria, people carry their most precious belongings on their heads.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
This girl is going to school with a laptop on her head.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
I mean, to me, it just means so much.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
But when Nicholas Negroponte --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and he has spoken about this project a lot,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:19.958
he's the founder of OLPC -- came to us

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
about two and a half years ago,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
there were some clear ideas.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
He wanted to bring education and he wanted to bring technology,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:30.958
and those are pillars of his life,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
but also pillars of the mission of One Laptop per Child.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
But the third pillar that he talked about was design.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And at the time, I wasn't really working on computers.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
I didn't really want to, from the previous adventure.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
But what he said was really significant,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
is that design was going to be why the kids

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
were going to love this product,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
how we were going to make it low cost, robust.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And plus, he said he was going to get rid of the Caps Lock key --

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
(Laughter) --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:05.958
and the Num Lock key, too.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
So, I was convinced. We designed it to be iconic,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:15.958
to look different. To look like it's for a kid, but not like a toy.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
And then the integration of

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
all these great technologies, which you've heard about,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
the Wi-Fi antennas that allow the kids to connect;

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
the screen, which you can read in sunlight;

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
the keyboard, which is made out of rubber,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
and it's protected from the environment.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
You know, all these great technologies really happened

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
because of the passion and

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
the OLPC people and the engineers.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
They fought the suppliers,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
they fought the manufacturers.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
I mean, they fought like animals

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
for this to remain they way it is.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And in a way, it is that will that makes projects like this one --

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:02.958
allows the process

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
from not destroying the original idea.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
And I think this is something really important.

you get up in the morning, and you see the kids in Nigeria

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:14.958
and you see them in Uruguay

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:19.958
with their computers, and in Mongolia.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
And we went away from obviously the beige.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:23.958
I mean it's colorful, it's fun.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:27.958

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
It's because we were able

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.958
to run, during the manufacturing process,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:37.958
20 colors for the X and the O,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
which is the name of the computer,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
and by mixing them on the manufacturing floor,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
you get 20 times 20: you get

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
400 different options there.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
So, the lessons from seeing the kids

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
using them in the developing world are incredible.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
But this is my nephew, Anthony, in Switzerland,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and he had the laptop for an afternoon,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and I had to take it back. It was hard.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:03.958
(Laughter)

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:08.958
I come back to Switzerland,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
and there he is playing with his own version.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:15.958
(Laughter)

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:25.958
So, I'm going to finish with one last project,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
and this is a little bit more of adult play.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:29.958
(Laughter)

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
Some of you might have heard about the New York City condom.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
It's actually just launched, actually launched on Valentine's Day,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
February 14, about 10 days ago.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:45.958
So, the Department of Health in New York came to us,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:50.958
and they needed a way to distribute

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:55.958
36 million condoms for free to the citizens of New York.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:15:00.958
So a pretty big endeavor, and we worked on the dispensers.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
These are the dispensers. There's this friendly shape.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.958
It's a little bit like designing a fire hydrant,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
and it has to be easily serviceable:

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
you have to know where it is and what it does.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And we also designed the condoms themselves.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
And I was just in New York at the launch,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and I went to see all these places where they're installed:

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
this is at a Puerto Rican little mom-and-pop store;

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
at a bar in Christopher Street; at a pool hall.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:58.958
(Music)

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:00.958
(Laughter)

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
Get some.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:08.958
(Applause)

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:13.958
is able to create a conversation.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
I was in these venues, and people were,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
you know, really into getting them. They were excited.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
It was breaking the ice,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
it was getting over a stigma,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
and I think that's also what design can do.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:31.958
So, I was going to

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.958
throw some condoms in the room and whatnot,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
but I'm not sure it's the etiquette here.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:40.958
(Laughter)

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
Yeah? All right, all right. I have only a few.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
(Laughter)

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
(Applause)

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:54.958
So, I have more, you can always ask me for some more later.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:56.958
(Laughter)

00:16:56.958 --> 00:17:00.958

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:01.958
you can just say you like the design.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
(Laughter)

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
So, I'll finish with just one thought:

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958

title: Moving sculpture
transcript: A few words about how I got started, and it has a lot to do with happiness, actually. When I was a very young child, I was extremely introverted and very much to myself. And, kind of as a way of surviving, I would go into my own very personal space, and I would make things. I would make things for people as a way of, you know, giving, showing them my love. I would go into these private places, and I would put my ideas and my passions into objects — and sort of learning how to speak with my hands. So, the whole activity of working with my hands and creating objects is very much connected with not only the idea realm, but also with very much the feeling realm. And the ideas are very disparate.I'm going to show you many different kinds of pieces, and there's no real connection between one or the other, except that they sort of come out of my brain, and they're all different sort of thoughts that are triggered by looking at life, and seeing nature and seeing objects, and just having kind of playful random thoughts about things.When I was a child, I started to explore motion. I fell in love with the way things moved, so I started to explore motion by making little flipbooks. And this is one that I did, probably like when I was around seventh grade, and I remember when I was doing this, I was thinking about that little rock there, and the pathway of the vehicles as they would fly through the air, and how the characters —(Laughter) —would come shooting out of the car, so, on my mind, I was thinking about the trajectory of the vehicles. And of course, when you're a little kid, there's always destruction. So, it has to end with this —(Laughter) —gratuitous violence.(Laughter)So that was how I first started to explore the way things moved, and expressed it.Now, when I went to college, I found myself making fairly complicated, fragile machines. And this really came about from having many different kinds of interests. When I was in high school, I loved to program computers, so I sort of liked the logical flow of events. I was also very interested in perhaps going into surgery and becoming a surgeon, because it meant working with my hands in a very focused, intense way. So, I started taking art courses, and I found a way to make sculpture that brought together my love for being very precise with my hands, with coming up with different kinds of logical flows of energy through a system. And also, working with wire — everything that I did was both a visual and a mechanical engineering decision at the same time. So, I was able to sort of exercise all of that.Now, this kind of machine is as close as I can get to painting. And it's full of many little trivial end points, like there's a little foot here that just drags around in circles and it doesn't really mean anything. It's really just for the sort of joy of its own triviality. The connection I have with engineering is the same as any other engineer, in that I love to solve problems. I love to figure things out, but the end result of what I'm doing is really completely ambiguous.(Laughter)That's pretty ambiguous.(Laughter)The next piece that is going to come up is an example of a kind of machine that is fairly complex. I gave myself the problem. Since I'm always liking to solve problems, I gave myself the problem of turning a crank in one direction, and solving all of the mechanical problems for getting this little man to walk back and forth. So, when I started this, I didn't have an overall plan for the machine, but I did have a sense of the gesture, and a sense of the shape and how it would occupy space. And then it was a matter of starting from one point and sort of building to that final point. That little gear there switches back and forth to change direction. And that's a little found object.So a lot of the pieces that I've made, they involve found objects. And it really — it's almost like doing visual puns all the time. When I see objects, I imagine them in motion. I imagine what can be said with them.This next one here, "Machine with Wishbone," it came about from playing with this wishbone after dinner. You know, they say, never play with your food — but I always play with things. So, I had this wishbone, and I thought, it's kind of like a cowboy who's been on his horse for too long.(Laughter)And I started to make him walk across the table, and I thought, "Oh, I can make a little machine that will do that." So, I made this device, linked it up, and the wishbone walks. And because the wishbone is bone — it's animal — it's sort of a point where I think we can enter into it. And that's the whole piece.(Laughter)That's about that big.(Applause)This kind of work is also very much like puppetry, where the found object is, in a sense, the puppet, and I'm the puppeteer at first, because I'm playing with an object. But then I make the machine, which is sort of the stand-in for me, and it is able to achieve the action that I want.The next piece I'll show you is a much more conceptual thought, and it's a little piece called "Cory's Yellow Chair." I had this image in my mind, when I saw my son's little chair, and I saw it explode up and out. And — so the way I saw this in my mind at first, was that the pieces would explode up and out with infinite speed, and the pieces would move far out, and then they would begin to be pulled back with a kind of a gravitational feel, to the point where they would approach infinite speed back to the center. And they would coalesce for just a moment, so you could perceive that there was a chair there. For me, it's kind of a feeling about the fleetingness of the present moment, and I wanted to express that. Now, the machine is — in this case, it's a real approximation of that, because obviously you can't move physical matter infinitely with infinite speed and have it stop instantaneously. This whole thing is about four feet wide, and the chair itself is only about a few inches.(Applause)Now, this is a funny sort of conceptual thing, and yesterday we were talking about Danny Hillis' "10,000 Year Clock." So, we have a motor here on the left, and it goes through a gear train. There are 12 pairs of 50:1 reductions, so that means that the final speed of that gear on the end is so slow that it would take two trillion years to turn once. So I've invented it in concrete, because it doesn't really matter.(Laughter)Because it could run all the time.(Laughter)Now, a completely different thought. I'm always imagining myself in different situations. I'm imagining myself as a machine. What would I love? I would love to be bathed in oil.(Laughter)So, this machine does nothing but just bathe itself in oil.(Laughter)(Applause)And it's really, just sort of — for me, it was just really about the lusciousness of oil.(Laughter)And then, I got a call from a friend who wanted to have a show of erotic art, and I didn't have any pieces. But when she suggested to be in the show, this piece came to mind. So, it's sort of related, but you can see it's much more overtly erotic. And this one I call "Machine with Grease." It's just continually ejaculating, and it's —(Laughter) —this is a happy machine, I'll tell you.(Laughter)It's definitely happy.From an engineering point of view, this is just a little four-bar linkage. And then again, this is a found object, a little fan that I found. And I thought, what about the gesture of opening the fan, and how simply could I state something. And, in a case like this, I'm trying to make something which is clear but also not suggestive of any particular kind of animal or plant.For me, the process is very important, because I'm inventing machines, but I'm also inventing tools to make machines, and the whole thing is all sort of wrapped up from the beginning. So this is a little wire-bending tool. After many years of bending gears with a pair of pliers, I made that tool, and then I made this other tool for sort of centering gears very quickly — sort of developing my own little world of technology. My life completely changed when I found a spot welder.(Laughter)And that was that tool. It completely changed what I could do. Now here, I'm going to do a very poor job of silver soldering. This is not the way they teach you to silver solder when you're in school. I just like, throw it in. I mean, real jewelers put little bits of solder in. So, that's a finished gear.When I moved to Boston, I joined a group called the World Sculpture Racing Society.(Laughter)And the idea, their premise was that we wanted to show pieces of sculpture on the street, and there'd be no subjective decision about what was the best. It would be — whatever came across the finish line first would be the winner.(Laughter)So I made — this is my first racing sculpture, and I thought, "Oh, I'm going to make a cart, and I'm going to have it — I'm going to have my hand writing 'faster,' so as I run down the street, the cart's going to talk to me and it's going to go, 'Faster, faster!' " So, that's what it does.(Laughter)But then in the end, what I decided was every time you finish writing the word, I would stop and I would give the card to somebody on the side of the road. So I would never win the race because I'm always stopping. But I had a lot of fun.(Applause)Now, I only have two and a half minutes — I'm going to play this. This is a piece that, for me, is in some ways the most complete kind of piece. Because when I was a kid, I also played a lot of guitar. And when I had this thought, I was imagining that I would make — I would have a whole machine theater evening, where I would — you would have an audience, the curtain would open, and you'd be entertained by machines on stage. So, I imagined a very simple gestural dance that would be between a machine and just a very simple chair, and ... When I'm making these pieces, I'm always trying to find a point where I'm saying something very clearly and it's very simple, but also at the same time it's very ambiguous. And I think there's a point between simplicity and ambiguity which can allow a viewer to perhaps take something from it.And that leads me to the thought that all of these pieces start off in my own mind, in my heart, and I do my best at finding ways to express them with materials, and it always feels really crude. It's always a struggle, but somehow I manage to sort of get this thought out into an object, and then it's there, OK. It means nothing at all. The object itself just means nothing. Once it's perceived, and someone brings it into their own mind, then there's a cycle that has been completed. And to me, that's the most important thing because, ever since being a kid, I've wanted to communicate my passion and love. And that means the complete cycle of coming from inside, out to the physical, to someone perceiving it. So I'll just let this chair come down.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)
