00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:41.958
We know from working on animals that the truth is

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
that's exactly what you don't want to do -- because evolution works

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
on the just-good-enough principle, not on a perfecting principle.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:52.958
And the constraints in building any organism, when you look at it,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:57.958
are really severe. Natural technologies have incredible constraints.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Think about it. If you were an engineer and I told you

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:05.958
that you had to build an automobile, but it had to start off to be this big,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.958
then it had to grow to be full size and had to work every step along the way.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
Or think about the fact that if you build an automobile, I'll tell you that you also -- inside it --

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:17.958
have to put a factory that allows you to make another automobile.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
(Laughter)

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
And you can absolutely never, absolutely never, because of history

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and the inherited plan, start with a clean slate.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
So, organisms have this important history.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:35.958
Really evolution works more like a tinkerer than an engineer.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
And this is really important when you begin to look at animals.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:45.958
Instead, we believe you need to be inspired by biology.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:49.958
You need to discover the general principles of nature,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and then use these analogies when they're advantageous.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
This is a real challenge to do this, because animals,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
when you start to really look inside them -- how they work --

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
appear hopelessly complex. There's no detailed history

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
of the design plans, you can't go look it up anywhere.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:12.958
They have way too many motions for their joints, too many muscles.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
Even the simplest animal we think of, something like an insect,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
and they have more neurons and connections than you can imagine.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:23.958
How can you make sense of this? Well, we believed --

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:28.958
and we hypothesized -- that one way animals could work simply,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
is if the control of their movements

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:37.958
tended to be built into their bodies themselves.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:44.958
What we discovered was that two-, four-, six- and eight-legged animals

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
all produce the same forces on the ground when they move.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
They all work like this kangaroo, they bounce.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And they can be modeled by a spring-mass system that we call the spring mass system

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
because we're biomechanists. It's actually a pogo stick.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:02.958
They all produce the pattern of a pogo stick. How is that true?

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:08.958
Well, a human, one of your legs works like two legs of a trotting dog,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.958
or works like three legs, together as one, of a trotting insect,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
or four legs as one of a trotting crab.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And then they alternate in their propulsion,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:23.958
but the patterns are all the same. Almost every organism we've looked at this way

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
-- you'll see next week, I'll give you a hint,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
there'll be an article coming out that says that really big things

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
like T. rex probably couldn't do this, but you'll see that next week.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
Now, what's interesting is the animals, then -- we said -- bounce along

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
the vertical plane this way, and in our collaborations with Pixar,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
in "A Bug's Life," we discussed the

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
bipedal nature of the characters of the ants.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
And we told them, of course, they move in another plane as well.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
And they asked us this question. They say, "Why model

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
just in the sagittal plane or the vertical plane,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
when you're telling us these animals are moving

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
in the horizontal plane?" This is a good question.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
Nobody in biology ever modeled it this way.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:01.958
We took their advice and we modeled the animals moving

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
in the horizontal plane as well. We took their three legs,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:05.958
we collapsed them down as one.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
We got some of the best mathematicians in the world

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
from Princeton to work on this problem.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
And we were able to create a model

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:14.958
where animals are not only bouncing up and down,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
but they're also bouncing side to side at the same time.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And many organisms fit this kind of pattern.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Now, why is this important to have this model?

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
Because it's very interesting. When you take this model

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and you perturb it, you give it a push,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
as it bumps into something, it self-stabilizes, with no brain

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:36.958
or no reflexes, just by the structure alone.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:41.958
It's a beautiful model. Let's look at the mathematics.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
(Laughter)

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:44.958
That's enough!

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
(Laughter)

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
The animals, when you look at them running,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
appear to be self-stabilizing like this,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
using basically springy legs. That is, the legs can do

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
computations on their own; the control algorithms, in a sense,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
are embedded in the form of the animal itself.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:09.958
Why haven't we been more inspired by nature and these kinds of discoveries?

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
Well, I would argue that human technologies are really different from

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
natural technologies, at least they have been so far.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Think about the typical kind of robot that you see.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Human technologies have tended to be large, flat,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:29.958
with right angles, stiff, made of metal. They have rolling devices

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
and axles. There are very few motors, very few sensors.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Whereas nature tends to be small, and curved,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
and it bends and twists, and has legs instead, and appendages,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and has many muscles and many, many sensors.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
So it's a very different design. However, what's changing,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
what's really exciting -- and I'll show you some of that next --

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
is that as human technology takes on more of the characteristics

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:58.958
of nature, then nature really can become a much more useful teacher.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And here's one example that's really exciting.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
This is a collaboration we have with Stanford.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And they developed this new technique, called Shape Deposition Manufacturing.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
It's a technique where they can mix materials together and mold any shape

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
that they like, and put in the material properties.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
They can embed sensors and actuators right in the form itself.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:22.958
For example, here's a leg: the clear part is stiff,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
the white part is compliant, and you don't need any axles there or anything.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
It just bends by itself beautifully.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
So, you can put those properties in. It inspired them to show off

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:37.958
this design by producing a little robot they named Sprawl.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Our work has also inspired another robot, a biologically inspired bouncing robot,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
from the University of Michigan and McGill

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:51.958
named RHex, for robot hexapod, and this one's autonomous.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
Let's go to the video, and let me show you some of these animals moving

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
and then some of the simple robots

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
that have been inspired by our discoveries.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Here's what some of you did this morning, although you did it outside,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
not on a treadmill.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Here's what we do.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
(Laughter)

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:15.958
This is a death's head cockroach. This is an American cockroach

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:16.958
you think you don't have in your kitchen.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:23.958
This is an eight-legged scorpion, six-legged ant, forty-four-legged centipede.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
Now, I said all these animals are sort of working like pogo sticks --

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
they're bouncing along as they move. And you can see that

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
in this ghost crab, from the beaches of Panama and North Carolina.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
It goes up to four meters per second when it runs.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
It actually leaps into the air, and has aerial phases

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
when it does it, like a horse, and you'll see it's bouncing here.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
What we discovered is whether you look at the leg of a human

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:52.958
like Richard, or a cockroach, or a crab, or a kangaroo,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:57.958
the relative leg stiffness of that spring is the same for everything we've seen so far.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
Now, what good are springy legs then? What can they do?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
Well, we wanted to see if they allowed the animals

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
to have greater stability and maneuverability.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
So, we built a terrain that had obstacles three times the hip height

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:09.958
of the animals that we're looking at.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
And we were certain they couldn't do this. And here's what they did.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
The animal ran over it and it didn't even slow down!

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
It didn't decrease its preferred speed at all.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
We couldn't believe that it could do this. It said to us

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:26.958
that if you could build a robot with very simple, springy legs,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:32.958
you could make it as maneuverable as any that's ever been built.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Here's the first example of that. This is the Stanford

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
Shape Deposition Manufactured robot, named Sprawl.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:43.958
It has six legs -- there are the tuned, springy legs.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
It moves in a gait that an insect uses, and here it is

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:53.958
going on the treadmill. Now, what's important about this robot,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
compared to other robots, is that it can't see anything,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:02.958
it can't feel anything, it doesn't have a brain, yet it can maneuver

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:08.958
over these obstacles without any difficulty whatsoever.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
It's this technique of building the properties into the form.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
This is a graduate student. This is what he's doing to his thesis project --

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
very robust, if a graduate student

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
does that to his thesis project.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:20.958
(Laughter)

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
This is from McGill and University of Michigan. This is the RHex,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
making its first outing in a demo.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:31.958
(Laughter)

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:36.958
Same principle: it only has six moving parts,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:42.958
six motors, but it has springy, tuned legs. It moves in the gait of the insect.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
It has the middle leg moving in synchrony with the front,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and the hind leg on the other side. Sort of an alternating tripod,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
and they can negotiate obstacles just like the animal.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:11:00.958
(Laughter)

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:01.958
(Voice: Oh my God.)

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:06.958
(Applause)

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Robert Full: It'll go on different surfaces -- here's sand --

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:13.958
although we haven't perfected the feet yet, but I'll talk about that later.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Here's RHex entering the woods.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
(Laughter)

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Again, this robot can't see anything, it can't feel anything,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:41.958
it has no brain. It's just working with a tuned mechanical system,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:51.958
with very simple parts, but inspired from the fundamental dynamics of the animal.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:59.958
(Voice: Ah, I love him, Bob.) RF: Here's it going down a pathway.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
I presented this to the jet propulsion lab at NASA, and they said

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
that they had no ability to go down craters to look for ice,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
and life, ultimately, on Mars. And he said --

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
especially with legged-robots, because they're way too complicated.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Nothing can do that. And I talk next. I showed them this video

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
with the simple design of RHex here. And just to convince them

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
we should go to Mars in 2011, I tinted the video orange

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
just to give them the sense of being on Mars.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:28.958
(Laughter)

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:34.958
(Applause)

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
Another reason why animals have extraordinary performance,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
and can go anywhere, is because they have an effective interaction

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
with the environment. The animal I'm going to show you,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
that we studied to look at this, is the gecko.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:56.958
We have one here and notice its position. It's holding on.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Now I'm going to challenge you. I'm going show you a video.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
One of the animals is going to be running on the level,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
and the other one's going to be running up a wall. Which one's which?

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:10.958
They're going at a meter a second. How many think the one on the left

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
is running up the wall?

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
(Applause)

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:21.958
Okay. The point is it's really hard to tell, isn't it? It's incredible,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
we looked at students do this and they couldn't tell.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
They can run up a wall at a meter a second, 15 steps per second,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
and they look like they're running on the level. How do they do this?

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:36.958
It's just phenomenal. The one on the right was going up the hill.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
How do they do this? They have bizarre toes. They have toes

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
that uncurl like party favors when you blow them out,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
and then peel off the surface, like tape.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
Like if we had a piece of tape now, we'd peel it this way.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:56.958
They do this with their toes. It's bizarre! This peeling inspired

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
iRobot -- that we work with -- to build Mecho-Geckos.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Here's a legged version and a tractor version, or a bulldozer version.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Let's see some of the geckos move with some video,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and then I'll show you a little bit of a clip of the robots.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Here's the gecko running up a vertical surface. There it goes,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:21.958
in real time. There it goes again. Obviously, we have to slow this down a little bit.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
You can't use regular cameras.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
You have to take 1,000 pictures per second to see this.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
And here's some video at 1,000 frames per second.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Now, I want you to look at the animal's back.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Do you see how much it's bending like that? We can't figure that out --

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
that's an unsolved mystery. We don't know how it works.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
If you have a son or a daughter that wants to come to Berkeley,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
come to my lab and we'll figure this out. Okay, send them to Berkeley

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
because that's the next thing I want to do. Here's the gecko mill.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:48.958
(Laughter)

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
It's a see-through treadmill with a see-through treadmill belt,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
so we can watch the animal's feet, and videotape them

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
through the treadmill belt, to see how they move.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
Here's the animal that we have here, running on a vertical surface.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Pick a foot and try to watch a toe, and see if you can see what the animal's doing.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
See it uncurl and then peel these toes.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:16.958
It can do this in 14 milliseconds. It's unbelievable.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Here are the robots that they inspire, the Mecho-Geckos from iRobot.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:25.958
First we'll see the animals toes peeling -- look at that.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
And here's the peeling action of the Mecho-Gecko.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
It uses a pressure-sensitive adhesive to do it.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
Peeling in the animal. Peeling in the Mecho-Gecko --

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
that allows them climb autonomously. Can go on the flat surface,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
transition to a wall, and then go onto a ceiling.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:47.958
There's the bulldozer version. Now, it doesn't use pressure-sensitive glue.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
The animal does not use that.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
But that's what we're limited to, at the moment.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.958
What does the animal do? The animal has weird toes.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
And if you look at the toes, they have these little leaves there,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and if you blow them up and zoom in, you'll see

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
that's there's little striations in these leaves.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:12.958
And if you zoom in 270 times, you'll see it looks like a rug.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And if you blow that up, and zoom in 900 times,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:20.958
you see there are hairs there, tiny hairs. And if you look carefully,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:26.958
those tiny hairs have striations. And if you zoom in on those 30,000 times,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
you'll see each hair has split ends.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:34.958
And if you blow those up, they have these little structures on the end.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
The smallest branch of the hairs looks like spatulae,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:43.958
and an animal like that has one billion of these nano-size split ends,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:48.958
to get very close to the surface. In fact, there's the diameter of your hair --

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:54.958
a gecko has two million of these, and each hair has 100 to 1,000 split ends.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
Think of the contact of that that's possible.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
We were fortunate to work with another group

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
at Stanford that built us a special manned sensor,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
that we were able to measure the force of an individual hair.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:09.958
Here's an individual hair with a little split end there.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
When we measured the forces, they were enormous.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
They were so large that a patch of hairs about this size --

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
the gecko's foot could support the weight of a small child,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:22.958
about 40 pounds, easily. Now, how do they do it?

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:26.958
We've recently discovered this. Do they do it by friction?

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
No, force is too low. Do they do it by electrostatics?

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
No, you can change the charge -- they still hold on.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
Do they do it by interlocking? That's kind of a like a Velcro-like thing.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
No, you can put them on molecular smooth surfaces -- they don't do it.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:41.958
How about suction? They stick on in a vacuum.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
How about wet adhesion? Or capillary adhesion?

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
They don't have any glue, and they even stick under water just fine.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
If you put their foot under water, they grab on.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:53.958
How do they do it then? Believe it or not, they grab on

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:57.958
by intermolecular forces, by Van der Waals forces.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
You know, you probably had this a long time ago in chemistry,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
where you had these two atoms, they're close together,

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
and the electrons are moving around. That tiny force is sufficient

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
to allow them to do that because it's added up so many times

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:10.958
with these small structures.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:15.958
What we're doing is, we're taking that inspiration of the hairs,

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:20.958
and with another colleague at Berkeley, we're manufacturing them.

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
And just recently we've made a breakthrough, where we now believe

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:28.958
we're going to be able to create the first synthetic, self-cleaning,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:33.958
dry adhesive. Many companies are interested in this.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
(Laughter)

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:38.958
We also presented to Nike even.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
(Laughter)

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:47.958
(Applause)

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
We'll see where this goes. We were so excited about this

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
that we realized that that small-size scale --

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
and where everything gets sticky, and gravity doesn't matter anymore --

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
we needed to look at ants and their feet, because

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:04.958
one of my other colleagues at Berkeley has built a six-millimeter silicone

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
robot with legs. But it gets stuck. It doesn't move very well.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
But the ants do, and we'll figure out why, so that ultimately

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:13.958
we'll make this move. And imagine: you're going to be able

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:18.958
to have swarms of these six-millimeter robots available to run around.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
Where's this going? I think you can see it already.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:25.958
Clearly, the Internet is already having eyes and ears,

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:29.958
you have web cams and so forth. But it's going to also have legs and hands.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
You're going to be able to do programmable

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:35.958
work through these kinds of robots, so that you can run,

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:44.958
fly and swim anywhere. We saw David Kelly is at the beginning of that with his fish.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:46.958
So, in conclusion, I think the message is clear.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:50.958
If you need a message, if nature's not enough, if you care about

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
search and rescue, or mine clearance, or medicine,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:56.958
or the various things we're working on, we must preserve

00:19:56.958 --> 00:20:00.958
nature's designs, otherwise these secrets will be lost forever.

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:01.958
Thank you.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:10.958
(Applause)

title: A mobile fridge for vaccines
transcript: This is a work in process, based on some comments that were made at TED two years ago about the need for the storage of vaccine.(Video): [On this planet 1.6 billion people don't have access to electricity refrigeration or stored fuels this is a problem it impacts: the spread of disease the storage of food and medicine and the quality of life. So here's the plan ... inexpensive refrigeration that doesn't use electricity, propane, gas, kerosene or consumables time for some thermodynamics And the story of the Intermittent Absorption Refrigerator]Adam Grosser: So 29 years ago, I had this thermo teacher who talked about absorption and refrigeration, one of those things that stuck in my head, a lot like the Stirling engine: it was cool, but you didn't know what to do with it. It was invented in 1858, by this guy Ferdinand Carré, but he couldn't actually build anything with it because of the tools at the time.This crazy Canadian named Powel Crosley commercialized this thing called the IcyBall, in 1928. It was a really neat idea, and I'll get to why it didn't work, but here's how it works. There's two spheres and they're separated in distance. One has a working fluid, water and ammonia, and the other is a condenser. You heat up one side, the hot side. The ammonia evaporates and it recondenses in the other side. You let it cool to room temperature, and then, as the ammonia reevaporates and combines with the water back on the erstwhile hot side, it creates a powerful cooling effect. So it was a great idea that didn't work at all. They blew up.(Laughter)Because you're using ammonia, you get hugely high pressures if you heated them wrong; it topped 400 psi. The ammonia was toxic, it sprayed everywhere. But it was kind of an interesting thought.So the great thing about 2006, there's a lot of really great computational work you can do. So we got the whole thermodynamics department at Stanford involved — a lot of computational fluid dynamics. We proved that most of the ammonia refrigeration tables are wrong. We found some nontoxic refrigerants that worked at very low vapor pressures. We brought in a team from the UK — a lot of great refrigeration people, it turns out, in the UK — and built a test rig, and proved that, in fact, we could make a low-pressure, nontoxic refrigerator.So this is the way it works. You put it on a cooking fire. Most people have cooking fires in the world, whether it's camel dung or wood. It heats up for about 30 minutes, cools for an hour. You put it into a container and it will refrigerate for 24 hours. It looks like this. This is the fifth prototype, it's not quite done. It weighs about eight pounds, and this is the way it works. You put it into a 15-liter vessel, about three gallons, and it'll cool it down to just above freezing — three degrees above freezing — for 24 hours in a 30 degree C environment. It's really cheap. We think we can build these in high volumes for about 25 dollars, in low volumes for about 40 dollars. And we think we can make refrigeration something that everybody can have.Thank you.(Applause)

title: Surprising stats about child carseats
transcript: Once upon a time, there was a dread disease that afflicted children. And in fact, among all the diseases that existed in this land, it was the worst. It killed the most children. And along came a brilliant inventor, a scientist, who came up with a partial cure for that disease. And it wasn't perfect. Many children still died, but it was certainly better than what they had before. And one of the good things about this cure was that it was free, virtually free, and was very easy to use. But the worst thing about it was that you couldn't use it on the youngest children, on infants, and on one-year-olds.And so, as a consequence, a few years later, another scientist — perhaps maybe this scientist not quite as brilliant as the one who had preceded him, but building on the invention of the first one — came up with a second cure. And the beauty of the second cure for this disease was that it could be used on infants and one-year-olds. And the problem with this cure was it was very expensive, and it was very complicated to use. And although parents tried as hard as they could to use it properly, almost all of them ended up using it wrong in the end. But what they did, of course, since it was so complicated and expensive, they only used it on the zero-year-olds and the one-year-olds. And they kept on using the existing cure that they had on the two-year-olds and up.And this went on for quite some time. People were happy. They had their two cures. Until a particular mother, whose child had just turned two, died of this disease. And she thought to herself, "My child just turned two, and until the child turned two, I had always used this complicated, expensive cure, you know, this treatment. And then the child turned two, and I started using the cheap and easy treatment, and I wonder" — and she wondered, like all parents who lose children wonder — "if there isn't something that I could have done, like keep on using that complicated, expensive cure." And she told all the other people, and she said, "How could it possibly be that something that's cheap and simple works as well as something that's complicated and expensive?" And the people thought, "You know, you're right. It probably is the wrong thing to do to switch and use the cheap and simple solution." And the government, they heard her story and the other people, and they said, "Yeah, you're right, we should make a law. We should outlaw this cheap and simple treatment and not let anybody use this on their children." And the people were happy. They were satisfied.For many years this went along, and everything was fine. But then along came a lowly economist, who had children himself, and he used the expensive and complicated treatment. But he knew about the cheap and simple one. And he thought about it, and the expensive one didn't seem that great to him. So he thought, "I don't know anything about science, but I do know something about data, so maybe I should go and look at the data and see whether this expensive and complicated treatment actually works any better than the cheap and simple one." And lo and behold, when he went through the data, he found that it didn't look like the expensive, complicated solution was any better than the cheap one, at least for the children who were two and older — the cheap one still didn't work on the kids who were younger.And so, he went forth to the people and he said, "I've made this wonderful finding: it looks as if we could just use the cheap and simple solution, and by doing so we could save ourselves 300 million dollars a year, and we could spend that on our children in other ways." And the parents were very unhappy, and they said, "This is a terrible thing, because how can the cheap and easy thing be as good as the hard thing?" And the government was very upset. And in particular, the people who made this expensive solution were very upset because they thought, "How can we hope to compete with something that's essentially free? We would lose all of our market." And people were very angry, and they called him horrible names. And he decided that maybe he should leave the country for a few days, and seek out some more intelligent, open-minded people in a place called Oxford, and come and try and tell the story at that place.And so, anyway, here I am. It's not a fairy tale. It's a true story about the United States today, and the disease I'm referring to is actually motor vehicle accidents for children. And the free cure is adult seatbelts, and the expensive cure — the 300-million-dollar-a-year cure — is child car seats. And what I'd like to talk to you about today is some of the evidence why I believe this to be true: that for children two years old and up, there really is no real benefit — proven benefit — of car seats, in spite of the incredible energy that has been devoted toward expanding the laws and making it socially unacceptable to put your children into seatbelts. And then talk about why — what is it that makes that true? And then, finally talk a little bit about a third way, about another technology, which is probably better than anything we have, but which — there hasn't been any enthusiasm for adoption precisely because people are so enamored with the current car seat solution. OK.So, many times when you try to do research on data, it records complicated stories — it's hard to find in the data. It doesn't turn out to be the case when you look at seatbelts versus car seats. So the United States keeps a data set of every fatal accident that's happened since 1975. So in every car crash in which at least one person dies, they have information on all of the people. So if you look at that data — it's right up on the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration's website — you can just look at the raw data, and begin to get a sense of the limited amount of evidence that's in favor of car seats for children aged two and up. So, here is the data. Here I have, among two- to six-year-olds — anyone above six, basically no one uses car seats, so you can't compare — 29.3 percent of the children who are unrestrained in a crash in which at least one person dies, themselves die. If you put a child in a car seat, 18.2 percent of the children die. If they're wearing a lap-and-shoulder belt, in this raw data, 19.4 percent die. And interestingly, wearing a lap-only seatbelt, 16.7 percent die. And actually, the theory tells you that the lap-only seatbelt's got to be worse than the lap-and-shoulder belt. And that just reminds you that when you deal with raw data, there are hundreds of confounding variables that may be getting in the way.So what we do in the study is — and this is just presenting the same information, but turned into a figure to make it easier. So the yellow bar represents car seats, the orange bar lap-and-shoulder, and the red bar lap-only seatbelts. And this is all relative to unrestrained — the bigger the bar, the better. Okay. So, this is the data I just showed, OK? So the highest bar is what you're striving to beat. So you can control for the basic things, like how hard the crash was, what seat the child was sitting in, etc., the age of the child. And that's that middle set of bars. And so, you can see that the lap-only seatbelts start to look worse once you do that. And then finally, the last set of bars, which are really controlling for everything you could possibly imagine about the crash, 50, 75, 100 different characteristics of the crash.And what you find is that the car seats and the lap-and-shoulder belts, when it comes to saving lives, fatalities look exactly identical. And the standard error bands are relatively small around these estimates as well. And it's not just overall. It's very robust to anything you want to look at. One thing that's interesting: if you look at frontal-impact crashes — when the car crashes, the front hits into something — indeed, what you see is that the car seats look a little bit better. And I think this isn't just chance. In order to have the car seat approved, you need to pass certain federal standards, all of which involve slamming your car into a direct frontal crash. But when you look at other types of crashes, like rear-impact crashes, indeed, the car seats don't perform as well. And I think that's because they've been optimized to pass, as we always expect people to do, to optimize relative to bright-line rules about how affected the car will be.And the other thing you might argue is, "Well, car seats have got a lot better over time. And so if we look at recent crashes — the whole data set is almost 30 years' worth of data — you won't see it in the recent crashes. The new car seats are far, far better." But indeed, in recent crashes the lap-and-shoulder seatbelts, actually, are doing even better than the car seats. They say, "Well, that's impossible, that can't be." And the line of argument, if you ask parents, is, "But car seats are so expensive and complicated, and they have this big tangle of latches, how could they possibly not work better than seatbelts because they are so expensive and complicated?" It's kind of an interesting logic, I think, that people use. And the other logic, they say, "Well, the government wouldn't have told us [to] use them if they weren't much better."But what's interesting is the government telling us to use them is not actually based on very much. It really is based on some impassioned pleas of parents whose children died after they turned two, which has led to the passage of all these laws — not very much on data. So you can only get so far, I think, in telling your story by using these abstract statistics. And so I had some friends over to dinner, and I was asking — we had a cookout — I was asking them what advice they might have for me about proving my point. They said, "Why don't you run some crash tests?" And I said, "That's a great idea." So we actually tried to commission some crash tests. And it turns out that as we called around to the independent crash test companies around the country, none of them wanted to do our crash test because they said, some explicitly, some not so explicitly, "All of our business comes from car seat manufacturers. We can't risk alienating them by testing seatbelts relative to car seats."Now, eventually, one did. Under the conditions of anonymity, they said they would be happy to do this test for us — so anonymity, and 1,500 dollars per seat that we crashed. And so, we went to Buffalo, New York, and here is the precursor to it. These are the crash test dummies, waiting for their chance to take the center stage. And then, here's how the crash test works. Here, they don't actually crash the entire car, you know — it's not worth ruining a whole car to do it. So they just have these bench seats, and they strap the car seat and the seatbelt onto it. So I just wanted you to look at this. And I think this gives you a good idea of why parents think car seats are so great. Look at the kid in the car seat. Does he not look content, ready to go, like he could survive anything? And then, if you look at the kid in back, it looks like he's already choking before the crash even happens. It's hard to believe, when you look at this, that that kid in back is going to do very well when you get in a crash. So this is going to be a crash where they're going to slam this thing forward into a wall at 30 miles an hour, and see what happens. OK?So, let me show you what happens. These are three-year-old dummies, by the way. So here — this is the car seat. Now watch two things: watch how the head goes forward, and basically hits the knees — and this is in the car seat — and watch how the car seat flies around, in the rebound, up in the air. The car seat's moving all over the place. Bear in mind there are two things about this. This is a car seat that was installed by someone who has installed 1,000 car seats, who knew exactly how to do it. And also it turned out these bench seats are the very best way to install car seats. Having a flat back makes it much easier to install them. And so this is a test that's very much rigged in favor of the car seat, OK? So, that kid in this crash fared very well.The federal standards are that you have to score below a 1,000 to be an approved car seat on this crash, in some metric of units which are not important. And this crash would have been about a 450. So this car seat was actually an above-average car seat from Consumer Reports, and did quite well. So the next one. Now, this is the kid, same crash, who is in the seatbelt. He hardly moves at all, actually, relative to the other child. The funny thing is, the cam work is terrible because they've only set it up to do the car seats, and so, they actually don't even have a way to move the camera so you can see the kid that's on the rebound. Anyway, it turns out that those two crashes, that actually the three-year-old did slightly worse. So, he gets about a 500 out of — you know, on this range — relative to a 400 and something. But still, if you just took that data from that crash to the federal government, and said, "I have invented a new car seat. I would like you to approve it for selling," then they would say, "This is a fantastic new car seat, it works great. It only got a 500, it could have gotten as high up as a 1,000." And this seatbelt would have passed with flying colors into being approved as a car seat.So, in some sense, what this is suggesting is that it's not just that people are setting up their car seats wrong, which is putting children at risk. It's just that, fundamentally, the car seats aren't doing much. So here's the crash. So these are timed at the same time, so you can see that it takes much longer with the car seat — at rebound, it takes a lot longer — but there's just a lot less movement for child who's in the seatbelt. So, I'll show you the six-year-old crashes as well. The six-year-old is in a car seat, and it turns out that looks terrible, but that's great. That's like a 400, OK? So that kid would do fine in the crash. Nothing about that would have been problematic to the child at all. And then here's the six-year-old in the seatbelt, and in fact, they get exactly within, you know, within one or two points of the same. So really, for the six-year-old, the car seat did absolutely nothing whatsoever.That's some more evidence, so in some sense — I was criticized by a scientist, who said, "You could never publish a study with an n of 4," meaning those four crashes. So I wrote him back and I said, "What about an n of 45,004?" Because I had the other 45,000 other real-world crashes. And I just think that it's interesting that the idea of using real-world crashes, which is very much something that economists think would be the right thing to do, is something that scientists don't actually, usually think — they would rather use a laboratory, a very imperfect science of looking at the dummies, than actually 30 years of data of what we've seen with children and with car seats.And so I think the answer to this puzzle is that there's a much better solution out there, that's gotten nobody excited because everyone is so delighted with the way car seats are presumably working. And if you think from a design perspective, about going back to square one, and say, "I just want to protect kids in the back seat." I don't there's anyone in this room who'd say, "Well, the right way to start would be, let's make a great seat belt for adults. And then, let's make this really big contraption that you have to rig up to it in this daisy chain." I mean, why not start — who's sitting in the back seat anyway except for kids? But essentially, do something like this, which I don't know exactly how much it would cost to do, but there's no reason I could see why this should be much more expensive than a regular car seat. It's just actually — you see, this is folding up — it's behind the seat. You've got a regular seat for adults, and then you fold it down, and the kid sits on top, and it's integrated. It seems to me that this can't be a very expensive solution, and it's got to work better than what we already have.So the question is, is there any hope for adoption of something like this, which would presumably save a lot of lives? And I think the answer, perhaps, lies in a story. The answer both to why has a car seat been so successful, and why this may someday be adopted or not, lies in a story that my dad told me, relating to when he was a doctor in the U.S. Air Force in England. And this is a long time ago: you were allowed to do things then you can't do today. So, my father would have patients come in who he thought were not really sick. And he had a big jar full of placebo pills that he would give them, and he'd say, "Come back in a week, if you still feel lousy." OK, and most of them would not come back, but some of them would come back. And when they came back, he, still convinced they were not sick, had another jar of pills. In this jar were huge horse pills. They were almost impossible to swallow. And these, to me, are the analogy for the car seats. People would look at these and say, "Man, this thing is so big and so hard to swallow. If this doesn't make me feel better, you know, what possibly could?"And it turned out that most people wouldn't come back, because it worked. But every once in a while, there was still a patient convinced that he was sick, and he'd come back. And my dad had a third jar of pills. And the jar of pills he had, he said, were the tiniest little pills he could find, so small you could barely see them. And he would say, listen, I know I gave you that huge pill, that complicated, hard-to-swallow pill before, but now I've got one that's so potent, that is really tiny and small and almost invisible. It's almost like this thing here, which you can't even see."And it turned out that never, in all the times my dad gave out this pill, the really tiny pill, did anyone ever come back still complaining of sickness. So, my dad always took that as evidence that this little, teeny, powerful pill had the ultimate placebo effect. And in some sense, if that's the right story, I think integrated car seats you will see, very quickly, becoming something that everyone has. The other possible conclusion is, well, maybe after coming to my father three times, getting sent home with placebos, he still felt sick, he went and found another doctor. And that's completely possible. And if that's the case, then I think we're stuck with conventional car seats for a long time to come. Thank you very much.(Applause)(Audience: I just wanted to ask you, when we wear seatbelts we don't necessarily wear them just to prevent loss of life, it's also to prevent lots of serious injury. Your data looks at fatalities. It doesn't look at serious injury. Is there any data to show that child seats are actually less effective, or just as effective as seatbelts for serious injury? Because that would prove your case.)Steven Levitt: Yeah, that's a great question. In my data, and in another data set I've looked at for New Jersey crashes, I find very small differences in injury. So in this data, it's statistically insignificant differences in injury between car seats and lap-and-shoulder belts. In the New Jersey data, which is different, because it's not just fatal crashes, but all crashes in New Jersey that are reported, it turns out that there is a 10 percent difference in injuries, but generally they're the minor injuries. Now, what's interesting, I should say this as a disclaimer, there is medical literature that is very difficult to resolve with this other data, which suggests that car seats are dramatically better.And they use a completely different methodology that involves — after the crash occurs, they get from the insurance companies the names of the people who were in the crash, and they call them on the phone, and they asked them what happened. And I really can't resolve, yet, and I'd like to work with these medical researchers to try to understand how there can be these differences, which are completely at odds with one another. But it's obviously a critical question. The question is even if — are there enough serious injuries to make these cost-effective? It's kind of tricky. Even if they're right, it's not so clear that they're so cost-effective.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:16.958
Once upon a time, there was a dread disease that afflicted children.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:20.958
And in fact, among all the diseases that existed in this land,

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
it was the worst. It killed the most children.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
And along came a brilliant inventor, a scientist,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
who came up with a partial cure for that disease.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:33.958
And it wasn't perfect. Many children still died,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
but it was certainly better than what they had before.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:42.958
And one of the good things about this cure was that it was free,

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
virtually free, and was very easy to use.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
But the worst thing about it was that you couldn't use it

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:51.958
on the youngest children, on infants, and on one-year-olds.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
And so, as a consequence, a few years later,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
another scientist -- perhaps maybe this scientist

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
not quite as brilliant as the one who had preceded him,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
but building on the invention of the first one --

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
came up with a second cure.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
And the beauty of the second cure for this disease

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:11.958
was that it could be used on infants and one-year-olds.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:16.958
And the problem with this cure was it was very expensive,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:17.958
and it was very complicated to use.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And although parents tried as hard as they could to use it properly,

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
almost all of them ended up using it wrong in the end.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
But what they did, of course, since it was so complicated and expensive,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
they only used it on the zero-year-olds and the one-year-olds.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
And they kept on using the existing cure that they had

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:35.958
on the two-year-olds and up.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
And this went on for quite some time. People were happy.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
They had their two cures. Until a particular mother,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:45.958
whose child had just turned two, died of this disease.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:49.958
And she thought to herself, "My child just turned two,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:53.958
and until the child turned two, I had always used

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:58.958
this complicated, expensive cure, you know, this treatment.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:01:59.958
And then the child turned two, and I started using

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
the cheap and easy treatment, and I wonder" --

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
and she wondered, like all parents who lose children wonder --

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
"if there isn't something that I could have done,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
like keep on using that complicated, expensive cure."

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
And she told all the other people, and she said,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
"How could it possibly be that something

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
that's cheap and simple works as well as something

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
that's complicated and expensive?"

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And the people thought, "You know, you're right.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
It probably is the wrong thing to do to switch

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and use the cheap and simple solution."

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
And the government, they heard her story and the other people,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
and they said, "Yeah, you're right, we should make a law.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
We should outlaw this cheap and simple treatment

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
and not let anybody use this on their children."

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
And the people were happy. They were satisfied.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
For many years this went along, and everything was fine.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:48.958
But then along came a lowly economist, who had children himself,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:55.958
and he used the expensive and complicated treatment.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
But he knew about the cheap and simple one.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And he thought about it, and the expensive one

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
didn't seem that great to him. So he thought,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
"I don't know anything about science, but I do know something about data,

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
so maybe I should go and look at the data

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:11.958
and see whether this expensive and complicated treatment

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
actually works any better than the cheap and simple one."

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
And lo and behold, when he went through the data,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
he found that it didn't look like the expensive, complicated

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
solution was any better than the cheap one,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
at least for the children who were two and older --

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
the cheap one still didn't work on the kids who were younger.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:31.958
And so, he went forth to the people and he said,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
"I've made this wonderful finding:

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
it looks as if we could just use the cheap and simple solution,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
and by doing so we could save ourselves 300 million dollars a year,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
and we could spend that on our children in other ways."

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:45.958
And the parents were very unhappy, and they said,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
"This is a terrible thing, because how can the cheap and easy thing

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
be as good as the hard thing?" And the government was very upset.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And in particular, the people who made this expensive solution

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
were very upset because they thought,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
"How can we hope to compete with something that's essentially free?

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
We would lose all of our market."

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And people were very angry, and they called him horrible names.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And he decided that maybe he should leave the country

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:11.958
for a few days, and seek out some more intelligent,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
open-minded people in a place called Oxford,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
and come and try and tell the story at that place.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:21.958
And so, anyway, here I am. It's not a fairy tale.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
It's a true story about the United States today,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
and the disease I'm referring to is actually

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
motor vehicle accidents for children.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:35.958
And the free cure is adult seatbelts, and the expensive cure --

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
the 300-million-dollar-a-year cure -- is child car seats.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
And what I'd like to talk to you about today

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
is some of the evidence why I believe this to be true:

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
that for children two years old and up,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:51.958
there really is no real benefit -- proven benefit -- of car seats,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:56.958
in spite of the incredible energy

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
that has been devoted toward expanding the laws

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and making it socially unacceptable

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
to put your children into seatbelts. And then talk about why --

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:07.958
what is it that makes that true?

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And then, finally talk a little bit about a third way,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
about another technology, which is probably better than anything we have,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
but which -- there hasn't been any enthusiasm for adoption

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
precisely because people are so enamored

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
with the current car seat solution. OK.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
So, many times when you try to do research on data,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
it records complicated stories -- it's hard to find in the data.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
It doesn't turn out to be the case when you look at seatbelts versus car seats.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
So the United States keeps a data set

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
of every fatal accident that's happened since 1975.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
So in every car crash in which at least one person dies,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
they have information on all of the people.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
So if you look at that data -- it's right up on the National Highway

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Transportation Safety Administration's website --

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
you can just look at the raw data,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and begin to get a sense of the limited amount of evidence

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
that's in favor of car seats for children aged two and up.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
So, here is the data. Here I have, among two- to six-year-olds --

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
anyone above six, basically no one uses car seats,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:07.958
so you can't compare -- 29.3 percent of the children who are unrestrained

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
in a crash in which at least one person dies, themselves die.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:16.958
If you put a child in a car seat, 18.2 percent of the children die.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
If they're wearing a lap-and-shoulder belt, in this raw data,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:23.958
19.4 percent die. And interestingly, wearing a lap-only seatbelt,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
16.7 percent die. And actually, the theory tells you

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
that the lap-only seatbelt's got to be worse

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:29.958
than the lap-and-shoulder belt. And that just reminds you

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
that when you deal with raw data, there are hundreds

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
of confounding variables that may be getting in the way.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:39.958
So what we do in the study is -- and this is just presenting

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
the same information, but turned into a figure to make it easier.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
So the yellow bar represents car seats,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
the orange bar lap-and-shoulder, and the red bar lap-only seatbelts.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
And this is all relative to unrestrained --

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:52.958
the bigger the bar, the better. Okay.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
So, this is the data I just showed, OK?

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
So the highest bar is what you're striving to beat.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
So you can control for the basic things, like how hard the crash was,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
what seat the child was sitting in, etc., the age of the child.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
And that's that middle set of bars.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
And so, you can see that the lap-only seatbelts

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
start to look worse once you do that.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And then finally, the last set of bars,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
which are really controlling for everything

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
you could possibly imagine about the crash,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
50, 75, 100 different characteristics of the crash.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
And what you find is that the car seats and the lap-and-shoulder belts,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
when it comes to saving lives, fatalities look exactly identical.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And the standard error bands are relatively small around these estimates as well.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
And it's not just overall. It's very robust

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
to anything you want to look at.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
One thing that's interesting: if you look at frontal-impact crashes --

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
when the car crashes, the front hits into something --

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
indeed, what you see is that the car seats look a little bit better.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And I think this isn't just chance.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:51.958
In order to have the car seat approved,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
you need to pass certain federal standards,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:59.958
all of which involve slamming your car into a direct frontal crash.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
But when you look at other types of crashes, like rear-impact crashes,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
indeed, the car seats don't perform as well.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And I think that's because they've been optimized to pass,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
as we always expect people to do,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
to optimize relative to bright-line rules

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:14.958
about how affected the car will be.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:15.958
And the other thing you might argue is,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
"Well, car seats have got a lot better over time.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And so if we look at recent crashes --

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
the whole data set is almost 30 years' worth of data --

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
you won't see it in the recent crashes. The new car seats are far, far better."

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
But indeed, in recent crashes the lap-and-shoulder seatbelts,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
actually, are doing even better than the car seats.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
They say, "Well, that's impossible, that can't be."

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
And the line of argument, if you ask parents, is,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
"But car seats are so expensive and complicated,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and they have this big tangle of latches,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
how could they possibly not work better than seatbelts

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
because they are so expensive and complicated?"

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
It's kind of an interesting logic,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
I think, that people use. And the other logic, they say,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
"Well, the government wouldn't have told us [to] use them

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
if they weren't much better."

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
But what's interesting is the government telling us to use them

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
is not actually based on very much.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
It really is based on some impassioned pleas of parents

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
whose children died after they turned two,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
which has led to the passage of all these laws -- not very much on data.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
So you can only get so far, I think, in telling your story

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
by using these abstract statistics.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And so I had some friends over to dinner, and I was asking --

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
we had a cookout -- I was asking them what advice they might have for me

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
about proving my point. They said, "Why don't you run some crash tests?"

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And I said, "That's a great idea."

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
So we actually tried to commission some crash tests.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
And it turns out that as we called around to the independent

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
crash test companies around the country,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
none of them wanted to do our crash test

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
because they said, some explicitly, some not so explicitly,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
"All of our business comes from car seat manufacturers.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
We can't risk alienating them by testing seatbelts relative to car seats."

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Now, eventually, one did. Under the conditions of anonymity,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
they said they would be happy to do this test for us --

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:05.958
so anonymity, and 1,500 dollars per seat that we crashed.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
And so, we went to Buffalo, New York,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
and here is the precursor to it.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
These are the crash test dummies,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
waiting for their chance to take the center stage.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
And then, here's how the crash test works.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
Here, they don't actually crash the entire car, you know --

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
it's not worth ruining a whole car to do it.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:23.958
So they just have these bench seats,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and they strap the car seat and the seatbelt onto it.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
So I just wanted you to look at this.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
And I think this gives you a good idea of why parents think

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
car seats are so great. Look at the kid in the car seat.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
Does he not look content, ready to go,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
like he could survive anything? And then, if you look at the kid in back,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
it looks like he's already choking before the crash even happens.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
It's hard to believe, when you look at this, that

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
that kid in back is going to do very well when you get in a crash.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
So this is going to be a crash

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
where they're going to slam this thing forward into a wall

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
at 30 miles an hour, and see what happens. OK?

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
So, let me show you what happens.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
These are three-year-old dummies, by the way.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
So here -- this is the car seat. Now watch two things:

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
watch how the head goes forward,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
and basically hits the knees -- and this is in the car seat --

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and watch how the car seat flies around, in the rebound, up in the air.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
The car seat's moving all over the place.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Bear in mind there are two things about this.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
This is a car seat that was installed by someone

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
who has installed 1,000 car seats, who knew exactly how to do it.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:19.958
And also it turned out these bench seats

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
are the very best way to install car seats.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Having a flat back makes it much easier to install them.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And so this is a test that's very much rigged in favor of the car seat,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
OK? So, that kid in this crash fared very well.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
The federal standards are

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
that you have to score below a 1,000

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
to be an approved car seat on this crash,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:41.958
in some metric of units which are not important.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And this crash would have been about a 450.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
So this car seat was actually an above-average car seat

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
from Consumer Reports, and did quite well.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So the next one. Now, this is the kid, same crash,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:56.958
who is in the seatbelt. He hardly moves at all, actually,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
relative to the other child. The funny thing is,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
the cam work is terrible because they've only set it up

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
to do the car seats, and so, they actually don't even have a way

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
to move the camera so you can see the kid that's on the rebound.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
Anyway, it turns out that those two crashes, that actually

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
the three-year-old did slightly worse. So, he gets about a 500

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.958
out of -- you know, on this range -- relative to a 400 and something.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
But still, if you just took that data from that crash

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
to the federal government, and said, "I have invented a new car seat.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
I would like you to approve it for selling,"

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
then they would say, "This is a fantastic new car seat, it works great.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
It only got a 500, it could have gotten as high up as a 1,000."

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
And this seatbelt would have passed with flying colors

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
into being approved as a car seat.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
So, in some sense, what this is suggesting

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
is that it's not just that people are setting up their car seats wrong,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
which is putting children at risk. It's just that, fundamentally,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
the car seats aren't doing much.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
So here's the crash. So these are timed at the same time,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
so you can see that it takes much longer with the car seat --

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
at rebound, it takes a lot longer --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
but there's just a lot less movement for child who's in the seatbelt.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
So, I'll show you the six-year-old crashes as well.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:03.958
The six-year-old is in a car seat, and it turns out

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
that looks terrible, but that's great. That's like a 400, OK?

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:09.958
So that kid would do fine in the crash.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Nothing about that would have been problematic to the child at all.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And then here's the six-year-old in the seatbelt,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
and in fact, they get exactly within, you know,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
within one or two points of the same. So really, for the six-year-old,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
the car seat did absolutely nothing whatsoever.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
That's some more evidence, so in some sense --

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
I was criticized by a scientist, who said, "You could never publish

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
a study with an n of 4," meaning those four crashes.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:39.958
So I wrote him back and I said, "What about an n of 45,004?"

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Because I had the other 45,000 other real-world crashes.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And I just think that it's interesting that the idea

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
of using real-world crashes, which is very much something

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
that economists think would be the right thing to do,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
is something that scientists don't actually, usually think --

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
they would rather use a laboratory,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
a very imperfect science of looking at the dummies,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
than actually 30 years of data of what we've seen

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
with children and with car seats.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
And so I think the answer to this puzzle

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
is that there's a much better solution out there,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
that's gotten nobody excited because everyone

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
is so delighted with the way car seats are presumably working.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And if you think from a design perspective,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
about going back to square one, and say,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
"I just want to protect kids in the back seat."

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
I don't there's anyone in this room who'd say,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:27.958
"Well, the right way to start would be,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
let's make a great seat belt for adults.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
And then, let's make this really big contraption

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
that you have to rig up to it in this daisy chain."

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
I mean, why not start -- who's sitting in the back seat anyway except for kids?

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
But essentially, do something like this,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
which I don't know exactly how much it would cost to do,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:44.958
but there's no reason I could see

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
why this should be much more expensive than a regular car seat.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
It's just actually -- you see, this is folding up -- it's behind the seat.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
You've got a regular seat for adults, and then you fold it down,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
and the kid sits on top, and it's integrated.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
It seems to me that this can't be a very expensive solution,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
and it's got to work better than what we already have.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:06.958
So the question is, is there any hope for adoption of something like this,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
which would presumably save a lot of lives?

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
And I think the answer, perhaps, lies in a story.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
The answer both to why has a car seat been so successful,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
and why this may someday be adopted or not,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
lies in a story that my dad told me, relating to when he was a doctor

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
in the U.S. Air Force in England. And this is a long time ago:

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
you were allowed to do things then you can't do today.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:32.958
So, my father would have patients come in

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
who he thought were not really sick.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:39.958
And he had a big jar full of placebo pills that he would give them,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and he'd say, "Come back in a week, if you still feel lousy."

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:43.958
OK, and most of them would not come back,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
but some of them would come back.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
And when they came back, he, still convinced they were not sick,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:54.958
had another jar of pills. In this jar were huge horse pills.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
They were almost impossible to swallow.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
And these, to me, are the analogy for the car seats.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
People would look at these and say, "Man, this thing is so big

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
and so hard to swallow. If this doesn't make me feel better,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
you know, what possibly could?"

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
And it turned out that most people wouldn't come back,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
because it worked. But every once in a while,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:19.958
there was still a patient convinced that he was sick,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
and he'd come back. And my dad had a third jar of pills.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
And the jar of pills he had, he said,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
were the tiniest little pills he could find,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
so small you could barely see them.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
And he would say, listen, I know I gave you that huge pill,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.958
that complicated, hard-to-swallow pill before,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
but now I've got one that's so potent,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
that is really tiny and small and almost invisible.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
It's almost like this thing here, which you can't even see."

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
And it turned out that never,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
in all the times my dad gave out this pill, the really tiny pill,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
did anyone ever come back still complaining of sickness.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
So, my dad always took that as evidence

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
that this little, teeny, powerful pill

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
had the ultimate placebo effect. And in some sense, if that's the right story,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
I think integrated car seats you will see, very quickly,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:07.958
becoming something that everyone has. The other possible conclusion

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
is, well, maybe after coming to my father three times,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
getting sent home with placebos, he still felt sick,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
he went and found another doctor.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
And that's completely possible. And if that's the case,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
then I think we're stuck with conventional car seats for a long time to come.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
(Applause)

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
(Audience: I just wanted to ask you, when we wear seatbelts

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
we don't necessarily wear them just to prevent loss of life,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
it's also to prevent lots of serious injury.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:35.958
Your data looks at fatalities. It doesn't look at serious injury.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
Is there any data to show that child seats

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
are actually less effective, or just as effective as seatbelts

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
for serious injury? Because that would prove your case.)

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
Steven Levitt: Yeah, that's a great question. In my data, and in another data set

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
