title: The story of a girl
transcript: Some of you have heard the story before, but, in fact, there's somebody in the audience who's never heard this story in front of an audience before, so I'm a little more nervous than I normally am telling this story. I used to be a photographer for many years. In 1978, I was working for "TIME Magazine" and I was given a three-day assignment to photograph Amerasian children, children who had been fathered by American GIs all over Southeast Asia, and then abandoned — 40,000 children all over Asia. I had never heard the word Amerasian before. I spent a few days photographing children in different countries, and like a lot of photographers and a lot of journalists, I always hoped that when my pictures are published, they might actually have an effect on a situation, instead of just documenting it.So, I was so disturbed by what I saw and I was so unhappy with the article that ran afterwards, that I decided I would take six months off. I was 28 years old. I decided I would find six children in different countries, and actually go spend some time with the kids, and try to tell their story a little bit better than I thought I had done for Time magazine. In the course of doing the story, I was looking for children who hadn't been photographed before, and the Pearl Buck Foundation told me that they worked with a lot of Americans who were donating money to help some of these kids. And a man told me, who ran the Pearl Buck Foundation in Korea, that there was a young girl, who was 11 years old, being raised by her grandmother. And the grandmother had never let any Westerners see her. Every time any Westerners came to the village, she hid the girl. Of course, I was immediately intrigued. I saw photographs of her and I thought I wanted to go. And the guy just told me, "This grandmother — there's no way she's ever going to let you meet this girl that's she's raising."I took a translator with me and went to this village, found the grandmother, sat down with her. And to my astonishment, she agreed to let me photograph her granddaughter. And I was paying for this myself, so I asked the translator if it would be OK if I stayed for the week. I had a sleeping bag. The family had a small shed on the side of the house, so I said, "Could I sleep in my sleeping bag in the evenings?" And I just told the little girl, whose name was Eun-Sook Lee, that if I ever did anything to embarrass her — she didn't speak a word of English, although she looked very American — she could put up her hand and say, "Stop," and I would stop taking pictures. Then my translator left. I couldn't speak a word of Korean. This is the first night I met Eun-Sook. Her mother was still alive. She was not raising her, her grandmother was raising her. And what struck me immediately was how in love the two of these people were. The grandmother was incredibly fond, deeply in love with this little girl. They slept on the floor at night. The way they heat their homes in Korea is to put bricks under the floors, so the heat radiates from underneath the floor. Eun-Sook was 11 years old.I had photographed, as I said, a lot of these kids. Eun-Sook was the fifth child that I found to photograph. And almost universally, amongst all the kids, they were really psychologically damaged by having been made fun of, ridiculed, picked on and been rejected. And Korea was probably the place I found to be the worst for these kids. And what struck me immediately in meeting Eun-Sook was how confident she appeared to be, how happy she seemed to be in her own skin. And remember this picture, because I'm going to show you another picture later. She looks much like her grandmother, although she looks so Western.I decided to follow her to school. This is the first morning I stayed with her. This is on the way to school. This is the morning assembly outside her school. And I noticed that she was clowning around. When the teachers would ask questions, she'd be the first person to raise her hand. Again, not at all shy or withdrawn, or anything like the other children that I'd photographed. The first one to go to the blackboard to answer questions. Getting in trouble for whispering into her best friend's ears. And one of the other things I said to her through the translator — again, this thing about saying stop — was to not pay attention to me. So she really just completely ignored me most of the time. I noticed that at recess, she was the girl who picked the other girls to be on her team. It was very obvious, from the beginning, that she was a leader. This is on the way home. And that's North Korea up along the hill. This is up along the DMZ. They would actually cover the windows every night, so that light couldn't be seen, because the South Korean government has said for years that the North Koreans may invade at any time. So the closer you were to North Korea, the more terrifying it was.Very often at school, I'd be taking pictures, and she would whisper into her girlfriends' ears, and then look at me and say, "Stop." And I would stand at attention, and all the girls would crack up, and it was sort of a little joke.(Laughter)The end of the week came and my translator came back, because I'd asked her to come back, so I could formally thank the grandmother and Eun-Sook. And in the course of the grandmother talking to the translator, the grandmother started crying. And I said to my translator, "What's going on, why is she crying?" And she spoke to the grandmother for a moment, and then she started getting tears in her eyes. And I said, "What did I do? Why is everyone crying?" And the translator said, "The grandmother says that she thinks she's dying, and she wants to know if you would take Eun-Sook to America with you." And I said, "I'm 28 years old and I live in hotels, and I'm not married." I mean, I had fallen in love with this girl, but you know, emotionally I was about 12 years old. If you know of photographers, the joke is it's the finest form of delayed adolescence ever invented. "Sorry, I have to go on an assignment, I'll be back" — and then you never come back.So I asked the translator why she thought she was dying. Can I get her to a hospital? Could I pay to get her a doctor? And she refused any help at all. So when I got outside, I gave the translator some money and said, "Go back and see if you can do something." And I gave the grandmother my business card. And I said, "If you're serious, I will try to find a family for her." And I immediately wrote a letter to my best friends in Atlanta, Georgia, who had an 11-year-old son. And my best friend had mistakenly one day said something about wishing he had another child. So my friends Gene and Gayle had not heard from me in about a year, and suddenly I was calling, saying "I'm in Korea and I've met this extraordinary girl." And I said, "The grandmother thinks she's sick, but I think maybe we would have to bring the grandmother over also." And I said, "I'll pay for the ... " I mean, I had this whole sort of picture. So anyway, I left. And my friends actually said they were very interested in adopting her. And I said, "Look, I think I'll scare the grandmother to death, if I tell her that you're willing to adopt her. I want to go back and talk to her." But I was off on assignment. I figured I'd come back in a couple of weeks and talk to the grandmother.And on Christmas Day, I was in Bangkok with a group of photographers and got a telegram — back in those days, you got telegrams — from Time magazine saying someone in Korea had died and left their child in a will to me. Did I know anything about this? Because I hadn't told them what I was doing, because I was so upset with the story they'd run. So, I went back to Korea, and I went back to Eun-Sook's village, and she was gone. And the house that I had spent time in was empty. It was incredibly cold. No one in the village would tell me where Eun-Sook was, because the grandmother had always hidden her from Westerners. And they had no idea about this request that she'd made of me. So I finally found Myung Sung, her best friend that she used to play with after school every day. And Myung Sung, under some pressure from me and the translator, gave us an address on the outside of Seoul. And I went to that address and knocked on the door, and a man answered the door. It was not a very nice area of Seoul, there were mud streets outside of it. And I knocked on the door and Eun-Sook answered the door, and her eyes were bloodshot, and she seemed to be in shock. She didn't recognize me — there was no recognition whatsoever. And this man came to the door and kind of barked something in Korean. And I said to the translator, "What did he say?" And she said, "He wants to know who you are." And I said, "Tell him that I am a photographer." I started explaining who I was, and he interrupted. And she said, "He says he knows who you are, what do you want?" I said, "Well, tell him that I was asked by this little girl's grandmother to find a family for her." And he said, "I'm her uncle, she's fine, you can leave now."So I was — The door was being slammed in my face, it's incredibly cold, and I'm trying to think, "What would the hero do in a movie, if I was writing this as a movie script?" So I said, "It's really cold, I've come a very long way, do you mind if I come in for a minute? I'm freezing." So the guy reluctantly let us in and we sat down on the floor. And as we started talking, I saw him yell something, and Eun-Sook came and brought us some food. And I had this whole mental picture of — sort of like Cinderella. I sort of had this picture of this incredibly wonderful, bright, happy little child, who now appeared to be very withdrawn, being enslaved by this family. And I was really appalled, and I couldn't figure out what to do. And the more I tried talking to him, the less friendly he was getting. So finally I said "Look," — this is all through the translator, because, you know, I don't speak a word of Korean — and I said, "Look, I'm really glad that Eun-Sook has a family to live with. I was very worried about her. I made a promise to her grandmother, your mother, that I would find a family, and I'm so happy that you're going to take care of her. But I bought an airline ticket and I'm stuck here for a week. I'm staying in a hotel downtown. Would you like to come and have lunch tomorrow? And you can practice your English." Because he told me — I was trying to ask him questions about himself.And so I went to the hotel, and I found two older Amerasians. A girl whose mother had been a prostitute, and she was a prostitute, and a boy who'd been in and out of jail. And I said to them, "Look, there's a little girl who has a tiny chance of getting out of here and going to America. I don't know if it's the right decision or not, but I would like you to come to lunch tomorrow and tell the uncle what it's like to walk down the street, what people say to you, what you do for a living. I want him to understand what happens if she stays here. And I could be wrong, I don't know, but I wish you would come tomorrow."So, these two came to lunch and we got thrown out of the restaurant. They were yelling at him, it got to be really ugly. We went outside, and he was just furious. And I knew I had totally blown this thing. Here I was again, trying to figure out what to do. And he started yelling at me, and I said to the translator, "Tell him to calm down, what is he saying?" And she said, "He's saying, 'Who the hell are you to walk into my house, some rich American with your cameras around your neck, accusing me of enslaving my niece? This is my niece, I love her, she's my sister's daughter. Who the hell are you to accuse me of something like this?'" And I said, you know, "Look, you're absolutely right. I don't pretend to understand what's going on here. All I know is, I've been photographing a lot of these children. I'm in love with your niece, I think she's an incredibly special child." And I said, "Look, I will fly my friends over here from the United States if you want to meet them, to see if you approve of them. I just think that — what little I know about the situation, she has very little chance here of having the kind of life that you probably would like her to have."So, everyone told me afterwards that inviting the prospective parents over was, again, the stupidest thing I could have possibly done, because who's ever good enough for your relative? But he invited me to come to a ceremony they were having that day for her grandmother. And they actually take items of clothing and photographs, and they burn them as part of the ritual. And you can see how different she looks just in three months. This was now, I think, early February. And the pictures before were taken in September. Well, there was an American Maryknoll priest that I had met in the course of doing the story, who had 75 children living in his house. He had three women helping him take care of these kids. And so I suggested to the uncle that we go down and meet Father Keane to find out how the adoption process worked. Because I wanted him to feel like this was all being done very much above board.So, this is on the way down to the orphanage. This is Father Keane. He's just a wonderful guy. He had kids from all over Korea living there, and he would find families for these kids. This is a social worker interviewing Eun-Sook. Now, I had always thought she was completely untouched by all of this, because the grandmother, to me, appeared to be sort of the village wise woman — throughout the day, I noticed people kept coming to visit her grandmother. And I always had this mental picture that even though they may have been one of the poorer families in the village, they were one of the most respected. And I always felt that the grandmother had kind of demanded, and insisted, that the villagers treat Eun-Sook with the same respect they treated her. Eun-Sook stayed at Father Keane's, and her uncle agreed to let her stay there until the adoption went through. He actually agreed to the adoption.And I went off on assignment and came back a week later, and Father Keane said, "I've got to talk to you about Eun-Sook." I said, "Oh God, now what?" And he takes me into this room, closes the door and says, "I have 75 children here in the orphanage, and it's total bedlam." There's clothes, there's kids. Three adults and 75 kids — you can imagine. And he said, "The second day she was here she made up a list of all of the names of the older kids and the younger kids. And she assigned one of the older kids to each of the younger kids. And then she set up a work detail list of who cleaned the orphanage on what day." And he said, "She's telling me that I'm messy and I have to clean up my room." And he said, "I don't know who raised her, but she's running the orphanage, and she's been here three days."(Laughter)This was movie day that she organized where all the kids went to the movies. A lot of the kids who had been adopted wrote back to the other kids, telling them what their life was like with their new families. So it was a really big deal when the letters showed up. This is a woman who is now working at the orphanage, whose son had been adopted. Gene and Gayle started studying Korean the moment they had gotten my first letter. They really wanted to be able to welcome Eun-Sook into their family. And one of the things Father Keane told me when I came back from one of these trips — Eun-Sook had chosen the name Natasha, which I understood was from her watching a "Rocky and Bullwinkle" cartoon on the American Air Force station. This may be one of those myth-buster things that we'll have to clear up here, in a minute.So, my friend Gene flew over with his son, Tim. Gayle couldn't come. And they spent a lot of time huddled over a dictionary. And this was Gene showing the uncle where Atlanta was on the map, where he lived. This is the uncle signing the adoption papers. Now, we went out to dinner that night to celebrate. The uncle went back to his family and Natasha and Tim and Gene and I went out to dinner. And Gene was showing Natasha how to use a knife and fork, and then Natasha was returning the utensil lessons. We went back to our hotel room, and Gene was showing Natasha also where Atlanta was. This is the third night we were in Korea. The first night we'd gotten a room for the kids right next to us.I'd been staying in this room for about three months — it was a little 15-story Korean hotel. The second night, we didn't keep the kids' room, because we slept on the floor with all the kids at the orphanage. And the third night, we came back — we'd just gone out to dinner, where you saw the pictures — and we got to the front desk, and the guy said, "There's no other free rooms on your floor tonight, you can put the kids five floors below you." And Gene and I looked at each other and said, "We don't want two 11-year-olds five floors away." So his son said, "I have a sleeping bag, I'll sleep on the floor." And I said, "I have one too." So Tim and I slept on the floor, Natasha got one bed, Gene got the other — kids pass out, it's been very exciting for three days.We're lying in bed, and Gene and I are talking about how cool we are. We said, "That was so great, we saved this little girl's life." We were just like, you know, just full of ourselves. And we fall asleep — and I've been in this room for a couple of months now. And they always overheat the hotels in Korea terribly, so during the day I always left the window open. And then about midnight, they turn the heat off in the hotel. So at 1am, the whole room would be like 20 below zero, and I'd get up. I'd been doing this every night I'd been there. So, sure enough, it's one o'clock, room's freezing, I go to close the window and I hear people shouting outside, and I thought, "Oh, the bars must have just gotten out." I don't speak Korean, but I'm hearing these voices, and I'm not hearing anger, I'm hearing terror. So I open the window and I look out, and there's flames coming up the side of our hotel, and the hotel's on fire. So I run over to Gene and I wake him up, and I say, "Don't freak out, I think the hotel's on fire." And now there's smoke and flames coming by our windows — we're on the 11th floor. So the two of us were just like, "Oh my God, oh my God."So we're trying to get Natasha up, and we can't talk to her. You know what kids are like when they've been asleep for like an hour, it's like they took five Valiums — they're all over the place. And we can't talk to her. His son had the L.L.Bean bootlaces, and we're trying to do up his laces. So we try to get to the door, we run to the door, we open the door, and it's like walking into a blast furnace. There's people screaming, the sound of glass breaking, weird thumps. And the whole room filled with smoke in about two seconds. And Gene turns around and says, "We're not going to make it." And he closes the door, and the whole room is now filled with smoke. We're all choking, and there's smoke pouring through the vents, under the doors. There's people screaming. I just remember this unbelievable — just utter chaos.I remember sitting near the bed, and I had two overwhelming feelings. One was absolute terror. "Oh, please God, I just want to wake up. This has got to be a nightmare, this can't be happening. Please, I just want to wake up." And the other is unbelievable guilt. Here I've been playing God with my friends' lives, my friends' son, with Natasha's life, and this what you get when you try playing God, is you hurt people. I remember just being so frightened and terrified. And Gene, who's lying on the floor, says, "We've got to soak towels." I said, "What?" "We've got to soak towels. We're going to die from the smoke." So got towels and put them over our faces and the kids' faces. Then he said, "Do you have gaffer's tape?" "What?" "Do you have gaffer's tape?" I said, "Somewhere in my Halliburton." He says, "We've got to stop the smoke. That's all we can do." I mean, Gene — thank God for Gene. So we put the room service menus over the vents in the wall, we put blankets at the bottom of the door, we put the kids on the windowsill to try to get some air. And there was a new building, going up, that was being built right across the street from our hotel. And there, in the building, were photographers, waiting for people to jump. Eleven people ended up dying in the fire. Five people jumped and died, other people were killed by the smoke. And there's this loud thumping on the door after about 45 minutes in all this, and people were shouting in Korean. And I remember — Natasha didn't want us opening the door — sorry, I was trying not to open the door, because we'd spent so much time barricading the room. I didn't know who it was, I didn't know what they wanted, and Natasha could tell they were firemen trying to get us out. I remember a sort of a tussle at the door, trying to get the door open.In any case, 12 hours later — I mean, they put us in the lobby. Gene ended up using his coat, and his fist in the coat, to break open a liquor cabinet. People were lying on the floor. It was one of just the most horrifying nights. And then 12 hours later, we rented a car, as we had planned to, and drove back to Natasha's village. And we kept saying, "Do you realize we were dying in a hotel fire, like eight hours ago?" It's so weird how life just goes on. Natasha wanted to introduce her brother and father to all the villagers, and the day we showed up turned out to be a 60-year-old man's birthday. This guy's 60 years old. So it turned into a dual celebration, because Natasha was the first person from this village ever to go to the United States. So, these are the greenhouse tents. This is the elders teaching Gene their dances. We drank a lot of rice wine. We were both so drunk, I couldn't believe it.This is the last picture before Gene and Tim headed back. The adoption people told us it was going to take a year for the adoption to go through. Like, what could you do for a year? So I found out the name of every official on both the Korean and American side, and I photographed them, and told them how famous they were going to be when this book was done. And four months later, the adoption papers came through. This is saying goodbye to everybody at the orphanage. This is Father Keane with Natasha at the bus stop. Her great aunt at the airport. I had a wonderful deal with Cathay Pacific airlines for many years, where they gave me free passes on all their airlines in return for photography. It was like the ultimate perk. And the pilot, I actually knew — because they used to let me sit in the jump seat, to tell you how long ago this was. This is a TriStar, and so they let Natasha actually sit in the jump seat. And the pilot, Jeff Cowley, actually went back and adopted one of the other kids at the orphanage after meeting Natasha.This is 28 hours later in Atlanta. It's a very long flight. Just to make things even crazier, Gayle, Natasha's new mom, was three days away from giving birth to her own daughter. You know, if you were writing this, you'd say, "No, we've got to write the script differently." This is the first night showing Natasha her new cousins and uncles and aunts. Gene and Gayle know everyone in Atlanta — they're the most social couple imaginable. So, at this point, Natasha doesn't speak a word of English, other than what little Father Keane taught her. This is Kylie, her sister, who's now a doctor, on the right. This is a deal I had with Natasha, which is that when we got to Atlanta she could cut off my beard. She never liked it very much.She learned English in three months. She entered seventh grade at her own age level. Pledge of Allegiance for the first time. This is her cooking teacher. Natasha told me a lot of the kids thought she was stuck up, because they would talk to her and she wouldn't answer, and they didn't realize she didn't speak English very well. But what I noticed, again as an observer, was she was choosing who was going to be on her team, and seemed to be very popular very, very quickly. Now, remember the picture, how much she looked like her grandmother, at the beginning? People were always telling Natasha how much she looks like her mother, Gayle.(Laughter)This is a tense moment in the first football game, I think. And Kylie — I mean, it was almost like Kylie was her own child. She's being baptized. Now, a lot of parents, when they adopt, actually want to erase their children's history. And Gayle and Gene did the complete opposite. They were studying Korean; they bought Korean clothes. Gene even did a little tile work in the kitchen, which was that, "Once upon a time, there was a beautiful girl that came from the hills of Korea to live happily ever after in Atlanta."She hates this picture — it was her first job. She bought a bright red Karmann Ghia with the money she made working at Burger King. The captain of the cheerleaders. Beauty pageant. Used to do their Christmas card every year. Gene's been restoring this car for a million years.Kodak hired Natasha to be a translator for them at the Olympics in Korea. Her future husband, Jeff, was working for Canon cameras, and met Natasha at the Olympic Village. This is her first trip back to Korea. So there's her uncle. This is her half sister. She went back to the village. That's her best friend's mother. And I always thought that was a very Annie Hall kind of outfit.(Laughter)It's just, you know, it was just so interesting, just to watch — this is her mother in the background there. This is Natasha's wedding day. Gene is looking a little older. This is Sydney, who's going to be three years old in a couple of days. And there's Evan.And Natasha, would you just come up, for a second, just maybe to say hello to everybody?(Applause)Natasha's actually never heard me tell the story. You know, we've looked at the pictures together.Natasha: I've seen pictures millions of times, but today was the first time I'm actually seeing him give the whole presentation. I started crying.Rick Smolan: There's about 40 things she's going to tell me, "That wasn't what happened." Natasha: I'll tell you that later.RS: Anyway, thank you, Mike and Richard, so much for letting us tell the story.Thank you, all of you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.894
Some of you have heard the story before,

00:00:13.918 --> 00:00:16.094
but, in fact, there's somebody
in the audience

00:00:16.118 --> 00:00:18.974
who's never heard this story
in front of an audience before,

00:00:18.998 --> 00:00:22.734
so I'm a little more nervous
than I normally am telling this story.

00:00:22.758 --> 00:00:24.854
I used to be a photographer
for many years.

00:00:24.878 --> 00:00:27.734
In 1978, I was working for "TIME Magazine"

00:00:27.758 --> 00:00:31.894
and I was given a three-day assignment
to photograph Amerasian children,

00:00:31.918 --> 00:00:35.254
children who had been fathered
by American GIs all over Southeast Asia,

00:00:35.278 --> 00:00:38.614
and then abandoned --
40,000 children all over Asia.

00:00:38.638 --> 00:00:40.718
I had never heard
the word Amerasian before.

00:00:41.478 --> 00:00:45.014
I spent a few days photographing
children in different countries,

00:00:45.038 --> 00:00:48.294
and like a lot of photographers
and a lot of journalists,

00:00:48.318 --> 00:00:50.774
I always hoped that
when my pictures are published,

00:00:50.798 --> 00:00:53.174
they might actually
have an effect on a situation,

00:00:53.198 --> 00:00:54.734
instead of just documenting it.

00:00:54.758 --> 00:00:59.014
So, I was so disturbed by what I saw

00:00:59.038 --> 00:01:03.134
and I was so unhappy
with the article that ran afterwards,

00:01:03.158 --> 00:01:05.614
that I decided
I would take six months off.

00:01:05.638 --> 00:01:07.054
I was 28 years old.

00:01:07.078 --> 00:01:10.814
I decided I would find
six children in different countries,

00:01:10.838 --> 00:01:13.014
and actually go spend
some time with the kids,

00:01:13.038 --> 00:01:15.254
and try to tell their story
a little bit better

00:01:15.278 --> 00:01:17.438
than I thought I had done
for Time magazine.

00:01:18.278 --> 00:01:19.894
In the course of doing the story,

00:01:19.918 --> 00:01:25.574
I was looking for children
who hadn't been photographed before,

00:01:25.598 --> 00:01:30.534
and the Pearl Buck Foundation told me
that they worked with a lot of Americans

00:01:30.558 --> 00:01:32.974
who were donating money
to help some of these kids.

00:01:32.998 --> 00:01:34.254
And a man told me,

00:01:34.278 --> 00:01:36.934
who ran the Pearl Buck
Foundation in Korea,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.334
that there was a young girl,
who was 11 years old,

00:01:39.358 --> 00:01:40.934
being raised by her grandmother.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.654
And the grandmother
had never let any Westerners see her.

00:01:43.678 --> 00:01:46.734
Every time any Westerners
came to the village, she hid the girl.

00:01:46.758 --> 00:01:48.654
Of course, I was immediately intrigued.

00:01:48.678 --> 00:01:51.254
I saw photographs of her
and I thought I wanted to go.

00:01:51.278 --> 00:01:52.534
And the guy just told me,

00:01:52.558 --> 00:01:55.534
"This grandmother -- there's no way
she's ever going to let you

00:01:55.558 --> 00:01:57.374
meet this girl that's she's raising."

00:01:57.398 --> 00:01:59.894
I took a translator with me
and went to this village,

00:01:59.918 --> 00:02:01.894
found the grandmother, sat down with her.

00:02:01.918 --> 00:02:05.414
And to my astonishment, she agreed
to let me photograph her granddaughter.

00:02:05.438 --> 00:02:08.254
And I was paying for this myself,
so I asked the translator

00:02:08.278 --> 00:02:10.294
if it would be OK
if I stayed for the week.

00:02:10.318 --> 00:02:11.934
I had a sleeping bag.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.654
The family had a small shed
on the side of the house,

00:02:14.678 --> 00:02:17.854
so I said, "Could I sleep
in my sleeping bag in the evenings?"

00:02:17.878 --> 00:02:22.814
And I just told the little girl,
whose name was Eun-Sook Lee,

00:02:22.838 --> 00:02:25.054
that if I ever did anything
to embarrass her --

00:02:25.078 --> 00:02:28.494
she didn't speak a word of English,
although she looked very American --

00:02:28.518 --> 00:02:32.094
she could put up her hand and say, "Stop,"
and I would stop taking pictures.

00:02:32.118 --> 00:02:34.934
Then my translator left.
I couldn't speak a word of Korean.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.894
This is the first night I met Eun-Sook.

00:02:36.918 --> 00:02:38.254
Her mother was still alive.

00:02:38.278 --> 00:02:40.974
She was not raising her,
her grandmother was raising her.

00:02:40.998 --> 00:02:43.294
And what struck me immediately

00:02:43.318 --> 00:02:46.774
was how in love
the two of these people were.

00:02:46.798 --> 00:02:51.014
The grandmother was incredibly fond,
deeply in love with this little girl.

00:02:51.038 --> 00:02:52.654
They slept on the floor at night.

00:02:52.678 --> 00:02:56.134
The way they heat their homes in Korea
is to put bricks under the floors,

00:02:56.158 --> 00:02:58.374
so the heat radiates
from underneath the floor.

00:02:58.398 --> 00:02:59.734
Eun-Sook was 11 years old.

00:02:59.758 --> 00:03:02.174
I had photographed,
as I said, a lot of these kids.

00:03:02.198 --> 00:03:05.174
Eun-Sook was the fifth child
that I found to photograph.

00:03:05.198 --> 00:03:07.734
And almost universally,
amongst all the kids,

00:03:07.758 --> 00:03:10.454
they were really psychologically damaged

00:03:10.478 --> 00:03:14.294
by having been made fun of,
ridiculed, picked on and been rejected.

00:03:14.318 --> 00:03:18.094
And Korea was probably the place
I found to be the worst for these kids.

00:03:18.118 --> 00:03:21.294
And what struck me immediately
in meeting Eun-Sook

00:03:21.318 --> 00:03:23.134
was how confident she appeared to be,

00:03:23.158 --> 00:03:25.374
how happy she seemed to be
in her own skin.

00:03:25.398 --> 00:03:26.654
And remember this picture,

00:03:26.678 --> 00:03:29.134
because I'm going to show you
another picture later.

00:03:29.158 --> 00:03:32.334
She looks much like her grandmother,
although she looks so Western.

00:03:32.358 --> 00:03:34.014
I decided to follow her to school.

00:03:34.038 --> 00:03:36.134
This is the first morning
I stayed with her.

00:03:36.158 --> 00:03:37.574
This is on the way to school.

00:03:37.598 --> 00:03:40.038
This is the morning assembly
outside her school.

00:03:43.798 --> 00:03:47.294
And I noticed that
she was clowning around.

00:03:47.318 --> 00:03:49.174
When the teachers would ask questions,

00:03:49.198 --> 00:03:51.614
she'd be the first person
to raise her hand.

00:03:51.638 --> 00:03:53.574
Again, not at all shy or withdrawn,

00:03:53.598 --> 00:03:56.334
or anything like the other children
that I'd photographed.

00:03:56.358 --> 00:03:59.094
The first one to go
to the blackboard to answer questions.

00:03:59.118 --> 00:04:02.054
Getting in trouble for whispering
into her best friend's ears.

00:04:02.078 --> 00:04:05.254
And one of the other things
I said to her through the translator --

00:04:05.278 --> 00:04:09.854
again, this thing about saying stop --
was to not pay attention to me.

00:04:09.878 --> 00:04:12.694
So she really just completely
ignored me most of the time.

00:04:12.718 --> 00:04:13.934
I noticed that at recess,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.774
she was the girl who picked
the other girls to be on her team.

00:04:17.798 --> 00:04:20.774
It was very obvious, from the beginning,
that she was a leader.

00:04:20.798 --> 00:04:23.934
This is on the way home.
And that's North Korea up along the hill.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.174
This is up along the DMZ.

00:04:25.198 --> 00:04:27.574
They would actually
cover the windows every night,

00:04:27.598 --> 00:04:29.134
so that light couldn't be seen,

00:04:29.158 --> 00:04:31.694
because the South Korean government
has said for years

00:04:31.718 --> 00:04:33.893
that the North Koreans
may invade at any time.

00:04:33.917 --> 00:04:37.214
So the closer you were to North Korea,
the more terrifying it was.

00:04:37.238 --> 00:04:39.534
Very often at school,
I'd be taking pictures,

00:04:39.558 --> 00:04:41.894
and she would whisper
into her girlfriends' ears,

00:04:41.918 --> 00:04:43.734
and then look at me and say, "Stop."

00:04:43.758 --> 00:04:46.814
And I would stand at attention,
and all the girls would crack up,

00:04:46.838 --> 00:04:48.454
and it was sort of a little joke.

00:04:48.478 --> 00:04:49.854
(Laughter)

00:04:49.878 --> 00:04:52.374
The end of the week came
and my translator came back,

00:04:52.398 --> 00:04:54.094
because I'd asked her to come back,

00:04:54.118 --> 00:04:56.854
so I could formally thank
the grandmother and Eun-Sook.

00:04:56.878 --> 00:05:00.134
And in the course of the grandmother
talking to the translator,

00:05:00.158 --> 00:05:01.854
the grandmother started crying.

00:05:01.878 --> 00:05:05.014
And I said to my translator,
"What's going on, why is she crying?"

00:05:05.038 --> 00:05:07.214
And she spoke to
the grandmother for a moment,

00:05:07.238 --> 00:05:09.454
and then she started
getting tears in her eyes.

00:05:09.478 --> 00:05:11.934
And I said, "What did I do?
Why is everyone crying?"

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.174
And the translator said,

00:05:13.198 --> 00:05:16.014
"The grandmother says
that she thinks she's dying,

00:05:16.038 --> 00:05:19.678
and she wants to know if you would take
Eun-Sook to America with you."

00:05:20.558 --> 00:05:25.854
And I said, "I'm 28 years old
and I live in hotels,

00:05:25.878 --> 00:05:27.694
and I'm not married."

00:05:27.718 --> 00:05:29.934
I mean, I had fallen in love
with this girl,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.894
but you know, emotionally
I was about 12 years old.

00:05:32.918 --> 00:05:34.494
If you know of photographers,

00:05:34.518 --> 00:05:38.934
the joke is it's the finest form
of delayed adolescence ever invented.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.574
"Sorry, I have to go
on an assignment, I'll be back" --

00:05:41.598 --> 00:05:43.014
and then you never come back.

00:05:43.038 --> 00:05:48.334
So I asked the translator
why she thought she was dying.

00:05:48.358 --> 00:05:51.254
Can I get her to a hospital?
Could I pay to get her a doctor?

00:05:51.278 --> 00:05:53.294
And she refused any help at all.

00:05:53.318 --> 00:05:56.478
So when I got outside,
I gave the translator some money and said,

00:05:56.502 --> 00:05:58.598
"Go back and see if you can do something."

00:05:58.622 --> 00:06:00.694
And I gave the grandmother
my business card.

00:06:00.718 --> 00:06:03.974
And I said, "If you're serious,
I will try to find a family for her."

00:06:03.998 --> 00:06:07.414
And I immediately wrote a letter
to my best friends in Atlanta, Georgia,

00:06:07.438 --> 00:06:08.774
who had an 11-year-old son.

00:06:08.798 --> 00:06:12.254
And my best friend
had mistakenly one day said something

00:06:12.278 --> 00:06:14.774
about wishing he had another child.

00:06:14.798 --> 00:06:18.854
So my friends Gene and Gayle
had not heard from me in about a year,

00:06:18.878 --> 00:06:20.294
and suddenly I was calling,

00:06:20.318 --> 00:06:23.574
saying "I'm in Korea
and I've met this extraordinary girl."

00:06:23.598 --> 00:06:26.294
And I said, "The grandmother
thinks she's sick,

00:06:26.318 --> 00:06:29.814
but I think maybe we would have to
bring the grandmother over also."

00:06:29.838 --> 00:06:33.494
And I said, "I'll pay for the ... "
I mean, I had this whole sort of picture.

00:06:33.518 --> 00:06:34.774
So anyway, I left.

00:06:34.798 --> 00:06:40.294
And my friends actually said
they were very interested in adopting her.

00:06:40.318 --> 00:06:43.294
And I said, "Look, I think
I'll scare the grandmother to death,

00:06:43.318 --> 00:06:45.894
if I tell her that
you're willing to adopt her.

00:06:45.918 --> 00:06:48.934
I want to go back and talk to her."
But I was off on assignment.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.054
I figured I'd come back
in a couple of weeks

00:06:51.078 --> 00:06:52.454
and talk to the grandmother.

00:06:52.478 --> 00:06:55.694
And on Christmas Day, I was in Bangkok
with a group of photographers

00:06:55.718 --> 00:06:58.654
and got a telegram --
back in those days, you got telegrams --

00:06:58.678 --> 00:07:01.094
from Time magazine
saying someone in Korea had died

00:07:01.118 --> 00:07:03.374
and left their child in a will to me.

00:07:03.398 --> 00:07:04.934
Did I know anything about this?

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.054
Because I hadn't told them
what I was doing,

00:07:07.078 --> 00:07:09.614
because I was so upset
with the story they'd run.

00:07:09.638 --> 00:07:13.014
So, I went back to Korea,
and I went back to Eun-Sook's village,

00:07:13.038 --> 00:07:14.254
and she was gone.

00:07:14.278 --> 00:07:16.974
And the house that
I had spent time in was empty.

00:07:16.998 --> 00:07:18.614
It was incredibly cold.

00:07:18.638 --> 00:07:21.254
No one in the village
would tell me where Eun-Sook was,

00:07:21.278 --> 00:07:24.214
because the grandmother
had always hidden her from Westerners.

00:07:24.238 --> 00:07:27.174
And they had no idea
about this request that she'd made of me.

00:07:27.198 --> 00:07:29.014
So I finally found Myung Sung,

00:07:29.038 --> 00:07:32.174
her best friend that she used to play with
after school every day.

00:07:32.198 --> 00:07:35.174
And Myung Sung, under some pressure
from me and the translator,

00:07:35.198 --> 00:07:37.574
gave us an address
on the outside of Seoul.

00:07:37.598 --> 00:07:42.214
And I went to that address
and knocked on the door,

00:07:42.238 --> 00:07:43.614
and a man answered the door.

00:07:43.638 --> 00:07:48.534
It was not a very nice area of Seoul,
there were mud streets outside of it.

00:07:48.558 --> 00:07:51.254
And I knocked on the door
and Eun-Sook answered the door,

00:07:51.278 --> 00:07:54.054
and her eyes were bloodshot,
and she seemed to be in shock.

00:07:54.078 --> 00:07:57.054
She didn't recognize me --
there was no recognition whatsoever.

00:07:57.078 --> 00:08:00.334
And this man came to the door
and kind of barked something in Korean.

00:08:00.358 --> 00:08:02.614
And I said to the translator,
"What did he say?"

00:08:02.638 --> 00:08:04.774
And she said, "He wants
to know who you are."

00:08:04.798 --> 00:08:07.054
And I said, "Tell him
that I am a photographer."

00:08:07.078 --> 00:08:09.494
I started explaining who I was,
and he interrupted.

00:08:09.518 --> 00:08:12.494
And she said, "He says he knows
who you are, what do you want?"

00:08:12.518 --> 00:08:16.974
I said, "Well, tell him that I was asked
by this little girl's grandmother

00:08:16.998 --> 00:08:18.934
to find a family for her."

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.198
And he said, "I'm her uncle,
she's fine, you can leave now."

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.318
So I was --

00:08:26.478 --> 00:08:28.334
The door was being slammed in my face,

00:08:28.358 --> 00:08:30.534
it's incredibly cold,
and I'm trying to think,

00:08:30.558 --> 00:08:34.214
"What would the hero do in a movie,
if I was writing this as a movie script?"

00:08:34.238 --> 00:08:36.894
So I said, "It's really cold,
I've come a very long way,

00:08:36.918 --> 00:08:39.414
do you mind if I come in
for a minute? I'm freezing."

00:08:39.438 --> 00:08:42.374
So the guy reluctantly let us in
and we sat down on the floor.

00:08:42.398 --> 00:08:44.853
And as we started talking,
I saw him yell something,

00:08:44.877 --> 00:08:47.654
and Eun-Sook came
and brought us some food.

00:08:47.678 --> 00:08:51.014
And I had this whole mental picture
of -- sort of like Cinderella.

00:08:51.038 --> 00:08:54.534
I sort of had this picture
of this incredibly wonderful,

00:08:54.558 --> 00:08:56.534
bright, happy little child,

00:08:56.558 --> 00:09:01.534
who now appeared to be very withdrawn,
being enslaved by this family.

00:09:01.558 --> 00:09:04.614
And I was really appalled,
and I couldn't figure out what to do.

00:09:04.638 --> 00:09:07.934
And the more I tried talking to him,
the less friendly he was getting.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.974
So finally I said "Look," --
this is all through the translator,

00:09:10.998 --> 00:09:13.454
because, you know,
I don't speak a word of Korean --

00:09:13.478 --> 00:09:17.774
and I said, "Look, I'm really glad
that Eun-Sook has a family to live with.

00:09:17.798 --> 00:09:19.214
I was very worried about her.

00:09:19.238 --> 00:09:22.894
I made a promise to her grandmother,
your mother, that I would find a family,

00:09:22.918 --> 00:09:25.534
and I'm so happy that
you're going to take care of her.

00:09:25.558 --> 00:09:28.454
But I bought an airline ticket
and I'm stuck here for a week.

00:09:28.478 --> 00:09:30.054
I'm staying in a hotel downtown.

00:09:30.078 --> 00:09:32.294
Would you like to come
and have lunch tomorrow?

00:09:32.318 --> 00:09:34.014
And you can practice your English."

00:09:34.038 --> 00:09:37.334
Because he told me -- I was trying
to ask him questions about himself.

00:09:37.358 --> 00:09:41.454
And so I went to the hotel,
and I found two older Amerasians.

00:09:41.478 --> 00:09:45.934
A girl whose mother had been a prostitute,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.814
and she was a prostitute,

00:09:47.838 --> 00:09:49.774
and a boy who'd been in and out of jail.

00:09:49.798 --> 00:09:52.094
And I said to them,
"Look, there's a little girl

00:09:52.118 --> 00:09:55.254
who has a tiny chance
of getting out of here

00:09:55.278 --> 00:09:56.534
and going to America.

00:09:56.558 --> 00:09:58.894
I don't know if it's
the right decision or not,

00:09:58.918 --> 00:10:01.094
but I would like you
to come to lunch tomorrow

00:10:01.118 --> 00:10:03.854
and tell the uncle what it's like
to walk down the street,

00:10:03.878 --> 00:10:06.454
what people say to you,
what you do for a living.

00:10:06.478 --> 00:10:09.494
I want him to understand
what happens if she stays here.

00:10:09.518 --> 00:10:12.934
And I could be wrong, I don't know,
but I wish you would come tomorrow."

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.774
So, these two came to lunch
and we got thrown out of the restaurant.

00:10:16.798 --> 00:10:20.254
They were yelling at him,
it got to be really ugly.

00:10:20.278 --> 00:10:22.231
We went outside, and he was just furious.

00:10:22.255 --> 00:10:24.294
And I knew I had totally blown this thing.

00:10:24.318 --> 00:10:26.694
Here I was again,
trying to figure out what to do.

00:10:26.718 --> 00:10:29.534
And he started yelling at me,
and I said to the translator,

00:10:29.558 --> 00:10:31.574
"Tell him to calm down,
what is he saying?"

00:10:31.598 --> 00:10:35.014
And she said, "He's saying, 'Who the hell
are you to walk into my house,

00:10:35.038 --> 00:10:37.574
some rich American
with your cameras around your neck,

00:10:37.598 --> 00:10:40.294
accusing me of enslaving my niece?

00:10:40.318 --> 00:10:43.620
This is my niece, I love her,
she's my sister's daughter.

00:10:43.644 --> 00:10:48.054
Who the hell are you
to accuse me of something like this?'"

00:10:48.078 --> 00:10:50.934
And I said, you know,
"Look, you're absolutely right.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.374
I don't pretend to understand
what's going on here.

00:10:53.398 --> 00:10:56.374
All I know is, I've been
photographing a lot of these children.

00:10:56.398 --> 00:10:59.334
I'm in love with your niece,

00:10:59.358 --> 00:11:01.694
I think she's an incredibly
special child."

00:11:01.718 --> 00:11:05.174
And I said, "Look, I will fly my friends
over here from the United States

00:11:05.198 --> 00:11:07.854
if you want to meet them,
to see if you approve of them.

00:11:07.878 --> 00:11:11.494
I just think that --
what little I know about the situation,

00:11:11.518 --> 00:11:14.254
she has very little chance here
of having the kind of life

00:11:14.278 --> 00:11:16.294
that you probably would like her to have."

00:11:16.318 --> 00:11:19.814
So, everyone told me afterwards
that inviting the prospective parents over

00:11:19.838 --> 00:11:22.614
was, again, the stupidest thing
I could have possibly done,

00:11:22.638 --> 00:11:24.974
because who's ever
good enough for your relative?

00:11:24.998 --> 00:11:28.094
But he invited me to come to a ceremony
they were having that day

00:11:28.118 --> 00:11:29.494
for her grandmother.

00:11:29.518 --> 00:11:32.214
And they actually take
items of clothing and photographs,

00:11:32.238 --> 00:11:34.198
and they burn them as part of the ritual.

00:11:34.998 --> 00:11:37.894
And you can see how different she looks
just in three months.

00:11:37.918 --> 00:11:40.334
This was now, I think, early February.

00:11:40.358 --> 00:11:42.638
And the pictures before
were taken in September.

00:11:43.998 --> 00:11:46.094
Well, there was
an American Maryknoll priest

00:11:46.118 --> 00:11:48.374
that I had met in the course
of doing the story,

00:11:48.398 --> 00:11:50.334
who had 75 children living in his house.

00:11:50.358 --> 00:11:52.974
He had three women helping him
take care of these kids.

00:11:52.998 --> 00:11:56.254
And so I suggested to the uncle
that we go down and meet Father Keane

00:11:56.278 --> 00:11:58.374
to find out how
the adoption process worked.

00:11:58.398 --> 00:11:59.774
Because I wanted him to feel

00:11:59.798 --> 00:12:02.214
like this was all being done
very much above board.

00:12:02.238 --> 00:12:04.598
So, this is on the way
down to the orphanage.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.198
This is Father Keane.
He's just a wonderful guy.

00:12:10.038 --> 00:12:12.294
He had kids from
all over Korea living there,

00:12:12.318 --> 00:12:14.318
and he would find families for these kids.

00:12:15.398 --> 00:12:17.854
This is a social worker
interviewing Eun-Sook.

00:12:17.878 --> 00:12:21.294
Now, I had always thought she was
completely untouched by all of this,

00:12:21.318 --> 00:12:22.814
because the grandmother, to me,

00:12:22.838 --> 00:12:26.414
appeared to be sort of
the village wise woman --

00:12:26.438 --> 00:12:29.934
throughout the day, I noticed people
kept coming to visit her grandmother.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.694
And I always had this mental picture

00:12:31.718 --> 00:12:35.414
that even though they may have been
one of the poorer families in the village,

00:12:35.438 --> 00:12:37.174
they were one of the most respected.

00:12:37.198 --> 00:12:40.774
And I always felt that the grandmother
had kind of demanded, and insisted,

00:12:40.798 --> 00:12:44.238
that the villagers treat Eun-Sook
with the same respect they treated her.

00:12:46.198 --> 00:12:48.294
Eun-Sook stayed at Father Keane's,

00:12:48.318 --> 00:12:51.894
and her uncle agreed to let her stay there
until the adoption went through.

00:12:51.918 --> 00:12:53.774
He actually agreed to the adoption.

00:12:53.798 --> 00:12:56.454
And I went off on assignment
and came back a week later,

00:12:56.478 --> 00:12:59.494
and Father Keane said,
"I've got to talk to you about Eun-Sook."

00:12:59.518 --> 00:13:00.854
I said, "Oh God, now what?"

00:13:00.878 --> 00:13:03.574
And he takes me into this room,
closes the door and says,

00:13:03.598 --> 00:13:06.734
"I have 75 children here in the orphanage,
and it's total bedlam."

00:13:06.758 --> 00:13:08.214
There's clothes, there's kids.

00:13:08.238 --> 00:13:10.574
Three adults and 75 kids --
you can imagine.

00:13:10.598 --> 00:13:13.454
And he said, "The second day
she was here she made up a list

00:13:13.478 --> 00:13:16.454
of all of the names
of the older kids and the younger kids.

00:13:16.478 --> 00:13:20.014
And she assigned one of the older kids
to each of the younger kids.

00:13:20.038 --> 00:13:24.614
And then she set up a work detail list
of who cleaned the orphanage on what day."

00:13:24.638 --> 00:13:26.774
And he said, "She's telling me
that I'm messy

00:13:26.798 --> 00:13:28.374
and I have to clean up my room."

00:13:28.398 --> 00:13:31.974
And he said, "I don't know who raised her,
but she's running the orphanage,

00:13:31.998 --> 00:13:33.574
and she's been here three days."

00:13:33.598 --> 00:13:35.054
(Laughter)

00:13:35.078 --> 00:13:39.118
This was movie day that she organized
where all the kids went to the movies.

00:13:40.158 --> 00:13:43.374
A lot of the kids who had been adopted
wrote back to the other kids,

00:13:43.398 --> 00:13:46.334
telling them what their life
was like with their new families.

00:13:46.358 --> 00:13:48.974
So it was a really big deal
when the letters showed up.

00:13:48.998 --> 00:13:51.454
This is a woman who is
now working at the orphanage,

00:13:51.478 --> 00:13:52.764
whose son had been adopted.

00:13:55.918 --> 00:13:57.934
Gene and Gayle started studying Korean

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.974
the moment they had gotten
my first letter.

00:13:59.998 --> 00:14:04.494
They really wanted to be able
to welcome Eun-Sook into their family.

00:14:04.518 --> 00:14:06.574
And one of the things Father Keane told me

00:14:06.598 --> 00:14:08.614
when I came back
from one of these trips --

00:14:08.638 --> 00:14:10.534
Eun-Sook had chosen the name Natasha,

00:14:10.558 --> 00:14:14.814
which I understood was from her watching
a "Rocky and Bullwinkle" cartoon

00:14:14.838 --> 00:14:16.774
on the American Air Force station.

00:14:16.798 --> 00:14:18.854
This may be one
of those myth-buster things

00:14:18.878 --> 00:14:21.054
that we'll have to
clear up here, in a minute.

00:14:21.078 --> 00:14:23.374
So, my friend Gene
flew over with his son, Tim.

00:14:23.398 --> 00:14:24.934
Gayle couldn't come.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.574
And they spent a lot of time
huddled over a dictionary.

00:14:27.598 --> 00:14:29.294
And this was Gene showing the uncle

00:14:29.318 --> 00:14:31.438
where Atlanta was on the map,
where he lived.

00:14:32.758 --> 00:14:34.918
This is the uncle
signing the adoption papers.

00:14:35.798 --> 00:14:38.214
Now, we went out to dinner
that night to celebrate.

00:14:38.238 --> 00:14:39.854
The uncle went back to his family

00:14:39.878 --> 00:14:43.334
and Natasha and Tim and Gene and I
went out to dinner.

00:14:43.358 --> 00:14:47.214
And Gene was showing Natasha
how to use a knife and fork,

00:14:47.238 --> 00:14:50.958
and then Natasha
was returning the utensil lessons.

00:14:51.918 --> 00:14:53.814
We went back to our hotel room,

00:14:53.838 --> 00:14:56.294
and Gene was showing Natasha
also where Atlanta was.

00:14:56.318 --> 00:14:58.294
This is the third night we were in Korea.

00:14:58.318 --> 00:15:01.374
The first night we'd gotten a room
for the kids right next to us.

00:15:01.398 --> 00:15:04.014
I'd been staying in this room
for about three months --

00:15:04.038 --> 00:15:06.958
it was a little 15-story Korean hotel.

00:15:07.558 --> 00:15:09.934
The second night,
we didn't keep the kids' room,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.054
because we slept on the floor
with all the kids at the orphanage.

00:15:13.078 --> 00:15:14.814
And the third night, we came back --

00:15:14.838 --> 00:15:17.614
we'd just gone out to dinner,
where you saw the pictures --

00:15:17.638 --> 00:15:19.854
and we got to the front desk,
and the guy said,

00:15:19.878 --> 00:15:22.294
"There's no other free rooms
on your floor tonight,

00:15:22.318 --> 00:15:24.414
you can put the kids
five floors below you."

00:15:24.438 --> 00:15:26.574
And Gene and I
looked at each other and said,

00:15:26.598 --> 00:15:28.974
"We don't want two 11-year-olds
five floors away."

00:15:28.998 --> 00:15:32.134
So his son said, "I have a sleeping bag,
I'll sleep on the floor."

00:15:32.158 --> 00:15:35.094
And I said, "I have one too."
So Tim and I slept on the floor,

00:15:35.118 --> 00:15:37.894
Natasha got one bed,
Gene got the other -- kids pass out,

00:15:37.918 --> 00:15:39.814
it's been very exciting for three days.

00:15:39.838 --> 00:15:43.334
We're lying in bed, and Gene and I
are talking about how cool we are.

00:15:43.358 --> 00:15:46.334
We said, "That was so great,
we saved this little girl's life."

00:15:46.358 --> 00:15:49.814
We were just like,
you know, just full of ourselves.

00:15:49.838 --> 00:15:51.174
And we fall asleep --

00:15:51.198 --> 00:15:53.774
and I've been in this room
for a couple of months now.

00:15:53.798 --> 00:15:57.654
And they always overheat
the hotels in Korea terribly,

00:15:57.678 --> 00:15:59.974
so during the day
I always left the window open.

00:15:59.998 --> 00:16:02.894
And then about midnight,
they turn the heat off in the hotel.

00:16:02.918 --> 00:16:06.214
So at 1am, the whole room would be
like 20 below zero, and I'd get up.

00:16:06.238 --> 00:16:08.454
I'd been doing this
every night I'd been there.

00:16:08.478 --> 00:16:10.974
So, sure enough,
it's one o'clock, room's freezing,

00:16:10.998 --> 00:16:14.694
I go to close the window
and I hear people shouting outside,

00:16:14.718 --> 00:16:17.338
and I thought, "Oh, the bars
must have just gotten out."

00:16:17.362 --> 00:16:19.774
I don't speak Korean,
but I'm hearing these voices,

00:16:19.798 --> 00:16:22.278
and I'm not hearing anger,
I'm hearing terror.

00:16:23.038 --> 00:16:25.134
So I open the window and I look out,

00:16:25.158 --> 00:16:27.894
and there's flames
coming up the side of our hotel,

00:16:27.918 --> 00:16:29.614
and the hotel's on fire.

00:16:29.638 --> 00:16:31.574
So I run over to Gene and I wake him up,

00:16:31.598 --> 00:16:34.374
and I say, "Don't freak out,
I think the hotel's on fire."

00:16:34.398 --> 00:16:37.094
And now there's smoke and flames
coming by our windows --

00:16:37.118 --> 00:16:38.374
we're on the 11th floor.

00:16:38.398 --> 00:16:41.054
So the two of us were just like,
"Oh my God, oh my God."

00:16:41.078 --> 00:16:44.454
So we're trying to get Natasha up,
and we can't talk to her.

00:16:44.478 --> 00:16:47.774
You know what kids are like
when they've been asleep for like an hour,

00:16:47.798 --> 00:16:50.774
it's like they took five Valiums --
they're all over the place.

00:16:50.798 --> 00:16:52.014
And we can't talk to her.

00:16:52.038 --> 00:16:55.454
His son had the L.L.Bean bootlaces,
and we're trying to do up his laces.

00:16:55.478 --> 00:16:58.654
So we try to get to the door,
we run to the door, we open the door,

00:16:58.678 --> 00:17:00.734
and it's like walking
into a blast furnace.

00:17:00.758 --> 00:17:04.134
There's people screaming,
the sound of glass breaking, weird thumps.

00:17:04.158 --> 00:17:06.974
And the whole room filled
with smoke in about two seconds.

00:17:06.998 --> 00:17:09.894
And Gene turns around and says,
"We're not going to make it."

00:17:09.918 --> 00:17:13.134
And he closes the door, and the whole room
is now filled with smoke.

00:17:13.158 --> 00:17:14.894
We're all choking, and there's smoke

00:17:14.918 --> 00:17:16.934
pouring through the vents,
under the doors.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.214
There's people screaming.

00:17:18.238 --> 00:17:20.854
I just remember this unbelievable --
just utter chaos.

00:17:20.878 --> 00:17:24.374
I remember sitting near the bed,
and I had two overwhelming feelings.

00:17:24.398 --> 00:17:27.694
One was absolute terror.
"Oh, please God, I just want to wake up.

00:17:27.718 --> 00:17:30.374
This has got to be a nightmare,
this can't be happening.

00:17:30.398 --> 00:17:31.974
Please, I just want to wake up."

00:17:31.998 --> 00:17:33.734
And the other is unbelievable guilt.

00:17:33.758 --> 00:17:36.134
Here I've been playing God
with my friends' lives,

00:17:36.158 --> 00:17:37.974
my friends' son, with Natasha's life,

00:17:37.998 --> 00:17:41.294
and this what you get when you try
playing God, is you hurt people.

00:17:41.318 --> 00:17:43.694
I remember just being
so frightened and terrified.

00:17:43.718 --> 00:17:45.694
And Gene, who's lying on the floor, says,

00:17:45.718 --> 00:17:47.774
"We've got to soak towels."
I said, "What?"

00:17:47.798 --> 00:17:50.734
"We've got to soak towels.
We're going to die from the smoke."

00:17:50.758 --> 00:17:53.663
So got towels and put them
over our faces and the kids' faces.

00:17:53.687 --> 00:17:55.734
Then he said, "Do you have gaffer's tape?"

00:17:55.758 --> 00:17:57.494
"What?" "Do you have gaffer's tape?"

00:17:57.518 --> 00:17:59.374
I said, "Somewhere in my Halliburton."

00:17:59.398 --> 00:18:02.256
He says, "We've got to stop the smoke.
That's all we can do."

00:18:02.280 --> 00:18:04.120
I mean, Gene -- thank God for Gene.

00:18:04.758 --> 00:18:09.614
So we put the room service menus
over the vents in the wall,

00:18:09.638 --> 00:18:11.694
we put blankets at the bottom of the door,

00:18:11.718 --> 00:18:14.414
we put the kids on the windowsill
to try to get some air.

00:18:14.438 --> 00:18:16.334
And there was a new building, going up,

00:18:16.358 --> 00:18:19.214
that was being built
right across the street from our hotel.

00:18:19.238 --> 00:18:21.429
And there, in the building,
were photographers,

00:18:21.453 --> 00:18:23.254
waiting for people to jump.

00:18:23.278 --> 00:18:25.374
Eleven people ended up dying in the fire.

00:18:25.398 --> 00:18:29.454
Five people jumped and died,
other people were killed by the smoke.

00:18:29.478 --> 00:18:34.454
And there's this loud thumping on the door
after about 45 minutes in all this,

00:18:34.478 --> 00:18:36.174
and people were shouting in Korean.

00:18:36.198 --> 00:18:37.438
And I remember --

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.574
Natasha didn't want us opening the door --

00:18:43.598 --> 00:18:45.574
sorry, I was trying not to open the door,

00:18:45.598 --> 00:18:48.094
because we'd spent so much time
barricading the room.

00:18:48.118 --> 00:18:50.814
I didn't know who it was,
I didn't know what they wanted,

00:18:50.838 --> 00:18:53.774
and Natasha could tell
they were firemen trying to get us out.

00:18:53.798 --> 00:18:57.134
I remember a sort of a tussle at the door,
trying to get the door open.

00:18:57.158 --> 00:19:01.574
In any case, 12 hours later --
I mean, they put us in the lobby.

00:19:01.598 --> 00:19:05.214
Gene ended up using his coat,
and his fist in the coat,

00:19:05.238 --> 00:19:06.774
to break open a liquor cabinet.

00:19:06.798 --> 00:19:08.334
People were lying on the floor.

00:19:08.358 --> 00:19:10.534
It was one of just
the most horrifying nights.

00:19:10.558 --> 00:19:14.294
And then 12 hours later,
we rented a car, as we had planned to,

00:19:14.318 --> 00:19:16.294
and drove back to Natasha's village.

00:19:16.318 --> 00:19:19.454
And we kept saying, "Do you realize
we were dying in a hotel fire,

00:19:19.478 --> 00:19:20.694
like eight hours ago?"

00:19:20.718 --> 00:19:22.454
It's so weird how life just goes on.

00:19:22.478 --> 00:19:25.894
Natasha wanted to introduce her brother
and father to all the villagers,

00:19:25.918 --> 00:19:29.254
and the day we showed up turned out
to be a 60-year-old man's birthday.

00:19:29.278 --> 00:19:30.494
This guy's 60 years old.

00:19:30.518 --> 00:19:32.294
So it turned into a dual celebration,

00:19:32.318 --> 00:19:34.854
because Natasha was
the first person from this village

00:19:34.878 --> 00:19:36.454
ever to go to the United States.

00:19:36.478 --> 00:19:38.174
So, these are the greenhouse tents.

00:19:38.198 --> 00:19:40.374
This is the elders
teaching Gene their dances.

00:19:40.398 --> 00:19:41.774
We drank a lot of rice wine.

00:19:41.798 --> 00:19:44.118
We were both so drunk,
I couldn't believe it.

00:19:47.718 --> 00:19:50.694
This is the last picture
before Gene and Tim headed back.

00:19:50.718 --> 00:19:52.374
The adoption people told us

00:19:52.398 --> 00:19:55.438
it was going to take a year
for the adoption to go through.

00:19:56.038 --> 00:19:57.894
Like, what could you do for a year?

00:19:57.918 --> 00:20:01.654
So I found out the name of every official
on both the Korean and American side,

00:20:01.678 --> 00:20:02.934
and I photographed them,

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:06.294
and told them how famous they were
going to be when this book was done.

00:20:06.318 --> 00:20:10.174
And four months later,
the adoption papers came through.

00:20:10.198 --> 00:20:13.374
This is saying goodbye
to everybody at the orphanage.

00:20:13.398 --> 00:20:16.318
This is Father Keane with Natasha
at the bus stop.

00:20:16.758 --> 00:20:18.494
Her great aunt at the airport.

00:20:18.518 --> 00:20:21.934
I had a wonderful deal with Cathay Pacific
airlines for many years,

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:24.974
where they gave me free passes
on all their airlines

00:20:24.998 --> 00:20:26.294
in return for photography.

00:20:26.318 --> 00:20:28.094
It was like the ultimate perk.

00:20:28.118 --> 00:20:30.014
And the pilot, I actually knew --

00:20:30.038 --> 00:20:32.374
because they used to let me sit
in the jump seat,

00:20:32.398 --> 00:20:34.054
to tell you how long ago this was.

00:20:34.078 --> 00:20:37.534
This is a TriStar, and so they let Natasha
actually sit in the jump seat.

00:20:37.558 --> 00:20:39.734
And the pilot, Jeff Cowley,
actually went back

00:20:39.758 --> 00:20:43.854
and adopted one of the other kids
at the orphanage after meeting Natasha.

00:20:43.878 --> 00:20:45.934
This is 28 hours later in Atlanta.

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:47.374
It's a very long flight.

00:20:47.398 --> 00:20:50.734
Just to make things even crazier,
Gayle, Natasha's new mom,

00:20:50.758 --> 00:20:53.478
was three days away
from giving birth to her own daughter.

00:20:54.718 --> 00:20:56.894
You know, if you were
writing this, you'd say,

00:20:56.918 --> 00:20:59.174
"No, we've got to write
the script differently."

00:20:59.198 --> 00:21:02.894
This is the first night showing Natasha
her new cousins and uncles and aunts.

00:21:02.918 --> 00:21:06.974
Gene and Gayle know everyone in Atlanta --
they're the most social couple imaginable.

00:21:06.998 --> 00:21:09.915
So, at this point, Natasha
doesn't speak a word of English,

00:21:09.939 --> 00:21:12.139
other than what little
Father Keane taught her.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:16.478
This is Kylie, her sister,
who's now a doctor, on the right.

00:21:19.398 --> 00:21:22.814
This is a deal I had with Natasha,
which is that when we got to Atlanta

00:21:22.838 --> 00:21:24.998
she could cut off my beard.

00:21:25.518 --> 00:21:26.918
She never liked it very much.

00:21:28.398 --> 00:21:30.174
She learned English in three months.

00:21:30.198 --> 00:21:32.398
She entered seventh grade
at her own age level.

00:21:35.158 --> 00:21:37.094
Pledge of Allegiance for the first time.

00:21:37.118 --> 00:21:38.494
This is her cooking teacher.

00:21:38.518 --> 00:21:41.334
Natasha told me a lot of the kids
thought she was stuck up,

00:21:41.358 --> 00:21:43.974
because they would talk to her
and she wouldn't answer,

00:21:43.998 --> 00:21:46.774
and they didn't realize
she didn't speak English very well.

00:21:46.798 --> 00:21:48.774
But what I noticed, again as an observer,

00:21:48.798 --> 00:21:51.278
was she was choosing
who was going to be on her team,

00:21:53.278 --> 00:21:56.974
and seemed to be very popular
very, very quickly.

00:21:56.998 --> 00:21:58.294
Now, remember the picture,

00:21:58.318 --> 00:22:01.094
how much she looked like
her grandmother, at the beginning?

00:22:01.118 --> 00:22:04.774
People were always telling Natasha
how much she looks like her mother, Gayle.

00:22:04.798 --> 00:22:06.038
(Laughter)

00:22:06.838 --> 00:22:10.558
This is a tense moment
in the first football game, I think.

00:22:12.838 --> 00:22:17.358
And Kylie -- I mean, it was
almost like Kylie was her own child.

00:22:21.998 --> 00:22:23.358
She's being baptized.

00:22:24.798 --> 00:22:26.694
Now, a lot of parents, when they adopt,

00:22:26.718 --> 00:22:28.974
actually want to erase
their children's history.

00:22:28.998 --> 00:22:31.134
And Gayle and Gene
did the complete opposite.

00:22:31.158 --> 00:22:33.734
They were studying Korean;
they bought Korean clothes.

00:22:33.758 --> 00:22:36.014
Gene even did a little
tile work in the kitchen,

00:22:36.038 --> 00:22:38.934
which was that, "Once upon a time,
there was a beautiful girl

00:22:38.958 --> 00:22:42.387
that came from the hills of Korea
to live happily ever after in Atlanta."

00:22:42.411 --> 00:22:44.627
She hates this picture --
it was her first job.

00:22:44.651 --> 00:22:47.054
She bought a bright red Karmann Ghia

00:22:47.078 --> 00:22:49.454
with the money she made
working at Burger King.

00:22:49.478 --> 00:22:51.198
The captain of the cheerleaders.

00:22:51.798 --> 00:22:52.998
Beauty pageant.

00:22:54.598 --> 00:22:56.734
Used to do their
Christmas card every year.

00:22:56.758 --> 00:22:59.358
Gene's been restoring this car
for a million years.

00:23:02.958 --> 00:23:07.094
Kodak hired Natasha to be a translator
for them at the Olympics in Korea.

00:23:07.118 --> 00:23:12.014
Her future husband, Jeff,
was working for Canon cameras,

00:23:12.038 --> 00:23:14.998
and met Natasha at the Olympic Village.

00:23:15.558 --> 00:23:18.358
This is her first trip back to Korea.
So there's her uncle.

00:23:19.478 --> 00:23:21.158
This is her half sister.

00:23:22.518 --> 00:23:23.934
She went back to the village.

00:23:23.958 --> 00:23:25.518
That's her best friend's mother.

00:23:27.798 --> 00:23:31.094
And I always thought that was
a very Annie Hall kind of outfit.

00:23:31.118 --> 00:23:32.358
(Laughter)

00:23:33.118 --> 00:23:36.174
It's just, you know, it was
just so interesting, just to watch --

00:23:36.198 --> 00:23:38.238
this is her mother
in the background there.

00:23:43.165 --> 00:23:44.965
This is Natasha's wedding day.

00:23:49.758 --> 00:23:51.478
Gene is looking a little older.

00:24:02.718 --> 00:24:07.078
This is Sydney, who's going to be
three years old in a couple of days.

00:24:08.078 --> 00:24:09.318
And there's Evan.

00:24:10.678 --> 00:24:13.214
And Natasha, would you
just come up, for a second,

00:24:13.238 --> 00:24:15.054
just maybe to say hello to everybody?

00:24:15.078 --> 00:24:20.598
(Applause)

00:24:25.478 --> 00:24:27.814
Natasha's actually
never heard me tell the story.

00:24:27.838 --> 00:24:30.094
You know, we've looked
at the pictures together.

00:24:30.118 --> 00:24:32.294
Natasha: I've seen pictures
millions of times,

00:24:32.318 --> 00:24:36.158
but today was the first time I'm actually
seeing him give the whole presentation.

00:24:36.998 --> 00:24:38.854
I started crying.

00:24:38.878 --> 00:24:41.734
Rick Smolan: There's about 40 things
she's going to tell me,

00:24:41.758 --> 00:24:45.094
"That wasn't what happened."
Natasha: I'll tell you that later.

00:24:45.118 --> 00:24:49.014
RS: Anyway, thank you, Mike and Richard,
so much for letting us tell the story.

00:24:49.038 --> 00:24:50.294
Thank you, all of you.

00:24:50.318 --> 00:24:53.798
(Applause)
