00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:18.958
I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at Oxford now,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
that we think is going to change the way that

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
computer games and Hollywood movies are being made.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
That technology is simulating humans.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
It's simulated humans with a simulated body

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and a simulated nervous system to control that body.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
Now, before I talk more about that technology,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
let's have a quick look at what human characters look like

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
at the moment in computer games.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
This is a clip from a game called "Grand Theft Auto 3."

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
We already saw that briefly yesterday.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And what you can see is -- it is actually a very good game.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
It's one of the most successful games of all time.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
But what you'll see is that all the animations in this game are very repetitive.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
They pretty much look the same.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
I've made him run into a wall here, over and over again.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
And you can see he looks always the same.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
The reason for that is that these characters

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
are actually not real characters.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
They are a graphical visualization of a character.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:20.958
To produce these animations, an animator at a studio has to anticipate

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
what's going to happen in the actual game,

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
and then has to animate that particular sequence.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:30.958
So, he or she sits down, animates it, and tries to anticipate what's going to happen,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
and then these particular animations are just played back

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
at appropriate times in the computer game.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:41.958
Now, the result of that is that you can't have real interactivity.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
All you have is animations that are played back

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
at more or less the appropriate times.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:51.958
It also means that games aren't really going to be as surprising as they could be,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
because you only get out of it, at least in terms of the character,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
what you actually put into it.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
There's no real emergence there.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:02.958
And thirdly, as I said, most of the animations are very repetitive because of that.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
Now, the only way to get around that

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
is to actually simulate the human body

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:11.958
and to simulate that bit of the nervous system of the brain that controls that body.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
And maybe, if I could have you for a quick demonstration

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
to show what the difference is --

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.958
because, I mean, it's very, very trivial.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
If I push Chris a bit, like this, for example, he'll react to it.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
If I push him from a different angle, he'll react to it differently,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
and that's because he has a physical body,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and because he has the motor skills to control that body.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
It's a very trivial thing.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
It's not something you get in computer games at the moment, at all.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
Thank you very much. Chris Anderson: That's it?

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
Torsten Reil: That's it, yes.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:40.958
So, that's what we're trying to simulate --

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:44.958
not Chris specifically, I should say, but humans in general.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:50.958
Now, we started working on this a while ago at Oxford University,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and we tried to start very simply.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
What we tried to do was teach a stick figure how to walk.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
That stick figure is physically stimulated. You can see it here on the screen.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
So, it's subject to gravity, has joints, etc.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
If you just run the simulation, it will just collapse, like this.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
The tricky bit is now to put an AI controller in it

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
that actually makes it work.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
And for that, we use the neural network, which we based on

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
that part of the nervous system that we have in our spine

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
that controls walking in humans.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
It's called the central pattern generator.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
So, we simulated that as well, and then the really tricky bit

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
is to teach that network how to walk.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
For that we used artificial evolution -- genetic algorithms.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
We heard about those already yesterday,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and I suppose that most of you are familiar with that already.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
But, just briefly, the concept is that

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
you create a large number of different individuals --

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
neural networks, in this case --

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
all of which are random at the beginning.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
You hook these up -- in this case, to the virtual muscles

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
of that two-legged creature here --

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
and hope that it does something interesting.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
At the beginning, they're all going to be very boring.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
Most of them won't move at all,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
but some of them might make a tiny step.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
Those are then selected by the algorithm,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:02.958
reproduced with mutation and recombinations to introduce sex as well.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And you repeat that process over and over again,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
until you have something that walks --

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
in this case, in a straight line, like this.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
So that was the idea behind this.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
When we started this, I set up the simulation one evening.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
It took about three to four hours to run the simulation.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:20.958
I got up the next morning, went to the computer and looked at the results,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
and was hoping for something that walked in a straight line,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
like I've just demonstrated,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and this is what I got instead.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:37.958
(Laughter)

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
So, it was back to the drawing board for us.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
We did get it to work eventually,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
after tweaking a bit here and there.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
And this is an example of a successful evolutionary run.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
So, what you'll see in a moment is a very simple biped

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
that's learning how to walk using artificial evolution.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
At the beginning, it can't walk at all,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
but it will get better and better over time.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
So, this is the one that can't walk at all.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:10.958
(Laughter)

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
Now, after five generations of applying evolutionary process,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
the genetic algorithm is getting a tiny bit better.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:24.958
(Laughter)

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
Generation 10 and it'll take a few steps more --

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
still not quite there.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:38.958
But now, after generation 20, it actually walks in a straight line without falling over.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
That was the real breakthrough for us.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
It was, academically, quite a challenging project,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
and once we had reached that stage, we were quite confident

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
that we could try and do other things as well with this approach --

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
actually simulating the body

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and simulating that part of the nervous system that controls it.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
Now, at this stage, it also became clear that this could be very exciting

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
for things like computer games or online worlds.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
What you see here is the character standing there,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and there's an obstacle that we put in its way.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And what you see is, it's going to fall over the obstacle.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Now, the interesting bit is, if I move the obstacle a tiny bit to the right,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
which is what I'm doing now, here,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
it will fall over it in a completely different way.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:28.958
And again, if you move the obstacle a tiny bit, it'll again fall differently.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
(Laughter)

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Now, what you see, by the way, at the top there,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
are some of the neural activations being fed into the virtual muscles.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Okay. That's the video. Thanks.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Now, this might look kind of trivial, but it's actually very important

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
because this is not something you get at the moment

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
in any interactive or any virtual worlds.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
Now, at this stage, we decided to start a company and move this further,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
because obviously this was just a very simple, blocky biped.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
What we really wanted was a full human body.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:56.958
So we started the company.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:01.958
We hired a team of physicists, software engineers and biologists

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
to work on this, and the first thing we had to work on

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
was to create the human body, basically.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
It's got to be relatively fast, so you can run it on a normal machine,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
but it's got to be accurate enough, so it looks good enough, basically.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
So we put quite a bit of biomechanical knowledge into this thing,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:21.958
and tried to make it as realistic as possible.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
What you see here on the screen right now

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
is a very simple visualization of that body.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
I should add that it's very simple to add things like hair, clothes, etc.,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
but what we've done here is use a very simple visualization,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
so you can concentrate on the movement.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Now, what I'm going to do right now, in a moment,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
is just push this character a tiny bit and we'll see what happens.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Nothing really interesting, basically.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
It falls over, but it falls over like a rag doll, basically.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
The reason for that is that there's no intelligence in it.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
It becomes interesting when you put artificial intelligence into it.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:01.958
So, this character now has motor skills in the upper body --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
nothing in the legs yet, in this particular one.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
But what it will do -- I'm going to push it again.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
It will realize autonomously that it's being pushed.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
It's going to stick out its hands.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
It's going to turn around into the fall, and try and catch the fall.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
So that's what you see here.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Now, it gets really interesting

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
if you then add the AI for the lower part of the body as well.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
So here, we've got the same character.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
I'm going to push it a bit harder now,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
harder than I just pushed Chris.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
But what you'll see is -- it's going to receive a push now from the left.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
What you see is it takes steps backwards,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
it tries to counter-balance,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
it tries to look at the place where it thinks it's going to land.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
I'll show you this again.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
And then, finally hits the floor.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
Now, this becomes really exciting

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:02.958
when you push that character in different directions, again, just as I've done.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
That's something that you cannot do right now.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
At the moment, you only have empty computer graphics in games.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
What this is now is a real simulation. That's what I want to show you now.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
So, here's the same character with the same behavior I've just shown you,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
but now I'm just going to push it from different directions.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
First, starting with a push from the right.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
This is all slow motion, by the way, so we can see what's going on.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Now, the angle will have changed a tiny bit,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.958
so you can see that the reaction is different.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
Again, a push, now this time from the front.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
And you see it falls differently.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And now from the left --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and it falls differently.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
That was really exciting for us to see that.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
That was the first time we've seen that.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
This is the first time the public sees this as well,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
because we have been in stealth mode.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
I haven't shown this to anybody yet.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Now, just a fun thing:

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
what happens if you put that character --

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
this is now a wooden version of it, but it's got the same AI in it --

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
but if you put that character on a slippery surface, like ice.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
We just did that for a laugh, just to see what happens.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:06.958
(Laughter)

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
And this is what happens.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
(Laughter)

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
(Applause)

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
It's nothing we had to do about this.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
We just took this character that I just talked about,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
put it on a slippery surface, and this is what you get out of it.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
And that's a really fascinating thing about this approach.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Now, when we went to film studios and games developers

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
and showed them that technology, we got a very good response.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
And what they said was, the first thing they need immediately is virtual stuntmen.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
Because stunts are obviously very dangerous, they're very expensive,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and there are a lot of stunt scenes that you cannot do, obviously,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
because you can't really allow the stuntman to be seriously hurt.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
So, they wanted to have a digital version of a stuntman

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and that's what we've been working on for the past few months.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:54.958
And that's our first product that we're going to release in a couple of weeks.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:59.958
So, here are just a few very simple scenes of the guy just being kicked.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
That's what people want. That's what we're giving them.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:08.958
(Laughter)

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
You can see, it's always reacting.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.958
This is not a dead body. This is a body who basically, in this particular case,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
feels the force and tries to protect its head.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Only, I think it's quite a big blow again.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
You feel kind of sorry for that thing,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
and we've seen it so many times now that

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
we don't really care any more.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:25.958
(Laughter)

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
There are much worse videos than this, by the way, which I have taken out, but ...

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Now, here's another one.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
What people wanted as a behavior was to have an explosion,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
a strong force applied to the character,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
and have the character react to it in midair.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
So that you don't have a character that looks limp,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
but actually a character that you can use in an action film straight away,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
that looks kind of alive in midair as well.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
So this character is going to be hit by a force,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
it's going to realize it's in the air,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
and it's going to try and, well,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
stick out its arm in the direction where it's landing.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
That's one angle; here's another angle.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
We now think that the realism we're achieving with this

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
is good enough to be used in films.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
And let's just have a look at a slightly different visualization.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
This is something I just got last night

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
from an animation studio in London, who are using our software

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
and experimenting with it right now.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
So this is exactly the same behavior that you saw,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
but in a slightly better rendered version.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
So if you look at the character carefully,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
you see there are lots of body movements going on,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
none of which you have to animate like in the old days.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
Animators had to actually animate them.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
This is all happening automatically in the simulation.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
This is a slightly different angle,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and again a slow motion version of this.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
This is incredibly quick. This is happening in real time.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
You can run this simulation in real time, in front of your eyes,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
change it, if you want to, and you get the animation straight out of it.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
At the moment, doing something like this by hand

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
would take you probably a couple of days.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
This is another behavior they requested.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
I'm not quite sure why, but we've done it anyway.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
It's a very simple behavior that shows you the power of this approach.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
In this case, the character's hands

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
are fixed to a particular point in space,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
and all we've told the character to do is to struggle.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
And it looks organic. It looks realistic.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
You feel kind of sorry for the guy.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
It's even worse -- and that is another video I just got last night --

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
if you render that a bit more realistically.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Now, I'm showing this to you just to show you

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
how organic it actually can feel, how realistic it can look.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
And this is all a physical simulation of the body,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
using AI to drive virtual muscles in that body.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
Now, one thing which we did for a laugh was

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
to create a slightly more complex stunt scene,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and one of the most famous stunts is the one where James Bond

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
jumps off a dam in Switzerland and then is caught by a bungee.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
Got a very short clip here.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
Yes, you can just about see it here.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
In this case, they were using a real stunt man. It was a very dangerous stunt.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
It was just voted, I think in the Sunday Times, as one of the most impressive stunts.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Now, we've just tried and -- looked at our character and asked ourselves,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
"Can we do that ourselves as well?"

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Can we use the physical simulation of the character,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
use artificial intelligence,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
put that artificial intelligence into the character,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
drive virtual muscles, simulate the way he jumps off the dam,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
and then skydive afterwards,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
and have him caught by a bungee afterwards?

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
We did that. It took about altogether just two hours,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
pretty much, to create the simulation.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And that's what it looks like, here.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
Now, this could do with a bit more work. It's still very early stages,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and we pretty much just did this for a laugh,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
just to see what we'd get out of it.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
But what we found over the past few months

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
is that this approach -- that we're pretty much standard upon --

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
is incredibly powerful.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
We are ourselves surprised what you actually get out of the simulations.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
There's very often very surprising behavior that you didn't predict before.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
There's so many things we can do with this right now.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
The first thing, as I said, is going to be virtual stuntmen.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Several studios are using this software now to produce virtual stuntmen,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
and they're going to hit the screen quite soon, actually,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
for some major productions.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
The second thing is video games.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
With this technology, video games will look different and they will feel very different.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
For the first time, you'll have actors that really feel very interactive,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
that have real bodies that really react.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
I think that's going to be incredibly exciting.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
Probably starting with sports games,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
which are going to become much more interactive.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:31.958
But I particularly am really excited

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
about using this technology in online worlds,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
like there, for example, that Tom Melcher has shown us.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
The degree of interactivity you're going to get

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
is totally different, I think, from what you're getting right now.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:47.958
A third thing we are looking at and very interested in is simulation.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
We've been approached by several simulation companies,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
but one project we're particularly excited about, which we're starting next month,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
is to use our technology -- and in particular, the walking technology --

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:01.958
to help aid surgeons who work on children with cerebral palsy,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
to predict the outcome of operations on these children.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
As you probably know,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
it's very difficult to predict what the outcome of an operation is

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
if you try and correct the gait.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
The classic quote is, I think, it's unpredictable at best,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
is what people think right now, is the outcome.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Now, what we want to do with our software is allow our surgeons to have a tool.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
We're going to simulate the gait of a particular child

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and the surgeon can then work on that simulation

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and try out different ways to improve that gait,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
before he actually commits to an actual surgery.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
That's one project we're particularly excited about,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
and that's going to start next month.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
Just finally, this is only just the beginning.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
We can only do several behaviors right now.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
The AI isn't good enough to simulate a full human body.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
The body yes, but not all the motor skills that we have.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
And, I think, we're only there if we can have something like ballet dancing.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Right now, we don't have that

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
but I'm very sure that we will be able to do that at some stage.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
We do have one unintentional dancer actually,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
the last thing I'm going to show you.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
This was an AI contour that was produced and evolved --

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
half-evolved, I should say -- to produce balance, basically.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
So, you kick the guy and the guy's supposed to counter-balance.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
That's what we thought was going to come out of this.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
But this is what emerged out of it, in the end.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:26.958
(Music)

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
Bizarrely, this thing doesn't have a head. I'm not quite sure why.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
So, this was not something we actually put in there.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.958
He just started to create that dance himself.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
He's actually a better dancer than I am, I have to say.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
And what you see after a while --

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:44.958
I think he even goes into a climax right at the end.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
And I think -- there you go.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
(Laughter)

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
So, that all happened automatically. We didn't put that in there.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
That's just the simulation creating this itself, basically.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
So it's just --

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:01.958
(Applause)

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
Thanks.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
Not quite John Travolta yet, but we're working on that as well,

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
so thanks very much for your time.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:10.958
Thanks.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:11.958
(Applause)

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
CA: Incredible. That was really incredible.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:14.958
TR: Thanks.

title: What happens when you lose everything
transcript: I had a fire nine days ago. My archive: 175 films, my 16-millimeter negative, all my books, my dad's books, my photographs. I'd collected — I was a collector, major, big-time. It's gone. I just looked at it, and I didn't know what to do. I mean, this was — was I my things? I always live in the present — I love the present.I cherish the future. And I was taught some strange thing as a kid, like, you've got to make something good out of something bad. You've got to make something good out of something bad. This was bad! Man, I was — I cough. I was sick. That's my camera lens. The first one — the one I shot my Bob Dylan film with 35 years ago. That's my feature film. "King, Murray" won Cannes Film Festival 1970 — the only print I had. That's my papers.That was in minutes — 20 minutes. Epiphany hit me. Something hit me. "You've got to make something good out of something bad," I started to say to my friends, neighbors, my sister. By the way, that's "Sputnik." I ran it last year. "Sputnik" was downtown, the negative. It wasn't touched. These are some pieces of things I used in my Sputnik feature film, which opens in New York in two weeks downtown. I called my sister. I called my neighbors. I said, "Come dig." That's me at my desk. That was a desk took 40-some years to build. You know — all the stuff. That's my daughter, Jean. She came. She's a nurse in San Francisco."Dig it up," I said. "Pieces. I want pieces. Bits and pieces." I came up with this idea: a life of bits and pieces, which I'm just starting to work on — my next project. That's my sister. She took care of pictures, because I was a big collector of snapshot photography that I believed said a lot. And those are some of the pictures that — something was good about the burnt pictures. I didn't know. I looked at that — I said, "Wow, is that better than the —" That's my proposal on Jimmy Doolittle. I made that movie for television. It's the only copy I had. Pieces of it. Idea about women.So I started to say, "Hey, man, you are too much! You could cry about this." I really didn't. I just instead said, "I'm going to make something out of it, and maybe next year ... " And I appreciate this moment to come up on this stage with so many people who've already given me so much solace, and just say to TEDsters: I'm proud of me. That I take something bad, I turn it, and I'm going to make something good out of this, all these pieces. That's Arthur Leipzig's original photograph I loved. I was a big record collector — the records didn't make it. Boy, I tell you, film burns. Film burns. I mean, this was 16-millimeter safety film. The negatives are gone.That's my father's letter to me, telling me to marry the woman I first married when I was 20. That's my daughter and me. She's still there. She's there this morning, actually. That's my house. My family's living in the Hilton Hotel in Scotts Valley. That's my wife, Heidi, who didn't take it as well as I did. My children, Davey and Henry. My son, Davey, in the hotel two nights ago.So, my message to you folks, from my three minutes, is that I appreciate the chance to share this with you. I will be back. I love being at TED. I came to live it, and I am living it. That's my view from my window outside of Santa Cruz, in Bonny Doon, just 35 miles from here. Thank you everybody.(Applause)

title: Institutions vs. collaboration
transcript: How do groups get anything done? Right? How do you organize a group of individuals so that the output of the group is something coherent and of lasting value, instead of just being chaos? And the economic framing of that problem is called coordination costs. And a coordination cost is essentially all of the financial or institutional difficulties in arranging group output. And we've had a classic answer for coordination costs, which is, if you want to coordinate the work of a group of people, you start an institution, right? You raise some resources. You found something. It can be private or public. It can be for profit or not profit. It can be large or small. But you get these resources together. You found an institution, and you use the institution to coordinate the activities of the group.More recently, because the cost of letting groups communicate with each other has fallen through the floor — and communication costs are one of the big inputs to coordination — there has been a second answer, which is to put the cooperation into the infrastructure, to design systems that coordinate the output of the group as a by-product of the operating of the system, without regard to institutional models. So, that's what I want to talk about today. I'm going to illustrate it with some fairly concrete examples, but always pointing to the broader themes.So, I'm going to start by trying to answer a question that I know each of you will have asked yourself at some point or other, and which the Internet is purpose-built to answer, which is, where can I get a picture of a roller-skating mermaid? So, in New York City, on the first Saturday of every summer, Coney Island, our local, charmingly run-down amusement park, hosts the Mermaid Parade. It's an amateur parade; people come from all over the city; people get all dressed up. Some people get less dressed up. Young and old, dancing in the streets. Colorful characters, and a good time is had by all. And what I want to call your attention to is not the Mermaid Parade itself, charming though it is, but rather to these photos. I didn't take them. How did I get them? And the answer is: I got them from Flickr.Flickr is a photo-sharing service that allows people to take photos, upload them, share them over the Web and so forth. Recently, Flickr has added an additional function called tagging. Tagging was pioneered by Delicious and Joshua Schachter. Delicious is a social bookmarking service. Tagging is a cooperative infrastructure answer to classification. Right? If I had given this talk last year, I couldn't do what I just did, because I couldn't have found those photos. But instead of saying, we need to hire a professional class of librarians to organize these photos once they're uploaded, Flickr simply turned over to the users the ability to characterize the photos. So, I was able to go in and draw down photos that had been tagged "Mermaid Parade." There were 3,100 photos taken by 118 photographers, all aggregated and then put under this nice, neat name, shown in reverse chronological order. And I was then able to go and retrieve them to give you that little slideshow.Now, what hard problem is being solved here? And it's — in the most schematic possible view, it's a coordination problem, right? There are a large number of people on the Internet, a very small fraction of them have photos of the Mermaid Parade. How do we get those people together to contribute that work? The classic answer is to form an institution, right? To draw those people into some prearranged structure that has explicit goals. And I want to call your attention to some of the side effects of going the institutional route.First of all, when you form an institution, you take on a management problem, right? No good just hiring employees, you also have to hire other employees to manage those employees and to enforce the goals of the institution and so forth. Secondly, you have to bring structure into place. Right? You have to have economic structure. You have to have legal structure. You have to have physical structure. And that creates additional costs. Third, forming an institution is inherently exclusionary. You notice we haven't got everybody who has a photo. You can't hire everyone in a company, right? You can't recruit everyone into a governmental organization. You have to exclude some people. And fourth, as a result of that exclusion, you end up with a professional class. Look at the change here. We've gone from people with photos to photographers. Right? We've created a professional class of photographers whose goal is to go out and photograph the Mermaid Parade, or whatever else they're sent out to photograph.When you build cooperation into the infrastructure, which is the Flickr answer, you can leave the people where they are and you take the problem to the individuals, rather than moving the individuals to the problem. You arrange the coordination in the group, and by doing that you get the same outcome, without the institutional difficulties. You lose the institutional imperative. You lose the right to shape people's work when it's volunteer effort, but you also shed the institutional cost, which gives you greater flexibility. What Flickr does is it replaces planning with coordination. And this is a general aspect of these cooperative systems.Right. You'll have experienced this in your life whenever you bought your first mobile phone, and you stopped making plans. You just said, "I'll call you when I get there." "Call me when you get off work." Right? That is a point-to-point replacement of coordination with planning. Right. We're now able to do that kind of thing with groups. To say instead of, we must make an advance plan, we must have a five-year projection of where the Wikipedia is going to be, or whatever, you can just say, let's coordinate the group effort, and let's deal with it as we go, because we're now well-enough coordinated that we don't have to take on the problems of deciding in advance what to do.So here's another example. This one's somewhat more somber. These are photos on Flickr tagged "Iraq." And everything that was hard about the coordination cost with the Mermaid Parade is even harder here. There are more pictures. There are more photographers. It's taken over a wider geographic area. The photos are spread out over a longer period of time. And worst of all, that figure at the bottom, approximately ten photos per photographer, is a lie. It's mathematically true, but it doesn't really talk about anything important — because in these systems, the average isn't really what matters.What matters is this. This is a graph of photographs tagged Iraq as taken by the 529 photographers who contributed the 5,445 photos. And it's ranked in order of number of photos taken per photographer. You can see here, over at the end, our most prolific photographer has taken around 350 photos, and you can see there's a few people who have taken hundreds of photos. Then there's dozens of people who've taken dozens of photos. And by the time we get around here, we get ten or fewer photos, and then there's this long, flat tail. And by the time you get to the middle, you've got hundreds of people who have contributed only one photo each.This is called a power-law distribution. It appears often in unconstrained social systems where people are allowed to contribute as much or as little as they like — this is often what you get. Right? The math behind the power-law distribution is that whatever's in the nth position is doing about one-nth of whatever's being measured, relative to the person in the first position. So, we'd expect the tenth most prolific photographer to have contributed about a tenth of the photos, and the hundredth most prolific photographer to have contributed only about a hundred as many photos as the most prolific photographer did. So, the head of the curve can be sharper or flatter. But that basic math accounts both for the steep slope and for the long, flat tail.And curiously, in these systems, as they grow larger, the systems don't converge; they diverge more. In bigger systems, the head gets bigger and the tail gets longer, so the imbalance increases. You can see the curve is obviously heavily left-weighted. Here's how heavily: if you take the top 10 percent of photographers contributing to this system, they account for three quarters of the photos taken — just the top 10 percent most prolific photographers. If you go down to five percent, you're still accounting for 60 percent of the photos. If you go down to one percent, exclude 99 percent of the group effort, you're still accounting for almost a quarter of the photos. And because of this left weighting, the average is actually here, way to the left. And that sounds strange to our ears, but what ends up happening is that 80 percent of the contributors have contributed a below-average amount. That sounds strange because we expect average and middle to be about the same, but they're not at all.This is the math underlying the 80/20 rule. Right? Whenever you hear anybody talking about the 80/20 rule, this is what's going on. Right? 20 percent of the merchandise accounts for 80 percent of the revenue, 20 percent of the users use 80 percent of the resources — this is the shape people are talking about when that happens. Institutions only have two tools: carrots and sticks. And the 80 percent zone is a no-carrot and no-stick zone. The costs of running the institution mean that you cannot take on the work of those people easily in an institutional frame. The institutional model always pushes leftwards, treating these people as employees. The institutional response is, I can get 75 percent of the value for 10 percent of the hires — great, that's what I'll do. The cooperative infrastructure model says, why do you want to give up a quarter of the value? If your system is designed so that you have to give up a quarter of the value, re-engineer the system. Don't take on the cost that prevents you from getting to the contributions of these people. Build the system so that anybody can contribute at any amount.So the coordination response asks not, how are these people as employees, but rather, what is their contribution like? Right? We have over here Psycho Milt, a Flickr user, who has contributed one, and only one, photo titled "Iraq." And here's the photo. Right. Labeled, "Bad Day at Work." Right? So the question is, do you want that photo? Yes or no. The question is not, is Psycho Milt a good employee?And the tension here is between institution as enabler and institution as obstacle. When you're dealing with the left-hand edge of one of these distributions, when you're dealing with the people who spend a lot of time producing a lot of the material you want, that's an institution-as-enabler world. You can hire those people as employees, you can coordinate their work and you can get some output. But when you're down here, where the Psycho Milts of the world are adding one photo at a time, that's institution as obstacle.Institutions hate being told they're obstacles. One of the first things that happens when you institutionalize a problem is that the first goal of the institution immediately shifts from whatever the nominal goal was to self-preservation. And the actual goal of the institution goes to two through n. Right? So, when institutions are told they are obstacles, and that there are other ways of coordinating the value, they go through something a little bit like the Kubler-Ross stages — (Laughter) — of reaction, being told you have a fatal illness: denial, anger, bargaining, acceptance. Most of the cooperative systems we've seen haven't been around long enough to have gotten to the acceptance phase.Many, many institutions are still in denial, but we're seeing recently a lot of both anger and bargaining. There's a wonderful, small example going on right now. In France, a bus company is suing people for forming a carpool, right, because the fact that they have coordinated themselves to create cooperative value is depriving them of revenue. You can follow this in the Guardian. It's actually quite entertaining.The bigger question is, what do you do about the value down here? Right? How do you capture that? And institutions, as I've said, are prevented from capturing that. Steve Ballmer, now CEO of Microsoft, was criticizing Linux a couple of years ago, and he said, "Oh, this business of thousands of programmers contributing to Linux, this is a myth. We've looked at who's contributed to Linux, and most of the patches have been produced by programmers who've only done one thing." Right? You can hear this distribution under that complaint. And you can see why, from Ballmer's point of view, that's a bad idea, right? We hired this programmer, he came in, he drank our Cokes and played Foosball for three years and he had one idea. (Laughter) Right? Bad hire. Right? (Laughter)The Psycho Milt question is, was it a good idea? What if it was a security patch? What if it was a security patch for a buffer overflow exploit, of which Windows has not some, [but] several? Do you want that patch, right? The fact that a single programmer can, without having to move into a professional relation to an institution, improve Linux once and never be seen from again, should terrify Ballmer. Because this kind of value is unreachable in classic institutional frameworks, but is part of cooperative systems of open-source software, of file sharing,of the Wikipedia. I've used a lot of examples from Flickr, but there are actually stories about this from all over. Meetup, a service founded so that users could find people in their local area who share their interests and affinities and actually have a real-world meeting offline in a cafe or a pub or what have you. When Scott Heiferman founded Meetup, he thought it would be used for, you know, train spotters and cat fanciers — classic affinity groups. The inventors don't know what the invention is. Number one group on Meetup right now, most chapters in most cities with most members, most active? Stay-at-home moms. Right? In the suburbanized, dual-income United States, stay-at-home moms are actually missing the social infrastructure that comes from extended family and local, small-scale neighborhoods. So they're reinventing it, using these tools. Meetup is the platform, but the value here is in social infrastructure. If you want to know what technology is going to change the world, don't pay attention to 13-year-old boys — pay attention to young mothers, because they have got not an ounce of support for technology that doesn't materially make their lives better. This is so much more important than Xbox, but it's a lot less glitzy.I think this is a revolution. I think that this is a really profound change in the way human affairs are arranged. And I use that word advisedly. It's a revolution in that it's a change in equilibrium. It's a whole new way of doing things, which includes new downsides. In the United States right now, a woman named Judith Miller is in jail for not having given to a Federal Grand Jury her sources — she's a reporter for the New York Times — her sources, in a very abstract and hard-to-follow case. And journalists are in the street rallying to improve the shield laws. The shield laws are our laws — pretty much a patchwork of state laws — that prevent a journalist from having to betray a source. This is happening, however, against the background of the rise of Web logging. Web logging is a classic example of mass amateurization. It has de-professionalized publishing. Want to publish globally anything you think today? It is a one-button operation that you can do for free. That has sent the professional class of publishing down into the ranks of mass amateurization. And so the shield law, as much as we want it — we want a professional class of truth-tellers — it is becoming increasingly incoherent, because the institution is becoming incoherent. There are people in the States right now tying themselves into knots, trying to figure out whether or not bloggers are journalists. And the answer to that question is, it doesn't matter, because that's not the right question. Journalism was an answer to an even more important question, which is, how will society be informed? How will they share ideas and opinions? And if there is an answer to that that happens outside the professional framework of journalism, it makes no sense to take a professional metaphor and apply it to this distributed class. So as much as we want the shield laws, the background — the institution to which they were attached — is becoming incoherent.Here's another example. Pro-ana, the pro-ana groups. These are groups of teenage girls who have taken on Web logs, bulletin boards, other kinds of cooperative infrastructure, and have used it to set up support groups for remaining anorexic by choice. They post pictures of thin models, which they call "thinspiration." They have little slogans, like "Salvation through Starvation." They even have Lance Armstrong-style bracelets, these red bracelets, which signify, in the small group, I am trying to maintain my eating disorder. They trade tips, like, if you feel like eating something, clean a toilet or the litter box. The feeling will pass.We're used to support groups being beneficial. We have an attitude that support groups are inherently beneficial. But it turns out that the logic of the support group is value neutral. A support group is simply a small group that wants to maintain a way of living in the context of a larger group. Now, when the larger group is a bunch of drunks, and the small group wants to stay sober, then we think, that's a great support group. But when the small group is teenage girls who want to stay anorexic by choice, then we're horrified. What's happened is that the normative goals of the support groups that we're used to, came from the institutions that were framing them, and not from the infrastructure. Once the infrastructure becomes generically available, the logic of the support group has been revealed to be accessible to anyone, including people pursuing these kinds of goals.So, there are significant downsides to these changes as well as upsides. And of course, in the current environment, one need allude only lightly to the work of non-state actors trying to influence global affairs, and taking advantage of these. This is a social map of the hijackers and their associates who perpetrated the 9/11 attack. It was produced by analyzing their communications patterns using a lot of these tools. And doubtless the intelligence communities of the world are doing the same work today for the attacks of last week.Now, this is the part of the talk where I tell you what's going to come as a result of all of this, but I'm running out of time, which is good, because I don't know. (Laughter) Right. As with the printing press, if it's really a revolution, it doesn't take us from Point A to Point B. It takes us from Point A to chaos. The printing press precipitated 200 years of chaos, moving from a world where the Catholic Church was the sort of organizing political force to the Treaty of Westphalia, when we finally knew what the new unit was: the nation state.Now, I'm not predicting 200 years of chaos as a result of this. 50. 50 years in which loosely coordinated groups are going to be given increasingly high leverage, and the more those groups forego traditional institutional imperatives — like deciding in advance what's going to happen, or the profit motive — the more leverage they'll get. And institutions are going to come under an increasing degree of pressure, and the more rigidly managed, and the more they rely on information monopolies, the greater the pressure is going to be. And that's going to happen one arena at a time, one institution at a time. The forces are general, but the results are going to be specific.And so the point here is not, "This is wonderful," or "We're going to see a transition from only institutions to only cooperative framework." It's going to be much more complicated than that. But the point is that it's going to be a massive readjustment. And since we can see it in advance and know it's coming, my argument is essentially: we might as well get good at it. Thank you very much. (Applause)
