00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
you also have to hire other employees to manage those employees

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
and to enforce the goals of the institution and so forth.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Secondly, you have to bring structure into place.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
Right? You have to have economic structure.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
You have to have legal structure.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:00.958
You have to have physical structure.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
And that creates additional costs.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Third, forming an institution is inherently exclusionary.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:11.958
You notice we haven't got everybody who has a photo.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
You can't hire everyone in a company, right?

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
You can't recruit everyone into a governmental organization.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
You have to exclude some people.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
And fourth, as a result of that exclusion,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
you end up with a professional class. Look at the change here.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
We've gone from people with photos to photographers.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Right? We've created a professional class of photographers

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
whose goal is to go out and photograph the Mermaid Parade,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:39.958
or whatever else they're sent out to photograph.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
When you build cooperation into the infrastructure,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
which is the Flickr answer,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
you can leave the people where they are

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:51.958
and you take the problem to the individuals, rather than

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:52.958
moving the individuals to the problem.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:59.958
You arrange the coordination in the group, and by doing that

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
you get the same outcome, without the institutional difficulties.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
You lose the institutional imperative.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
You lose the right to shape people's work when it's volunteer effort,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
but you also shed the institutional cost,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
which gives you greater flexibility.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:18.958
What Flickr does is it replaces planning with coordination.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And this is a general aspect of these cooperative systems.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Right. You'll have experienced this in your life

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
whenever you bought your first mobile phone,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and you stopped making plans.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
You just said, "I'll call you when I get there."

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
"Call me when you get off work." Right?

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:37.958
That is a point-to-point replacement of coordination with planning.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
Right. We're now able to do that kind of thing with groups.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
To say instead of, we must make an advance plan,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:45.958
we must have a five-year projection

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
of where the Wikipedia is going to be, or whatever,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
you can just say, let's coordinate the group effort,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
and let's deal with it as we go,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:54.958
because we're now well-enough coordinated

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:59.958
that we don't have to take on the problems of deciding in advance what to do.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
So here's another example. This one's somewhat more somber.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
These are photos on Flickr tagged "Iraq."

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And everything that was hard about the coordination cost

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
with the Mermaid Parade is even harder here.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
There are more pictures. There are more photographers.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
It's taken over a wider geographic area.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
The photos are spread out over a longer period of time.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And worst of all, that figure at the bottom,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
approximately ten photos per photographer, is a lie.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
It's mathematically true,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
but it doesn't really talk about anything important --

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:40.958
because in these systems, the average isn't really what matters.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
What matters is this.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:47.958
This is a graph of photographs tagged Iraq

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:53.958
as taken by the 529 photographers who contributed the 5,445 photos.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:58.958
And it's ranked in order of number of photos taken per photographer.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
You can see here, over at the end,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
our most prolific photographer has taken around 350 photos,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and you can see there's a few people who have taken hundreds of photos.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Then there's dozens of people who've taken dozens of photos.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And by the time we get around here,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:17.958
we get ten or fewer photos, and then there's this long, flat tail.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
And by the time you get to the middle,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
you've got hundreds of people

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
who have contributed only one photo each.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
This is called a power-law distribution.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:31.958
It appears often in unconstrained social systems

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
where people are allowed to contribute as much or as little as they like --

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
this is often what you get. Right?

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
The math behind the power-law distribution is that whatever's in the nth position

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
is doing about one-nth of whatever's being measured,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
relative to the person in the first position.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
So, we'd expect the tenth most prolific photographer

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
to have contributed about a tenth of the photos,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
and the hundredth most prolific photographer

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
to have contributed only about a hundred as many photos

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
as the most prolific photographer did.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
So, the head of the curve can be sharper or flatter.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
But that basic math accounts both for the steep slope

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and for the long, flat tail.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
And curiously, in these systems, as they grow larger,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
the systems don't converge; they diverge more.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:14.958
In bigger systems, the head gets bigger

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:20.958
and the tail gets longer, so the imbalance increases.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
You can see the curve is obviously heavily left-weighted. Here's how heavily:

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
if you take the top 10 percent of photographers contributing to this system,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
they account for three quarters of the photos taken --

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
just the top 10 percent most prolific photographers.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
If you go down to five percent,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
you're still accounting for 60 percent of the photos.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:46.958
If you go down to one percent, exclude 99 percent of the group effort,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
you're still accounting for almost a quarter of the photos.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And because of this left weighting,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:56.958
the average is actually here, way to the left.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
And that sounds strange to our ears,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
but what ends up happening is that 80 percent of the contributors

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
have contributed a below-average amount.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
That sounds strange because we expect average and middle

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
to be about the same, but they're not at all.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
This is the math underlying the 80/20 rule. Right?

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Whenever you hear anybody talking about the 80/20 rule,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
this is what's going on. Right?

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:21.958
20 percent of the merchandise accounts for 80 percent of the revenue,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
20 percent of the users use 80 percent of the resources --

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
this is the shape people are talking about when that happens.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
Institutions only have two tools: carrots and sticks.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And the 80 percent zone is a no-carrot and no-stick zone.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:44.958
The costs of running the institution mean that you cannot

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
take on the work of those people easily in an institutional frame.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
The institutional model always pushes leftwards,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
treating these people as employees.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:54.958
The institutional response is,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
I can get 75 percent of the value for 10 percent of the hires -- great,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
that's what I'll do.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
The cooperative infrastructure model says,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
why do you want to give up a quarter of the value?

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
If your system is designed

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
so that you have to give up a quarter of the value,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
re-engineer the system.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Don't take on the cost that prevents you

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
from getting to the contributions of these people.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:23.958
Build the system so that anybody can contribute at any amount.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:29.958
So the coordination response asks not,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
how are these people as employees, but rather,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
what is their contribution like? Right?

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
We have over here Psycho Milt, a Flickr user,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
who has contributed one, and only one, photo titled "Iraq."

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
And here's the photo. Right. Labeled, "Bad Day at Work."

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Right? So the question is,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
do you want that photo? Yes or no.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
The question is not, is Psycho Milt a good employee?

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:01.958
And the tension here is between institution as enabler

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
and institution as obstacle.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
When you're dealing with the left-hand edge

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
of one of these distributions,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
when you're dealing with the people who spend a lot of time

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
producing a lot of the material you want,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
that's an institution-as-enabler world.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
You can hire those people as employees, you can coordinate their work

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and you can get some output.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
But when you're down here, where the Psycho Milts of the world

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
are adding one photo at a time,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
that's institution as obstacle.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Institutions hate being told they're obstacles.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
One of the first things that happens

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
when you institutionalize a problem

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:38.958
is that the first goal of the institution

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
immediately shifts from whatever the nominal goal was

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
to self-preservation.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And the actual goal of the institution goes to two through n.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Right? So, when institutions are told they are obstacles,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
and that there are other ways of coordinating the value,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:56.958
they go through something a little bit like the Kubler-Ross stages --

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:57.958
(Laughter)

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
-- of reaction, being told you have a fatal illness:

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
denial, anger, bargaining, acceptance.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Most of the cooperative systems we've seen

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:06.958
haven't been around long enough

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
to have gotten to the acceptance phase.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Many, many institutions are still in denial,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
but we're seeing recently a lot of both anger and bargaining.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
There's a wonderful, small example going on right now.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:23.958
In France, a bus company is suing people for forming a carpool,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
right, because the fact that they have coordinated

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:32.958
themselves to create cooperative value is depriving them of revenue.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:33.958
You can follow this in the Guardian.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:37.958
It's actually quite entertaining.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
The bigger question is,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
what do you do about the value down here?

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
Right? How do you capture that?

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And institutions, as I've said, are prevented from capturing that.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
Steve Ballmer, now CEO of Microsoft,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
was criticizing Linux a couple of years ago, and he said,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
"Oh, this business of thousands of programmers

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
contributing to Linux, this is a myth.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
We've looked at who's contributed to Linux,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
and most of the patches have been produced by programmers

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
who've only done one thing." Right?

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
You can hear this distribution under that complaint.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
And you can see why, from Ballmer's point of view,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:14.958
that's a bad idea, right?

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
We hired this programmer, he came in, he drank our Cokes

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and played Foosball for three years and he had one idea.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:20.958
(Laughter)

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
Right? Bad hire. Right?

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
(Laughter)

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:30.958
The Psycho Milt question is, was it a good idea?

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
What if it was a security patch?

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
What if it was a security patch for a buffer overflow exploit,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
of which Windows has not some, [but] several?

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Do you want that patch, right?

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
The fact that a single programmer can,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
without having to move into a professional relation

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
to an institution, improve Linux once

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and never be seen from again, should terrify Ballmer.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:58.958
Because this kind of value is unreachable in classic

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
institutional frameworks, but is part of cooperative

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
systems of open-source software, of file sharing,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
of the Wikipedia. I've used a lot of examples from Flickr,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
but there are actually stories about this from all over.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
Meetup, a service founded so that users could find people

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
in their local area who share their interests and affinities

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:18.958
and actually have a real-world meeting offline in a cafe

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
or a pub or what have you.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
When Scott Heiferman founded Meetup,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
he thought it would be used for, you know,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
train spotters and cat fanciers -- classic affinity groups.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
The inventors don't know what the invention is.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Number one group on Meetup right now,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
most chapters in most cities with most members, most active?

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Stay-at-home moms. Right?

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
In the suburbanized, dual-income United States,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
stay-at-home moms are actually missing

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
the social infrastructure that comes from extended family

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and local, small-scale neighborhoods.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
So they're reinventing it, using these tools.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:52.958
Meetup is the platform,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
but the value here is in social infrastructure.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
If you want to know what technology is going to change the world,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
don't pay attention to 13-year-old boys --

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
pay attention to young mothers,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
because they have got not an ounce of support for technology

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
that doesn't materially make their lives better.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
This is so much more important than Xbox,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
but it's a lot less glitzy.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
I think this is a revolution.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
I think that this is a really profound change

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:18.958
in the way human affairs are arranged.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And I use that word advisedly.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
It's a revolution in that it's a change in equilibrium.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:29.958
It's a whole new way of doing things, which includes new downsides.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
In the United States right now, a woman named Judith Miller

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:37.958
is in jail for not having given to a Federal Grand Jury her sources --

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:38.958
she's a reporter for the New York Times --

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
her sources, in a very abstract and hard-to-follow case.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
And journalists are in the street rallying to improve the shield laws.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:48.958
The shield laws are our laws -- pretty much a patchwork of state laws --

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
that prevent a journalist from having to betray a source.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
This is happening, however, against the background

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
of the rise of Web logging.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
Web logging is a classic example of mass amateurization.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
It has de-professionalized publishing.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
Want to publish globally anything you think today?

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
It is a one-button operation that you can do for free.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
That has sent the professional class of publishing down

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
into the ranks of mass amateurization.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
And so the shield law, as much as we want it --

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
we want a professional class of truth-tellers --

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
it is becoming increasingly incoherent, because

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
the institution is becoming incoherent.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
There are people in the States right now

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
tying themselves into knots, trying to figure out

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
whether or not bloggers are journalists.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
And the answer to that question is,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
it doesn't matter, because that's not the right question.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Journalism was an answer to an even more important question,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
which is, how will society be informed?

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
How will they share ideas and opinions?

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
And if there is an answer to that that happens outside

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
the professional framework of journalism,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
it makes no sense to take a professional metaphor

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and apply it to this distributed class.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
So as much as we want the shield laws,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:07.958
the background -- the institution to which they were attached --

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
is becoming incoherent.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
Here's another example.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
Pro-ana, the pro-ana groups.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
These are groups of teenage girls

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
who have taken on Web logs, bulletin boards,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
other kinds of cooperative infrastructure,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
and have used it to set up support groups for

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
remaining anorexic by choice.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
They post pictures of thin models, which they call "thinspiration."

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
They have little slogans, like "Salvation through Starvation."

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
They even have Lance Armstrong-style bracelets,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
these red bracelets, which signify, in the small group,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
I am trying to maintain my eating disorder.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
They trade tips, like, if you feel like eating something,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:45.958
clean a toilet or the litter box. The feeling will pass.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
We're used to support groups being beneficial.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
We have an attitude that support groups are inherently beneficial.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:55.958
But it turns out that the logic of the support group is value neutral.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:59.958
A support group is simply a small group that wants to maintain

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
a way of living in the context of a larger group.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
Now, when the larger group is a bunch of drunks,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
and the small group wants to stay sober, then we think,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
that's a great support group.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
But when the small group is teenage girls

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:14.958
who want to stay anorexic by choice, then we're horrified.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
What's happened is that the normative goals

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
of the support groups that we're used to,

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
came from the institutions that were framing them,

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:23.958
and not from the infrastructure.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:27.958
Once the infrastructure becomes generically available,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
the logic of the support group has been revealed to be

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:34.958
accessible to anyone, including people pursuing these kinds of goals.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:36.958
So, there are significant downsides to these changes

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:39.958
as well as upsides. And of course, in the current environment,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:44.958
one need allude only lightly to the work of non-state actors

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:47.958
trying to influence global affairs, and taking advantage of these.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
This is a social map of the hijackers and their associates

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
who perpetrated the 9/11 attack.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
It was produced by analyzing their communications patterns

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
using a lot of these tools. And doubtless the intelligence communities of the world

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
are doing the same work today for the attacks of last week.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
Now, this is the part of the talk where I tell you

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
what's going to come as a result of all of this,

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
but I'm running out of time, which is good,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
because I don't know.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
(Laughter)

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:20.958
Right. As with the printing press, if it's really a revolution,

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:22.958
it doesn't take us from Point A to Point B.

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:25.958
It takes us from Point A to chaos.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:30.958
The printing press precipitated 200 years of chaos,

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:32.958
moving from a world where the Catholic Church

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:36.958
was the sort of organizing political force to the Treaty of Westphalia,

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
when we finally knew what the new unit was: the nation state.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:44.958
Now, I'm not predicting 200 years of chaos as a result of this. 50.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:48.958
50 years in which loosely coordinated groups

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:51.958
are going to be given increasingly high leverage,

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:55.958
and the more those groups forego traditional institutional imperatives --

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:58.958
like deciding in advance what's going to happen,

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
or the profit motive -- the more leverage they'll get.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
And institutions are going to come under

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
an increasing degree of pressure,

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:07.958
and the more rigidly managed, and the more they rely

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:11.958
on information monopolies, the greater the pressure is going to be.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
And that's going to happen one arena at a time,

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:16.958
one institution at a time. The forces are general,

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
but the results are going to be specific.

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:20.958
And so the point here is not,

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:23.958
"This is wonderful," or "We're going to see a transition

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:26.958
from only institutions to only cooperative framework."

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
It's going to be much more complicated than that.

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:31.958
But the point is that it's going to be a massive readjustment.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:33.958
And since we can see it in advance and know it's coming,

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:36.958
my argument is essentially: we might as well get good at it.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:38.958
Thank you very much.

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:40.958
(Applause)

title: Let's look for life in the outer solar system
transcript: How will we be remembered in 200 years? I happen to live in a little town, Princeton, in New Jersey, which every year celebrates the great event in Princeton history: the Battle of Princeton, which was, in fact, a very important battle. It was the first battle that George Washington won, in fact, and was pretty much of a turning point in the war of independence. It happened 225 years ago. It was actually a terrible disaster for Princeton. The town was burned down; it was in the middle of winter, and it was a very, very severe winter. And about a quarter of all the people in Princeton died that winter from hunger and cold, but nobody remembers that. What they remember is, of course, the great triumph, that the Brits were beaten, and we won, and that the country was born. And so I agree very emphatically that the pain of childbirth is not remembered. It's the child that's remembered. And that's what we're going through at this time.I wanted to just talk for one minute about the future of biotechnology, because I think I know very little about that — I'm not a biologist — so everything I know about it can be said in one minute. (Laughter) What I'm saying is that we should follow the model that has been so successful with the electronic industry, that what really turned computers into a great success, in the world as a whole, is toys. As soon as computers became toys, when kids could come home and play with them, then the industry really took off. And that has to happen with biotech.There's a huge — (Laughter) (Applause) — there's a huge community of people in the world who are practical biologists, who are dog breeders, pigeon breeders, orchid breeders, rose breeders, people who handle biology with their hands, and who are dedicated to producing beautiful things, beautiful creatures, plants, animals, pets. These people will be empowered with biotech, and that will be an enormous positive step to acceptance of biotechnology. That will blow away a lot of the opposition. When people have this technology in their hands, you have a do-it-yourself biotech kit, grow your own — grow your dog, grow your own cat. (Laughter) (Applause) Just buy the software, you design it. I won't say anymore, you can take it on from there. It's going to happen, and I think it has to happen before the technology becomes natural, becomes part of the human condition, something that everybody's familiar with and everybody accepts.So, let's leave that aside. I want to talk about something quite different, which is what I know about, and that is astronomy. And I'm interested in searching for life in the universe. And it's open to us to introduce a new way of doing that, and that's what I'll talk about for 10 minutes, or whatever the time remains. The important fact is, that most of the real estate that's accessible to us — I'm not talking about the stars, I'm talking about the solar system, the stuff that's within reach for spacecraft and within reach of our earthbound telescopes — most of the real estate is very cold and very far from the Sun.If you look at the solar system, as we know it today, it has a few planets close to the Sun. That's where we live. It has a fairly substantial number of asteroids between the orbit of the Earth out through — to the orbit of Jupiter. The asteroids are a substantial amount of real estate, but not very large. And it's not very promising for life, since most of it consists of rock and metal, mostly rock. It's not only cold, but very dry. So the asteroids we don't have much hope for.There stand some interesting places a little further out: the moons of Jupiter and Saturn. Particularly, there's a place called Europa, which is — Europa is one of the moons of Jupiter, where we see a very level ice surface, which looks as if it's floating on top of an ocean. So, we believe that on Europa there is, in fact, a deep ocean. And that makes it extraordinarily interesting as a place to explore. Ocean — probably the most likely place for life to originate, just as it originated on the Earth. So we would love to explore Europa, to go down through the ice, find out who is swimming around in the ocean, whether there are fish or seaweed or sea monsters — whatever there may be that's exciting —- or cephalopods. But that's hard to do. Unfortunately, the ice is thick. We don't know just how thick it is, probably miles thick, so it's very expensive and very difficult to go down there — send down your submarine or whatever it is — and explore. That's something we don't yet know how to do. There are plans to do it, but it's hard.Go out a bit further, you'll find that beyond the orbit of Neptune, way out, far from the Sun, that's where the real estate really begins. You'll find millions or trillions or billions of objects which, in what we call the Kuiper Belt or the Oort Cloud — these are clouds of small objects which appear as comets when they fall close to the Sun. Mostly, they just live out there in the cold of the outer solar system, but they are biologically very interesting indeed, because they consist primarily of ice with other minerals, which are just the right ones for developing life. So if life could be established out there, it would have all the essentials — chemistry and sunlight — everything that's needed.So, what I'm proposing is that there is where we should be looking for life, rather than on Mars, although Mars is, of course, also a very promising and interesting place. But we can look outside, very cheaply and in a simple fashion. And that's what I'm going to talk about. There is a — imagine that life originated on Europa, and it was sitting in the ocean for billions of years. It's quite likely that it would move out of the ocean onto the surface, just as it did on the Earth. Staying in the ocean and evolving in the ocean for 2 billion years, finally came out onto the land. And then of course it had great — much greater freedom, and a much greater variety of creatures developed on the land than had ever been possible in the ocean. And the step from the ocean to the land was not easy, but it happened.Now, if life had originated on Europa in the ocean, it could also have moved out onto the surface. There wouldn't have been any air there — it's a vacuum. It is out in the cold, but it still could have come. You can imagine that the plants growing up like kelp through cracks in the ice, growing on the surface. What would they need in order to grow on the surface? They'd need, first of all, to have a thick skin to protect themselves from losing water through the skin. So they would have to have something like a reptilian skin. But better — what is more important is that they would have to concentrate sunlight. The sunlight in Jupiter, on the satellites of Jupiter, is 25 times fainter than it is here, since Jupiter is five times as far from the Sun. So they would have to have — these creatures, which I call sunflowers, which I imagine living on the surface of Europa, would have to have either lenses or mirrors to concentrate sunlight, so they could keep themselves warm on the surface. Otherwise, they would be at a temperature of minus 150, which is certainly not favorable for developing life, at least of the kind we know. But if they just simply could grow, like leaves, little lenses and mirrors to concentrate sunlight, then they could keep warm on the surface. They could enjoy all the benefits of the sunlight and have roots going down into the ocean; life then could flourish much more. So, why not look? Of course, it's not very likely that there's life on the surface of Europa. None of these things is likely, but my, my philosophy is, look for what's detectable, not for what's probable.There's a long history in astronomy of unlikely things turning out to be there. And I mean, the finest example of that was radio astronomy as a whole. This was — originally, when radio astronomy began, Mr. Jansky, at the Bell labs, detected radio waves coming from the sky. And the regular astronomers were scornful about this. They said, "It's all right, you can detect radio waves from the Sun, but the Sun is the only object in the universe that's close enough and bright enough actually to be detectable. You can easily calculate that radio waves from the Sun are fairly faint, and everything else in the universe is millions of times further away, so it certainly will not be detectable. So there's no point in looking." And that, of course, that set back the progress of radio astronomy by about 20 years. Since there was nothing there, you might as well not look. Well, of course, as soon as anybody did look, which was after about 20 years, when radio astronomy really took off. Because it turned out the universe is absolutely full of all kinds of wonderful things radiating in the radio spectrum, much brighter than the Sun. So, the same thing could be true for this kind of life, which I'm talking about, on cold objects: that it could in fact be very abundant all over the universe, and it's not been detected just because we haven't taken the trouble to look.So, the last thing I want to talk about is how to detect it. There is something called pit lamping. That's the phrase which I learned from my son George, who is there in the audience. You take — that's a Canadian expression. If you happen to want to hunt animals at night, you take a miner's lamp, which is a pit lamp. You strap it onto your forehead, so you can see the reflection in the eyes of the animal. So, if you go out at night, you shine a flashlight, the animals are bright. You see the red glow in their eyes, which is the reflection of the flashlight. And then, if you're one of these unsporting characters, you shoot the animals and take them home. And of course, that spoils the game for the other hunters who hunt in the daytime, so in Canada that's illegal. In New Zealand, it's legal, because the New Zealand farmers use this as a way of getting rid of rabbits, because the rabbits compete with the sheep in New Zealand. So, the farmers go out at night with heavily armed jeeps, and shine the headlights, and anything that doesn't look like a sheep, you shoot. (Laughter)So I have proposed to apply the same trick to looking for life in the universe. That if these creatures who are living on cold surfaces — either on Europa, or further out, anywhere where you can live on a cold surface — those creatures must be provided with reflectors. In order to concentrate sunlight, they have to have lenses and mirrors — in order to keep themselves warm. And then, when you shine sunlight at them, the sunlight will be reflected back, just as it is in the eyes of an animal. So these creatures will be bright against the cold surroundings. And the further out you go in this, away from the Sun, the more powerful this reflection will be. So actually, this method of hunting for life gets stronger and stronger as you go further away, because the optical reflectors have to be more powerful so the reflected light shines out even more in contrast against the dark background. So as you go further away from the Sun, this becomes more and more powerful. So, in fact, you can look for these creatures with telescopes from the Earth. Why aren't we doing it? Simply because nobody thought of it yet.But I hope that we shall look, and with any — we probably won't find anything, none of these speculations may have any basis in fact. But still, it's a good chance. And of course, if it happens, it will transform our view of life altogether. Because it means that — the way life can live out there, it has enormous advantages as compared with living on a planet. It's extremely hard to move from one planet to another. We're having great difficulties at the moment and any creatures that live on a planet are pretty well stuck. Especially if you breathe air, it's very hard to get from planet A to planet B, because there's no air in between. But if you breathe air — (Laughter) — you're dead — (Laughter) — as soon as you're off the planet, unless you have a spaceship.But if you live in a vacuum, if you live on the surface of one of these objects, say, in the Kuiper Belt, this — an object like Pluto, or one of the smaller objects in the neighborhood of Pluto, and you happened — if you're living on the surface there, and you get knocked off the surface by a collision, then it doesn't change anything all that much. You still are on a piece of ice, you can still have sunlight and you can still survive while you're traveling from one place to another. And then if you run into another object, you can stay there and colonize the other object. So life will spread, then, from one object to another. So if it exists at all in the Kuiper Belt, it's likely to be very widespread. And you will have then a great competition amongst species — Darwinian evolution — so there'll be a huge advantage to the species which is able to jump from one place to another without having to wait for a collision. And there'll be advantages for spreading out long, sort of kelp-like forest of vegetation. I call these creatures sunflowers. They look like, maybe like sunflowers. They have to be all the time pointing toward the Sun, and they will be able to spread out in space, because gravity on these objects is weak. So they can collect sunlight from a big area. So they will, in fact, be quite easy for us to detect.So, I hope in the next 10 years, we'll find these creatures, and then, of course, our whole view of life in the universe will change. If we don't find them, then we can create them ourselves. (Laughter) That's another wonderful opportunity that's opening. We can — as soon as we have a little bit more understanding of genetic engineering, one of the things you can do with your take-it-home, do-it-yourself genetic engineering kit — (Laughter) — is to design a creature that can live on a cold satellite, a place like Europa, so we could colonize Europa with our own creatures. That would be a fun thing to do. (Laughter) In the long run, of course, it would also make it possible for us to move out there. What's going to happen in the end, it's not going to be just humans colonizing space, it's going to be life moving out from the Earth, moving it into its kingdom. And the kingdom of life, of course, is going to be the universe. And if life is already there, it makes it much more exciting, in the short run. But in the long run, if there's no life there, we create it ourselves. We transform the universe into something much more rich and beautiful than it is today. So again, we have a big and wonderful future to look forward. Thank you. (Applause)

What they remember is, of course, the great triumph,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:07.958
that the Brits were beaten, and we won, and that the country was born.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:14.958
And so I agree very emphatically that the pain of childbirth is not remembered.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
It's the child that's remembered.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
And that's what we're going through at this time.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:28.958
I wanted to just talk for one minute about the future of biotechnology,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
because I think I know very little about that -- I'm not a biologist --

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
so everything I know about it can be said in one minute.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
(Laughter)

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
What I'm saying is that we should follow the model

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:44.958
that has been so successful with the electronic industry,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:49.958
that what really turned computers into a great success, in the world

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:54.958
as a whole, is toys. As soon as computers became toys,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
when kids could come home and play with them,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:02.958
then the industry really took off. And that has to happen with biotech.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:03.958
There's a huge --

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
(Laughter)

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
(Applause)

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
-- there's a huge community of people in the world

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
who are practical biologists, who are dog breeders,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:21.958
pigeon breeders, orchid breeders, rose breeders,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
people who handle biology with their hands,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and who are dedicated to producing beautiful things, beautiful creatures,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:38.958
plants, animals, pets. These people will be empowered with biotech,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:44.958
and that will be an enormous positive step

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:48.958
to acceptance of biotechnology.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:53.958
That will blow away a lot of the opposition.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
When people have this technology in their hands,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:03:03.958
you have a do-it-yourself biotech kit, grow your own --

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
grow your dog, grow your own cat.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
(Laughter)

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:11.958
(Applause)

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:17.958
Just buy the software, you design it. I won't say anymore,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:23.958
you can take it on from there. It's going to happen, and

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:31.958
I think it has to happen before the technology becomes natural,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
becomes part of the human condition,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
something that everybody's familiar with and everybody accepts.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
So, let's leave that aside.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
I want to talk about something quite different,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
which is what I know about, and that is astronomy.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And I'm interested in searching for life in the universe.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:56.958
And it's open to us to introduce a new way of doing that,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and that's what I'll talk about for 10 minutes,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
or whatever the time remains.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
The important fact is, that most of the real estate

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
that's accessible to us -- I'm not talking about the stars,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:15.958
I'm talking about the solar system, the stuff that's within reach

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:21.958
for spacecraft and within reach of our earthbound telescopes --

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:27.958
most of the real estate is very cold and very far from the Sun.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
If you look at the solar system, as we know it today,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:36.958
it has a few planets close to the Sun. That's where we live.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:42.958
It has a fairly substantial number of asteroids between

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:47.958
the orbit of the Earth out through -- to the orbit of Jupiter.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
The asteroids are a substantial amount of real estate,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:55.958
but not very large. And it's not very promising for life,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
since most of it consists of rock and metal, mostly rock.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:04.958
It's not only cold, but very dry.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:10.958
So the asteroids we don't have much hope for.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:15.958
There stand some interesting places a little further out:

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
the moons of Jupiter and Saturn.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
Particularly, there's a place called Europa, which is --

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Europa is one of the moons of Jupiter,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:27.958
where we see a very level ice surface,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
which looks as if it's floating on top of an ocean.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
So, we believe that on Europa there is, in fact, a deep ocean.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And that makes it extraordinarily interesting as a place to explore.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:45.958
Ocean -- probably the most likely place for life to originate,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:52.958
just as it originated on the Earth. So we would love to explore Europa,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
to go down through the ice,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
find out who is swimming around in the ocean,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:02.958
whether there are fish or seaweed or sea monsters --

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:08.958
whatever there may be that's exciting --- or cephalopods.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:14.958
But that's hard to do. Unfortunately, the ice is thick.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
We don't know just how thick it is, probably miles thick,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
so it's very expensive and very difficult to go down there --

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
send down your submarine or whatever it is -- and explore.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
That's something we don't yet know how to do.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:33.958
There are plans to do it, but it's hard.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Go out a bit further, you'll find that beyond the orbit of Neptune,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:42.958
way out, far from the Sun, that's where the real estate really begins.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:47.958
You'll find millions or trillions or billions of objects which,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
in what we call the Kuiper Belt or the Oort Cloud --

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:56.958
these are clouds of small objects which appear as comets

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
when they fall close to the Sun. Mostly, they just live out there

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
in the cold of the outer solar system,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
but they are biologically very interesting indeed,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
because they consist primarily of ice with other minerals,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
which are just the right ones for developing life.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
So if life could be established out there,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:23.958
it would have all the essentials -- chemistry and sunlight --

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
everything that's needed.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
So, what I'm proposing

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
is that there is where we should be looking for life, rather than on Mars,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
although Mars is, of course, also a very promising and interesting place.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:42.958
But we can look outside, very cheaply and in a simple fashion.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And that's what I'm going to talk about.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:51.958
There is a -- imagine that life originated on Europa,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
and it was sitting in the ocean for billions of years.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.958
It's quite likely that it would move out of the ocean onto the surface,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
just as it did on the Earth.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Staying in the ocean and evolving in the ocean for 2 billion years,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
finally came out onto the land. And then of course it had great --

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
much greater freedom, and a much greater variety of creatures

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
developed on the land than had ever been possible in the ocean.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:22.958
And the step from the ocean to the land was not easy, but it happened.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
Now, if life had originated on Europa in the ocean,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
it could also have moved out onto the surface.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
There wouldn't have been any air there -- it's a vacuum.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:37.958
It is out in the cold, but it still could have come.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
You can imagine that the plants growing up like kelp

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
through cracks in the ice, growing on the surface.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
What would they need in order to grow on the surface?

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:53.958
They'd need, first of all, to have a thick skin to protect themselves

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:59.958
from losing water through the skin.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:04.958
So they would have to have something like a reptilian skin.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
But better -- what is more important

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is that they would have to concentrate sunlight.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
The sunlight in Jupiter, on the satellites of Jupiter,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
is 25 times fainter than it is here,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
since Jupiter is five times as far from the Sun.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
So they would have to have -- these creatures, which I call sunflowers,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:29.958
which I imagine living on the surface of Europa, would have to have

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
either lenses or mirrors to concentrate sunlight,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
so they could keep themselves warm on the surface.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.958
Otherwise, they would be at a temperature of minus 150,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
which is certainly not favorable for developing life,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
at least of the kind we know.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
But if they just simply could grow, like leaves,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
little lenses and mirrors to concentrate sunlight,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
then they could keep warm on the surface.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:00.958
They could enjoy all the benefits of the sunlight

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and have roots going down into the ocean;

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
life then could flourish much more.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
So, why not look? Of course, it's not very likely

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
that there's life on the surface of Europa.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
None of these things is likely, but my,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:20.958
my philosophy is, look for what's detectable, not for what's probable.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
There's a long history in astronomy of unlikely things

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
turning out to be there. And I mean,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
the finest example of that was radio astronomy as a whole.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:34.958
This was -- originally, when radio astronomy began,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:44.958
Mr. Jansky, at the Bell labs, detected radio waves coming from the sky.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And the regular astronomers were scornful about this.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:54.958
They said, "It's all right, you can detect radio waves from the Sun,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
but the Sun is the only object in the universe that's close enough

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:02.958
and bright enough actually to be detectable. You can easily calculate

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
that radio waves from the Sun are fairly faint,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:12.958
and everything else in the universe is millions of times further away,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
so it certainly will not be detectable.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
So there's no point in looking."

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And that, of course, that set back the progress of radio astronomy

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:26.958
by about 20 years.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Since there was nothing there, you might as well not look.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
Well, of course, as soon as anybody did look,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
which was after about 20 years,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
when radio astronomy really took off. Because it turned out

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
the universe is absolutely full of all kinds of wonderful things

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:46.958
radiating in the radio spectrum, much brighter than the Sun.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So, the same thing could be true for this kind of life,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
which I'm talking about, on cold objects: that it could in fact

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
be very abundant all over the universe, and it's not been detected

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
just because we haven't taken the trouble to look.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:08.958
So, the last thing I want to talk about is how to detect it.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
There is something called pit lamping.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
That's the phrase which I learned from my son George,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
who is there in the audience.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:21.958
You take -- that's a Canadian expression.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
If you happen to want to hunt animals at night,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
you take a miner's lamp, which is a pit lamp.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
You strap it onto your forehead, so you can see

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.958
the reflection in the eyes of the animal. So, if you go out at night,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:41.958
you shine a flashlight, the animals are bright.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
You see the red glow in their eyes,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
which is the reflection of the flashlight.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:51.958
And then, if you're one of these unsporting characters,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
you shoot the animals and take them home.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And of course, that spoils the game

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
for the other hunters who hunt in the daytime,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:03.958
so in Canada that's illegal. In New Zealand, it's legal,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
because the New Zealand farmers use this as a way of getting rid of rabbits,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
because the rabbits compete with the sheep in New Zealand.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
So, the farmers go out at night

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:18.958
with heavily armed jeeps, and shine the headlights,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
and anything that doesn't look like a sheep, you shoot.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
(Laughter)

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
So I have proposed to apply the same trick

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
to looking for life in the universe.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
That if these creatures who are living on cold surfaces --

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
either on Europa, or further out, anywhere where you can live

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:42.958
on a cold surface -- those creatures must be provided with reflectors.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
In order to concentrate sunlight, they have to have lenses and mirrors --

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
in order to keep themselves warm.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
And then, when you shine sunlight at them,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
the sunlight will be reflected back,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
just as it is in the eyes of an animal.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
So these creatures will be bright against the cold surroundings.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
And the further out you go in this, away from the Sun,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
the more powerful this reflection will be. So actually,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
this method of hunting for life gets stronger and stronger

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
as you go further away,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:21.958
because the optical reflectors have to be more powerful so the reflected light

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:27.958
shines out even more in contrast against the dark background.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
So as you go further away from the Sun,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
this becomes more and more powerful.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:39.958
So, in fact, you can look for these creatures with telescopes from the Earth.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Why aren't we doing it? Simply because nobody thought of it yet.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:48.958
But I hope that we shall look, and with any --

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
we probably won't find anything,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
none of these speculations may have any basis in fact.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
But still, it's a good chance. And of course, if it happens,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
it will transform our view of life altogether.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:05.958
Because it means that -- the way life can live out there,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
it has enormous advantages as compared with living on a planet.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
It's extremely hard to move from one planet to another.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
We're having great difficulties at the moment

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
and any creatures that live on a planet are pretty well stuck.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
Especially if you breathe air,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
it's very hard to get from planet A to planet B,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
because there's no air in between. But if you breathe air --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:36.958
(Laughter)

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:37.958
-- you're dead --

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
(Laughter)

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
-- as soon as you're off the planet, unless you have a spaceship.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
But if you live in a vacuum, if you live on the surface

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
of one of these objects, say, in the Kuiper Belt,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
this -- an object like Pluto, or one of the

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
smaller objects in the neighborhood of Pluto,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
and you happened -- if you're living on the surface there,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
and you get knocked off the surface by a collision,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
then it doesn't change anything all that much.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:08.958
You still are on a piece of ice, you can still have sunlight

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and you can still survive while you're traveling from one place to another.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
And then if you run into another object, you can stay there

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
and colonize the other object. So life will spread, then,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
from one object to another. So if it exists at all in the Kuiper Belt,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
it's likely to be very widespread. And you will have then

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:31.958
a great competition amongst species -- Darwinian evolution --

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
so there'll be a huge advantage to the species

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
which is able to jump from one place to another

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:42.958
without having to wait for a collision. And there'll be advantages

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:49.958
for spreading out long, sort of kelp-like forest of vegetation.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
I call these creatures sunflowers.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
They look like, maybe like sunflowers.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
They have to be all the time pointing toward the Sun,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
and they will be able to spread out in space,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:04.958
because gravity on these objects is weak.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
So they can collect sunlight from a big area.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958
So they will, in fact, be quite easy for us to detect.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
So, I hope in the next 10 years, we'll find these creatures,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:19.958
and then, of course, our whole view of life in the universe will change.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:23.958
If we don't find them, then we can create them ourselves.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
(Laughter)

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:33.958
That's another wonderful opportunity that's opening.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
We can -- as soon as we have a little bit more understanding

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:41.958
of genetic engineering, one of the things you can do with your

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
take-it-home, do-it-yourself genetic engineering kit --

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
(Laughter) --

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
is to design a creature that can live on a cold satellite,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:54.958
a place like Europa, so we could colonize Europa with our own creatures.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:58.958
That would be a fun thing to do.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.958
(Laughter)

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
In the long run, of course,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:09.958
it would also make it possible for us to move out there.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
What's going to happen in the end,

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
it's not going to be just humans colonizing space,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
it's going to be life moving out from the Earth,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
moving it into its kingdom. And the kingdom of life,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:26.958
of course, is going to be the universe. And if life is already there,

title: The brain in love
transcript: I and my colleagues Art Aron and Lucy Brown and others, have put 37 people who are madly in love into a functional MRI brain scanner. 17 who were happily in love, 15 who had just been dumped, and we're just starting our third experiment: studying people who report that they're still in love after 10 to 25 years of marriage. So, this is the short story of that research.In the jungles of Guatemala, in Tikal, stands a temple. It was built by the grandest Sun King, of the grandest city-state, of the grandest civilization of the Americas, the Mayas. His name was Jasaw Chan K'awiil. He stood over six feet tall. He lived into his 80s, and he was buried beneath this monument in 720 AD. And Mayan inscriptions proclaim that he was deeply in love with his wife. So, he built a temple in her honor, facing his. And every spring and autumn, exactly at the equinox, the sun rises behind his temple, and perfectly bathes her temple with his shadow. And as the sun sets behind her temple in the afternoon, it perfectly bathes his temple with her shadow. After 1,300 years, these two lovers still touch and kiss from their tomb.Around the world, people love. They sing for love, they dance for love, they compose poems and stories about love. They tell myths and legends about love. They pine for love, they live for love, they kill for love, and they die for love. As Walt Whitman once said, "O I would stake all for you." Anthropologists have found evidence of romantic love in 170 societies. They've never found a society that did not have it.But love isn't always a happy experience. In one study of college students, they asked a lot of questions about love, but the two that stood out to me the most were: "Have you ever been rejected by somebody who you really loved?" And the second question was: "Have you ever dumped somebody who really loved you?" And almost 95 percent of both men and women said yes to both. Almost nobody gets out of love alive.So, before I start telling you about the brain, I want to read for you what I think is the most powerful love poem on Earth. There's other love poems that are, of course, just as good, but I don't think this one can be surpassed. It was told by an anonymous Kwakiutl Indian of southern Alaska to a missionary in 1896. And here it is. I've never had the opportunity to say it before. "Fire runs through my body with the pain of loving you. Pain runs through my body with the fires of my love for you. Pain like a boil about to burst with my love for you, consumed by fire with my love for you. I remember what you said to me. I am thinking of your love for me. I am torn by your love for me. Pain and more pain — where are you going with my love? I am told you will go from here. I am told you will leave me here. My body is numb with grief. Remember what I said, my love. Goodbye, my love, goodbye." Emily Dickinson once wrote, "Parting is all we need to know of hell." How many people have suffered in all the millions of years of human evolution? How many people around the world are dancing with elation at this very minute? Romantic love is one of the most powerful sensations on Earth.So, several years ago, I decided to look into the brain and study this madness. Our first study of people who were happily in love has been widely publicized, so I'm only going to say very little about it. We found activity in a tiny, little factory near the base of the brain called the ventral tegmental area. We found activity in some cells called the A10 cells, cells that actually make dopamine, a natural stimulant, and spray it to many brain regions. Indeed, this part, the VTA, is part of the brain's reward system. It's way below your cognitive thinking process. It's below your emotions. It's part of what we call the reptilian core of the brain, associated with wanting, with motivation, with focus and with craving. In fact, the same brain region where we found activity becomes active also when you feel the rush of cocaine.But romantic love is much more than a cocaine high — at least you come down from cocaine. Romantic love is an obsession, it possesses you. You lose your sense of self. You can't stop thinking about another human being. Somebody is camping in your head. As an eighth-century Japanese poet said, "My longing had no time when it ceases." Wild is love. And the obsession can get worse when you've been rejected.So, right now, Lucy Brown and I, the neuroscientists on our project, are looking at the data of the people who were put into the machine after they had just been dumped. It was very difficult actually, putting these people in the machine, because they were in such bad shape.(Laughter)So anyway, we found activity in three brain regions. We found activity in the brain region, in exactly the same brain region associated with intense romantic love. What a bad deal. You know, when you've been dumped, the one thing you love to do is just forget about this human being, and then go on with your life — but no, you just love them harder. As the poet Terence, the Roman poet once said, he said, "The less my hope, the hotter my love." And indeed, we now know why. Two thousand years later, we can explain this in the brain. That brain system — the reward system for wanting, for motivation, for craving, for focus — becomes more active when you can't get what you want. In this case, life's greatest prize: an appropriate mating partner.We found activity in other brain regions also — in a brain region associated with calculating gains and losses. You're lying there, you're looking at the picture, and you're in this machine, and you're calculating what went wrong. What have I lost? As a matter of fact, Lucy and I have a little joke about this. It comes from a David Mamet play, and there's two con artists in the play, and the woman is conning the man, and the man looks at the woman and says, "Oh, you're a bad pony, I'm not going to bet on you." And indeed, it's this part of the brain, the core of the nucleus accumbens, that is becoming active as you're measuring your gains and losses. It's also the brain region that becomes active when you're willing to take enormous risks for huge gains and huge losses.Last but not least, we found activity in a brain region associated with deep attachment to another individual. No wonder people suffer around the world, and we have so many crimes of passion. When you've been rejected in love, not only are you engulfed with feelings of romantic love, but you're feeling deep attachment to this individual. Moreover, this brain circuit for reward is working, and you're feeling intense energy, intense focus, intense motivation and the willingness to risk it all, to win life's greatest prize.So, what have I learned from this experiment that I would like to tell the world? Foremost, I have come to think that romantic love is a drive, a basic mating drive. Not the sex drive — the sex drive gets you looking for a whole range of partners. Romantic love enables you to focus your mating energy on just one at a time, conserve your mating energy, and start the mating process with this single individual. I think of all the poetry that I've read about romantic love, what sums it up best is something that is said by Plato over 2,000 years ago. He said, "The god of love lives in a state of need. It is a need, it is an urge, it is a homeostatic imbalance. Like hunger and thirst, it's almost impossible to stamp out." I've also come to believe that romantic love is an addiction: a perfectly wonderful addiction when it's going well, and a perfectly horrible addiction when it's going poorly.And indeed, it has all of the characteristics of addiction. You focus on the person, you obsessively think about them, you crave them, you distort reality, your willingness to take enormous risks to win this person. And it's got the three main characteristics of addiction: tolerance, you need to see them more, and more, and more; withdrawals; and last: relapse. I've got a girlfriend who's just getting over a terrible love affair. It's been about eight months, she's beginning to feel better. And she was driving along in her car the other day, and suddenly she heard a song on the car radio that reminded her of this man. Not only did the instant craving come back, but she had to pull over from the side of the road and cry. So, one thing I would like the medical community, and the legal community, and even the college community, to see if they can understand, that indeed, romantic love is one of the most addictive substances on Earth.I would also like to tell the world that animals love. There's not an animal on this planet that will copulate with anything that comes along. Too old, too young, too scruffy, too stupid, and they won't do it. Unless you're stuck in a laboratory cage — and you know, if you spend your entire life in a little box, you're not going to be as picky about who you have sex with, but I've looked in a hundred species, and everywhere in the wild, animals have favorites. As a matter of fact, ethologists know this. There are over eight words for what they call "animal favoritism:" selective proceptivity, mate choice, female choice, sexual choice. And indeed, there are now three academic articles in which they've looked at this attraction, which may only last for a second, but it's a definite attraction, and either this same brain region, this reward system, or the chemicals of that reward system are involved. In fact, I think animal attraction can be instant — you can see an elephant instantly go for another elephant. And I think that this is really the origin of what you and I call "love at first sight."People have often asked me whether what I know about love has spoiled it for me. And I just simply say, "Hardly." You can know every single ingredient in a piece of chocolate cake, and then when you sit down and eat that cake, you can still feel that joy. And certainly, I make all the same mistakes that everybody else does too, but it's really deepened my understanding and compassion, really, for all human life. As a matter of fact, in New York, I often catch myself looking in baby carriages and feeling a little sorry for the tot. And in fact, sometimes I feel a little sorry for the chicken on my dinner plate, when I think of how intense this brain system is. Our newest experiment has been hatched by my colleague, Art Aron — putting people who are reporting that they are still in love, in a long-term relationship, into the functional MRI. We've put five people in so far, and indeed, we found exactly the same thing. They're not lying. The brain areas associated with intense romantic love still become active, 25 years later.There are still many questions to be answered and asked about romantic love. The question that I'm working on right this minute — and I'm only going to say it for a second, and then end — is, why do you fall in love with one person, rather than another? I never would have even thought to think of this, but Match.com, the Internet dating site, came to me three years ago and asked me that question. And I said, I don't know. I know what happens in the brain, when you do become in love, but I don't know why you fall in love with one person rather than another. And so, I've spent the last three years on this. And there are many reasons that you fall in love with one person rather than another, that psychologists can tell you. And we tend to fall in love with somebody from the same socioeconomic background, the same general level of intelligence, of good looks, the same religious values. Your childhood certainly plays a role, but nobody knows how. And that's about it, that's all they know. No, they've never found the way two personalities fit together to make a good relationship.So, it began to occur to me that maybe your biology pulls you towards some people rather than another. And I have concocted a questionnaire to see to what degree you express dopamine, serotonin, estrogen and testosterone. I think we've evolved four very broad personality types associated with the ratios of these four chemicals in the brain. And on this dating site that I have created, called Chemistry.com, I ask you first a series of questions to see to what degree you express these chemicals, and I'm watching who chooses who to love. And 3.7 million people have taken the questionnaire in America. About 600,000 people have taken it in 33 other countries. I'm putting the data together now, and at some point — there will always be magic to love, but I think I will come closer to understanding why it is you can walk into a room and everybody is from your background, your same general level of intelligence, good looks, and you don't feel pulled towards all of them. I think there's biology to that. I think we're going to end up, in the next few years, to understand all kinds of brain mechanisms that pull us to one person rather than another.So, I will close with this. These are my older people. Faulkner said, "The past is not dead, it's not even past." Indeed, we carry a lot of luggage from our yesteryear in the human brain. And so, there's one thing that makes me pursue my understanding of human nature, and this reminds me of it. These are two women. Women tend to get intimacy differently than men do. Women get intimacy from face-to-face talking. We swivel towards each other, we do what we call the "anchoring gaze" and we talk. This is intimacy to women. I think it comes from millions of years of holding that baby in front of your face, cajoling it, reprimanding it, educating it with words. Men tend to get intimacy from side-by-side doing. As soon as one guy looks up, the other guy will look away.(Laughter)I think it comes from millions of years sitting behind the bush, looking straight ahead, trying to hit that buffalo on the head with a rock. I think, for millions of years, men faced their enemies, they sat side-by-side with friends. So my final statement is: love is in us. It's deeply embedded in the brain. Our challenge is to understand each other.Thank you.(Applause)
